PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1.The majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian national flag.

2.We therefore request that the Senate ensures that the Australian national flag, as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, is not changed or replaced without first being voted upon and approved by the people of Australia in a national poll.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Calvert (from 304 citizens), Senator Parer (from 30 citizens), Senator Patterson (from 114 citizens) and Senator Reid (from 60 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned draw to the attention of the Senate:
We are proud to fly the Australian Flag and will oppose any changes to it.
We support the Constitutional Monarchy and will oppose any moves to turn Australia into a Republic.
We believe in loyalty to the Crown and Nation, pride in the National Anthem and respect for our existing Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: World Heritage Listing of the Nullarbor Region
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned oppose the attempts by the Federal Government to World Heritage List the Nullarbor Region.
In doing so, we condemn the State and Federal Government for failing to consult with the residents of the Nullarbor in relation to the listing proposal.
Further, we affirm the excellent record of pastoralists, highway operators and the local communities in protecting the heritage and environmental value of the region.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. The petitioners note particularly that:

PARA.TAB: Australia is one of the world's oldest democracies
Australia has led the world in many democratic reforms

PETITION.PARA: Our constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:

PARA.TAB: ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should remain a constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty The Queen of Australia as our head of State and as in duty bound will ever pray. God save The Queen.

PETITION.TITLE: Trans-Tasman Travel Agreements
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, the petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully shows:

We, the undersigned, express our concerns at current Australian Government Policy towards New Zealand (The Trans Tasman Travel Agreements) which allows New Zealand visitors to gain employment at the expense of Australian workers.
Accordingly, in view of the growing differences between Australia and New Zealand with regard to:

PARA.TAB: Currency exchange rates;
Taxation systems;
Industrial Relations law;
Industry/Award wages and conditions;

PETITION.PARA: we call on the Federal government to implement a work permit system on New Zealand visitors intending to work in Australia, similar to the work permit system that applies to any other foreign national in Australia intending to work. We also call for a non discriminatory standard policy on immigration towards all foreign sovereign nations including New Zealand.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Childs (from 1,328 citizens) and Senator Devereux (from 480 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Waler Horse Society of Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia.

Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should recognise the Waler horse as being a unique part of Australia's heritage; that these horses are genetically endangered, exist in some feral horse (brumby) herds, and must be preserved. That action must be taken to preserve the Waler horse when implementing any program involving the capture and/or destruction of feral horses.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: ASSOCIATED PULP AND PAPER MILLS: DISPUTE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that General Business Notice of Motion No. 910 standing in my name, relating to proposals to resolve an industrial dispute at Burnie in Tasmania, be taken as formal.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to Senator Coulter's contingent notice, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Bell from moving a motion relating to the conduct of business, namely, a motion to give precedence to the General Business Notice of Motion No. 910 standing in the name of Senator Bell relating to proposals to resolve an industrial dispute at Burnie, Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: I move that General Business Notice of Motion No. 910 standing in my name, relating to proposals to resolve an industrial dispute at Burnie—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! You have moved a suspension motion. The question is that the suspension motion moved by Senator Bell be agreed to. Those of that opinion say aye; to the contrary no. I think the noes have it.
—Speaking to the motion to suspend standing orders—

—On a point of order: there was a deal of confusion, I must say, about this situation. In fairness to Senator Bell, I think there was a good deal of confusion and perhaps we ought to go back to square one and listen to his argument for the suspension of standing orders.
—I think there was confusion because Senator Bell just went straight on. By moving another motion, I did not think he was talking to his suspension.
—He clearly went straight on. But if you want to turn the clock back and give him a chance to do what he was trying to do, we are happy with that.

—Mr President, the purpose of seeking to suspend Standing Orders is to attempt to move the motion which I introduced into the Senate yesterday in which I asked the Senate to note that the Tasmanian State Liberal Government, the Labor Opposition in Tasmania and the Green Independents in Tasmania, as well as the Federal Labor Government, Independent Federal members and the Australian Democrats, were in concurrence with regard to the need for fair negotiations to be conducted by all participants in the Burnie paper mill dispute.

PARA.TAB: In reading the rest of the motion, honourable senators will note that I distinguish several Federal Liberal members of parliament as not having concurred with the other members of parliament. I intended to use this opportunity to expose the hypocrisy which is evident in the position adopted by several Liberal members of parliament. While the word `hypocrisy' is somewhat overworked in this forum, it is self-evident in the actions and statements that have been made by a number of spokespersons on behalf of the coalition.

We have several would-be shadow Ministers in the coalition. In addition to the Leader of the Opposition, who was very quick to support the APPM company in this dispute, we have had statements issued by Senator Crane, and by Mr Howard and Mr Miles, who are both members of the House of Representatives. Comments have been made, as one would expect, by Mr Smith, the member for Bass, and Mr Goodluck, the member for Franklin. At various stages they have offered either contradictory statements or, at least, statements which do not necessarily support the position that has been taken by Mr Howard, who is recognised as the Opposition shadow Minister for industrial relations.

All this is very hard to coalesce with the position taken by the Tasmanian Liberal Premier who, in what must be close to being a unique move, has found some concurrence with the position taken by a Labor Minister, the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Peter Cook. On 30 May Senator Cook and Premier Groom issued a joint statement, headed `Enough Is Enough', stating that they want to see a resolution to the problem and challenging the quarrelling parties to take the opportunity of meeting together without acrimony and with a resolution as their goal.

After the occurrence of that near unique situation we were told by Mr Howard, speaking on behalf of the coalition, that governments should butt out of the APPM dispute. While the Premier of Tasmania is doing his darnedest to put aside political prejudices and promote the goal of resolving a dispute which is greatly affecting his State, and is wisely moving to support further negotiations, what does his Federal industrial relations spokesperson tell him to do? He tells him to get out of it. That is such a contradiction and such a confusing statement, which is probably the only result one could have when there is such a confused set of statements and policies coming from the coalition.

Mr Groom was correct in saying that his policy in this area was one of never assuming that the company would always be right but, rather, of looking at the merits of the case and trying to find a resolution in that way. He is contradicted by such people as Mr McLachlan, from the other place, and, again, Mr Miles, who one would think would be fairly close to the dispute and understand the need to get back together and find a resolution for the sake of the community. But no, we have the continuation of petty, silly schoolyard tactics and bickering to the extent that resolution is impossible. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, as I indicated to Senator Bell before the Senate met today, while the Government has sympathy with the motion it does not have sympathy with the proposal to suspend Standing Orders. The Government has a very tight legislative timetable. Accordingly, we will not be supporting the motion for suspension of Standing Orders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We join with the Government in refusing to support the suspension of Standing Orders.
—For different reasons.
—I would be happy to give Senator Sherry some darned good reasons.
—Give us some darned good reasons.

—Senator Sherry might like to listen instead of being the sort of union interventionist that has caused the problem anyway. Let me put this matter into perspective by responding to some of the remarks made by Senator Bell. Mr Howard, the shadow spokesman on industrial relations, has made it quite clear that everyone should butt out of this dispute and leave it to the parties involved. The remarks made by Senator Bell, and the intervention by Senator Sherry on the other side, reflect the fact that in this Government we have a Minister for Industrial Relations who is a member of the BWIU and referred to by the media as `the Minister assisting the President of the ACTU'. He has involved himself in that dispute. This dispute has occurred under the rules laid down by this Government. What a great system!
—What about Ray Groom? What about the Liberal leader in Tasmania?

—Senator Sherry must let me finish. Naturally, Ray Groom is concerned; he is the Premier of Tasmania. The reason he came into the dispute is that he was dragged into it by the intervention of Senator Cook. He had no option.

PARA.TAB: Had Senator Bell's motion been agreed to, it was the intention of the Opposition to move an amendment to it. The amendment would have removed all the words after `that', which does not surprise Senator Bell, who I can see is smiling. He thinks he is pretty cute in bringing in such a motion because it might cause some problems in the Opposition. What a lot of nonsense! Everyone knows that we have the most unified Opposition that this country has ever seen; compare that with the rabble that sits on the other side. We intend to remove all words after `that' and add the following words:
the Senate notes:
(1) With concern, the intervention of the Federal Minister for Industrial Relations, the Tasmanian Government, and the ACTU has not resolved the industrial dispute between APPM and its employees;
(2) The inflammatory and irresponsible remarks of the Minister for Industrial Relations on the dispute; and
(3) Calls on the Federal Government and the ACTU to keep out of the dispute and allow the company and its employees to resolve their differences.

SPEECH.PARA: Historically—and I do not care what political colour we are talking about—every time there has been an intervention by governments in areas where they have had no interest except to gain some political brownie points, there have been problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did Howard intervene? Why did he go to a meeting?

—What a brilliant intervention. Senator Bell is saying that Mr Howard is not allowed to talk to the parties. The parties came to see Mr Howard because they wanted to tell him their side of the story. That is perfectly reasonable. Right from the word go, Mr Howard has said, `Keep out of it', because what we have down there is a—
—Why did he go and see them 12 days ago?
—Senator Sherry, how about a bit of honesty?
—Order!
—He was visited by Mr Wade, I think the man's name is. Be that as it may, what we had was a Minister go down there like a latter-day Bob Hawke.
—The poor-man's Bob Hawke.

—He has been referred to as the poor-man's Bob Hawke. He was of course rebuffed. Basically, we have a position which is outlined very well in today's Herald Sun—and I refer Senator Sherry to the article in that newspaper which says that the ACTU is in deep trouble over this dispute. No wonder Senator Cook is paranoid about it. One of the major points that are made is that the company is acting within the strict letter of the law. No-one I have heard from any side has disputed that. The company is acting within the strict letter of the law—this Government's law. This is the law under which this dispute is not being resolved.

—I rise to make a few brief remarks on this motion to suspend Standing Orders. I believe that consideration of this matter is urgent. As other speakers have indicated, there is a contest going on in Tasmania which is seriously hampering the economy of that State and leading to a great deal of hardship for the people of Burnie. So this is a matter of urgency.

PARA.TAB: Another matter that also attracts great urgency is the Opposition's industrial relations proposals. Quite distinct from the words in the Opposition's statement, we can now see what will happen in practice under its proposed legislation if it forms the next government. That demonstration is very much now open to inspection by the Australian people and it is very urgent that they have a look good look at it.

On the face of it, the idea of free and open contractual arrangements between employers and employees sounds very nice. It sounds very nice and very fair, and of course it may well be quite fair if we have fair and reasonable people acting in good faith on both sides. However, we all know that there are some people, on both sides I think one could say, who are unreasonable, who will make unreasonable demands and, therefore, a system of industrial relations does require reasonable levels of regulation.

What we have heard repeated again this morning from Senator Parer is really, `Butt out; leave it to the parties so that the strongest will win and the weak will go to the wall'. That is the way in which the Opposition's industrial program will work out in practice. We are seeing a practical demonstration of it, and I think at this stage we need to take very good and very careful note of that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion to suspend Standing Orders because of its urgency. I can understand that the Opposition may query certain aspects of Senator Bell's proposed motion. However, as we all know, this matter is urgent. This great crisis is not only in Burnie but is spreading throughout Tasmania. The effects of this dispute are being felt. The implications are quite vast for the rest of Australia and for the future of our industrial relations.

PARA.TAB: I would normally say, and I have said frequently, that the Government should butt out of industrial disputes except where it does have responsibility—and, indeed, the Parliament has a responsibility—in these matters. The Parliament and the Government have a responsibility which is imposed upon them by the Constitution. The Constitution says:
The Parliament shall, subject to this Constitution, have power to make laws for the peace, order, and good government of the Commonwealth with respect to—

SPEECH.PARA: (xxxv.) Conciliation and arbitration for the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes extending beyond the limits of any one State:

That mechanism has been invoked in this case and a decision has been made by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. Of course, under those circumstances it is the prerogative, indeed the duty, of governments and the Parliament to ensure that those decisions are carried forward in accordance with the law.

PARA.TAB: I make no comment here about the tactical considerations of whether on a previous occasion recommendations of the Commission in this dispute should have been followed by the parties. Whether those tactics were successful or useful is a matter for detailed consideration. But this is not the time to consider that aspect. The fact is that, at the present moment, a decision has been made by the Commission and it is the responsibility of the Government and the Parliament to have regard to that as well as, of course, the individual parties concerned.

Is there industrial peace in Burnie? No. Is there order in Burnie? No. Our job is to enact laws `for the peace, order, and good government of the Commonwealth' and those elements are missing at the present time in Burnie. It is the right of governments to consider those elements and ensure that they are implemented.

I repeat: I have consistently maintained that government should butt out of industrial disputes, except in so far as they are relevant to that constitutional provision. I am opposed, because of its possible ramifications, to the use of the corporations power, for example, under the Constitution to interfere with the industrial relations system in Australia. That, of course, has been my express view for years.

The governments and oppositions in Tasmania and the Commonwealth should be careful, as indeed should the unions and employers throughout Australia, lest governments use this situation to invoke other powers which may be used against the workers of Australia in future. I believe that this is a matter of public importance and that it ought to be considered by the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak very briefly on this motion to suspend Standing Orders. I do not think there is any purpose to be served by suspending Standing Orders at this stage. The dispute in Burnie is a most regrettable affair. There is no doubt that it could have been settled weeks ago had greater goodwill been shown by various of the parties involved.

PARA.TAB: But this matter has now reached the stage where all parties are following their own agendas. We have, for instance, the Federal ALP, the Tasmanian unions, the ACTU, the Tasmanian Liberals, the Federal Liberals, and the Greens. All these people have their own agenda. I do not blame them for having their own agenda; I am not complaining about it. I am saying that these agendas are crisscrossing. There is no possible solution at the moment because of the different aspects that are being put forward.

There has been quite a lot of publicity, and it would have been better if much of it had not occurred. The media has a responsibility to report. But it also has a responsibility to the broader community to ensure that it asks whether its reporting is likely to assist or further inflame the situation. We have had some excellent examples of that. A lot of the reporting has been done with the best will in the world; a lot of it has been mischievous in the extreme. But Burnie has become the pawn in this whole game.

The other day we saw in the paper that the ACTU and a variety of unions announced that they had $10m to fight Hewson at the next election. This is the main game and we all know that. The pawns in the game are the people of Burnie, Wynyard, Somerset and Penguin. I have lived with these people for over 50 years. I was at school with them. I have built houses for them and sold them houses. I know them all and they know one another. Whether they are staff or day workers, it makes no difference, but nobody is considering them in all this. It is time that the fellows with one income families and three or four kids at school got a bit of consideration. Who is worried about them?

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want to kick into the fighting fund?

—Is it any wonder they call Senator Sherry `yaffler'? I ask the honourable senator to shut up for a while. Is it any wonder that we are having trouble when someone like Senator Sherry is `yaffling' about the place with his trap going, doing nothing but stunting in front of cameras? He has not done one positive thing towards a resolution. Let us try to get this matter resolved.

PARA.TAB: A lot of work is being done by a lot of people at grassroots level who are really trying to get the matter settled. The obstacles are at the top, not the bottom. If it were possible for Ken Henderson to meet with the representatives of the on-site employees, we could settle it in 10 minutes.

TALK.START.PARA: —What rubbish!

—Honourable senators opposite would not let it happen; that is the trouble. If we could get the on-site people to deal with their own problem, it could be resolved in 10 minutes. But there are so many people strutting the stage and wanting to be heroes. One of the Government Ministers turned up and said, `I haven't come here to negotiate. I've come to settle'. Where is he? He did not settle. The situation is worse than it was when he went.
—Where is he now?

—I do not know where he is now. We need to consider what it is we are on about. Bandying the matter about in a place like this will not resolve it, even though it is done with the best intentions in the world. I have no problem with Senator Bell's authenticity in the matter and I know that Senator Harradine is genuine in his support. But I cannot see that suspending standing orders and going on with the matter now will do one thing towards getting a resolution and giving the people of Burnie the opportunity to get back to work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Senator Archer and Mr Miles in the other place, I am resident on the north west coast. Unlike Senator Archer I have had a lot of discussions with the workers and their families involved in this dispute. The reason that they are involved in this dispute is that, without any talks at all, the company unilaterally bludgeoned them and said, `We are taking away some of your over-award wages and conditions'. There was no discussion. The company said, `We want to discuss this issue with you as individual workers'. Those individual workers, collectively, through their democratically elected representative, said, `We do not want to discuss this dispute with you individually. We have our unions and we have faith in those unions'. That principle has stuck throughout this dispute.

PARA.TAB: The reason the strike was provoked was that the company misinformed the police, brought the police on site and had five workers arrested while they were at work. `Misinformation' is not my word; that is the word used by the Liberal State Minister for Police, Mr Madill, who criticised the company for continually misinforming and misusing the police. That sparked the strike and the walk-out and caused the dispute.

Senator Archer calls for the workers to sit down with the management, but the workers want to sit down collectively with their democratically elected representatives to discuss these issues. They want the legal actions withdrawn. They want the actions for trespass, while they were at work—which frankly I do not think will succeed in the courts—withdrawn. They want the decision for bona fide and legitimate discussions between workers and their representatives and the management to continue. But the company refuses. Its attitude is, `We will deal with individual workers as we want and we will do what we want unilaterally'. There has been no legitimate discussion. The amendment moved by Senator Parer is interesting.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not move it.
—He is criticising his State colleagues on this matter.
—Foreshadowed.

—He has foreshadowed that he will criticise his State colleagues. We have only to recall what the Liberal Premier, Mr Ray Groom, said about Dr Hewson's yet to be detailed industrial relations policy. He said it was a great theory, but, in practice in terms of the dispute in Tasmania, it was not appropriate. This great theory is being touted around. John Howard, the so-called Opposition spokesperson for industrial relations, is continually squabbling with his leader, Dr Hewson, about industrial relations. At the same time little honest Johnny Howard is saying that politicians should keep out of the dispute when secretly he met with APPM 12 days ago.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. Madam Acting Deputy President, could you ask Senator Sherry to refer to Mr Howard by his correct title?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Vanstone)—Perhaps it will be helpful if Senator Sherry referred to Mr Howard as `Mr Howard'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Howard, the so-called honest Mr Howard, keeps saying that politicians should butt out of this dispute, yet 12 days ago he had a secret meeting with Peter Wade from Broken Hill-APPM. I am sure that at that secret meeting, which was just revealed yesterday, he has been encouraging—
—Sit down, sonny.

—Senator Archer should go down and talk to the workers. They will soon tell him the facts of life about the way the company has been treating them. He should go onto the picket line and have a talk to them. He should contribute to their welfare fund and provide some food and clothing for them. He should look at the harsh realities of what an industrial dispute is all about and the reality of the outcomes as a result of his party's approach to industrial relations.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday Mr Howard defended APPM's position. He is saying that the company has offered a fair deal to its workers. There was no offer. It was, `Take it or leave it or you do not have a job'. There was no offer to negotiate; it was just a unilateral declaration. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: It did not set out with a meat cleaver to take those conditions away.

Well, what did it do? It just took them away without any discussion. Mr Howard went on in a typical double-faced way and refused to endorse explicitly the company's position in the face of criticism that he disagreed with the Tasmanian Liberal Government and was on APPM's side. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the few minutes available to me, I wish to make a few brief comments. After Senator Sherry's contribution, I was not really sure whether he was actually supporting the suspension of standing orders or not. I gather from the general thrust of his speech that he is, but it was not clear to me. I do not know whether he will have a chance to clear that up.

PARA.TAB: What is at stake here is quite simple; it is a failure of the current industrial relations system. There can be no shadow of doubt about that. The IRC, the ACTU, Senator Cook and politicians all over the place have been involved. It is a typical example of the current system of industrial relations; a system which has let this country down for the last 15 years. It is no wonder that changes must occur. As Senator Parer pointed out, Senator Cook went down there and marched into town at high noon with guns blazing. He was going to sort this issue out like Hawkie used to do in the early 1970s. Cookie was back in town. But what happened? It was a total and absolute disaster. Senator Cook went there and inflamed the dispute, then came back into this Parliament and tried to further inflame it by speaking about bloodshed in the streets and so forth. It was an example of the failure of the current industrial relations system and it is no wonder that changes must occur. I put on the record that APPM is prepared to accept the IRC decision and use that as the basis of a return to work.

TALK.START.PARA: —In part.
—That is what Senator McMullan does not like. The company has agreed to accept—
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired and the time allotted for this debate has expired.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present a brief interim report on the recent activities of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation and seek leave to have the following documents tabled and incorporated in Hansard: firstly, a submission by the Life Insurance Federation, commonly known as LIFA, in relation to life office fees, commissions and charges; and, secondly, a letter forwarded to LIFA written by the Chairman on behalf of the Committee in response to the above-mentioned submission.

SPEECH.PARA: SENATE SELECT COMMITTEE ON SUPERANNUATION
INTERIM REPORT ON FEES, COMMISSIONS AND CHARGES IN THE LIFE INSURANCE INDUSTRY
I present a brief interim report on the recent activities of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation and seek leave to have the following documents tabled and incorporated in Hansard:
(i)submission by the Life Insurance Federation (LIFA) in relation to life office fees, commissions and charges.
(ii)letter forwarded to LIFA written by Chair on behalf of the Committee in response to the abovementioned submission.
I seek leave to move a motion that the Senate take note of this report.
Mr Deputy President,

The Senate Select Committee on Superannuation is currently addressing one of the key long term issues confronting the present and future generations of Australians. The Committee has been given a comprehensive set of terms of reference which include an examination of two matters which impinge on the activities of superannuation funds and insurance companies selling superannuation products in respect of information to members and the level of fees, commission and charges.
I particularly refer to terms of reference (g) and (h) which read as follows:
(g)the level and structure of fees and commissions charged in relation to superannuation fund membership and asset management; and
(h)the information available to members of superannuation funds.

The Committee commenced its inquiry into these matters by calling for written submissions. Unfortunately, the depth and breadth of evidence on these terms of reference was most disappointing. With the exception of a small number of submissions very little reference was made to the level of fees and commissions. Almost no details of precise charges etc were given at this stage of the inquiry.

Consequently, the Committee used the public hearing process to obtain the information necessary to report on this matter. It was here that considerable difficulty was experienced and it was at this point that the Committee knew it would not be receiving unequivocal support and assistance of certain witnesses appearing before it.

First, the Committee had to debate the "need to know" question with the insurance industry contesting the relevance of the level of fees and commissions to the inquiry's terms of reference saying that they were reluctant to disclose an agent's commission because it was only one aspect of an insurance contract.
When pressed, LIFA undertook to conduct a survey and get detailed figures on fees commissions etc from individual companies and provide the information on a "confidential basis".

At hearings subsequent to LIFA's appearance, a number of life offices undertook to provide information on fees, commissions and charges but, either at the time of the request or informally at a later time, indicated that LIFA would coordinate the exercise.

Four months elapsed before LIFA provided the Committee with details of its survey. The Committee has considered the LIFA submission and, having regard to the time which was allowed for its preparation and the specificity of the Committee's request, the document is extremely disappointing.

The Committee needs information which displays for each company that participated in the survey and/or appeared before the inquiry, details of products or plans and the respective fees, commissions and charges, i.e. a matching of company, product and fees, commissions and charges. When this information has been received, the Committee could then determine whether it needs further information from LIFA or one of its member organisations to explore the reasons for any significant differences in the level of fees, charges and commissions.

It is for the preceding reasons that the Committee has sent a strongly worded letter to LIFA which I have just tabled requesting that the information be provided and reminding it of the powers that the Committee has under Senate Standing Orders, Senate Parliamentary Privilege Resolutions of 25 February 1988, and the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987 to obtain the information for the purposes of its inquiry.
The information provided by LIFA in the document intensifies the Committee's interest in the matter of fees and commissions for the following reasons.

Firstly, the survey reveals that commissions can be as high as 80 and 20 per cent during the first two years of a superannuation policy's life. This could mean that a contributor, should he or she wish to transfer a policy or cash it in would receive precious little of contributions at the end of two years of a policy. A number of witnesses have given evidence on this matter.

The second issue is that of vesting of benefits. No clear indication is given in the survey about the vesting policies issued by life offices. The survey merely says that it "varies, but is basically related to the period over which commission is paid". The Committee expects that the lack of specific detail and the apparent vagueness of the survey on this matter will be rectified when the next submission is prepared.

I need not remind Senators of the impact that fees, commissions and charges can have on superannuation plans, especially when they impact on front end accumulated savings. It is for this reason that the Committee has pursued terms of reference (g)
and (h) with a degree of vigour which might not be to the liking of the life assurance industry.
The Committee looks forward to reporting in detail on the matter of fees and commissions when it presents its final report to the Senate in September 1992. I commend this report to the Senate.
Life Insurance Federation of Australia Incorporated
Mr R. Gilbert
Dear Richard,

During LIFA's appearance before the Select Committee on Superannuation earlier this year, the Committee requested information in relation to life office fees and charges and commissions paid to life insurance agents. I apologise for the delay in responding.
In respect to fees and charges, a number of life offices provide this information in their disclosure documents which are publicly available and I understand the Committee has such documents.

Concerning commissions, please find attached a matrix which shows the level of commissions paid to life agents for various superannuation products. This matrix has been prepared after consultation with LIFA members and provides a good indication of the level and types of commissions paid by life offices.
I trust this information will assist the Committee. If you would like any further assistance, please contact Darren Davis on (03) 6295751.
Kind regards,
David A Purchase
Executive Director

SPEECH.PARA: SELECT COMMITTEE ON SUPERANNUATION
Parliament House
Canberra ACT 2600
1 June 1992
Mr David Purchase
Executive Director
Life Insurance Federation of Australia Inc.

MELBOURNE VIC 3000
Dear Mr Purchase

I refer to your submission dated 18 May 1992 regarding the fees, commissions and charges applicable to the superannuation products of your member life offices. The Committee has considered your submission and decided that it should correspond further on the matter.

You will recall that when you appeared before the Committee on 11 February 1992, the Committee requested that it be provided with `detailed figures on fees, commissions etc. from individual companies' (Hansard page 302). Following that request, you undertook to survey the companies and `get that information on a confidential basis' (ibid). At hearings subsequent to your appearance, a number of life offices undertook to provide information on fees, commissions and charges but, either at the time of the request or informally at a later time, indicated that LIFA would coordinate the exercise.
The Committee requires the information in question in order that it report to the Senate on terms of reference (g) and (h) which read as follows:
(g)the level and structure of fees and commissions charged in relation to superannuation fund membership and asset management; and
(h)the information available to members of superannuation funds.

In reporting on these terms of reference, the Committee wishes to collect as much primary source data as possible from a range of life offices and superannuation funds covering the full range of superannuation products which accurately represents the fees, commissions and charges that are applicable to each plan. Having collected the data, the Committee then intends comparing the various fees, commissions and charges on a product and company basis and identifying issues which may be examined by way of further written evidence or by the appearance of witnesses before the Committee. In making decisions in this regard the Committee would maintain its stance of protecting material received on a confidential basis.

The Committee believes that your submission of 18 May 1992, whilst it provides a useful overview of the level of fees, commissions and charges in the life industry, does not fully satisfy its original request. Accordingly, the Committee needs information which displays for each company that participated in your survey and/or appeared before the inquiry, details of products or plans and the respective fees, commissions and charges, ie. a matching of company, product and fees, commissions and charges. When this information has been received the Committee could then determine whether it needs further information from LIFA or one of its member organisations in order to explore the reasons for any significant differences in the level of fees, charges and commissions.

Whilst the committee fully appreciates that the nature of the competition in your industry to a large extent dictates that there will be product differentiation and associated differences in remuneration to agents and others involved in marketing activities, it believes that the provision of the material as outlined in this letter will be of benefit to its consideration of the issues and will thereby assist in reporting on the terms of reference.

As the Committee has been waiting for almost four months for this information to be supplied, and having regard to the fact that its final reporting deadline is fast approaching, the Committee requests that this matter be given high priority by both LIFA and the life offices concerned.

The information required should be forwarded to the Committee Secretary by the close of business, 12 June 1992. Should the information not be forthcoming, the Committee will use its powers under Senate Standing Orders, Senate Parliamentary Privilege Resolutions of 25 February 1988, and the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987 to obtain the information for the purposes of its inquiry.
Yours faithfully
Nick Sherry
Chair
