SPEECH.PARA: MIGRATION AMENDMENT BILL (No.3) 1992

PARA.TAB: This Bill gives legislative effect to a registration scheme for migration agents designed to improve standards of professional conduct and quality of service. I announced the proposed establishment of the scheme on 11 December 1991.

SPEECH.PARA: The registration arrangements are expected to begin operation in mid-September of this year.
They are to apply to agents operating in Australia and involve defining a migration agent, establishing a Migration Agents Registration Board and adopting a code of conduct.

This initiative reflects the Government's concern over the level and nature of complaints made against incompetent or unscrupulous agents, complaints which would be familiar to many members of this chamber. It also recognises the fact that many of those who are likely to seek the assistance of agents are among the most vulnerable in our society, sometimes having a poor grasp of English, fear of authority or meagre financial resources.

This is not to say that the great majority of agents are not honest and efficient. It is a sad fact of life that the activities of a minority has tended to tarnish the reputation of migration agents as a whole.

I do not intend to list comprehensively problems which led to the development of the scheme but some examples include agents having been paid to lodge applications and then failing to do so; lodging applications without paying the prescribed fees thereby not giving effect to the application; lodging applications tardily in a way which adversely affects the entitlements of applicants; and holding passports as "security" and then demanding extra payments. There are also examples of agents providing incompetent advice because they lack even a rudimentary knowledge of the Migration Act and Regulations.
These problems are not new ones and there have been attempts by previous governments to find legislative remedies.

Up to December 1989 a registration procedure existed which required persons wishing to practise as migration agents to notify the Secretary of my Department. This practice provided no real basis for regulating the activities of migration agents.

The Government sought to strengthen migration agent provisions in December 1989 when major amendments were made to the Migration Act, following its consideration of the recommendations of the Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies (CAAIP). These amendments required migration agents not to engage in false advertising, to provide statements of accounts to clients and to not misrepresent their relationship with the government and the Department. They were underpinned by appropriate penalty provisions.
While these were worthwhile initiatives, experience has shown that they have not gone far enough in addressing the problems.

Accordingly, the Government had to look at formulating a more comprehensive means of regulating migration agents. This was not an easy task given the complexity of the problems and competing interests involved. I also understand that Australia is the first country with a major immigration program to introduce regulatory arrangements of this kind.

The Government considered a range of options and carried out extensive consultations with the Migration Institute of Australia, ethnic community organisations, community based migration advice agencies and the legal profession. These consultations have been very fruitful and an important step in the development of the scheme.

The possibility of self-regulation was considered but rejected. This was because self-regulation assumes the existence of a well-organised and clearly identified group of individuals and corporations engaged in an activity. The reality is that there is a high level of fragmentation with professions organised into their own distinct associations, with a significant number of persons acting alone.
Consideration was also given to a system where agents could practise unless specifically barred or, in more technical language, negative licensing. This approach was rejected for a number of reasons.

The Government was concerned that the lack of contact with migration agents involved in negative licensing would have posed significant difficulties. These included ensuring that people recognised when they were operating as migration agents, understood the code of conduct and the need to adhere to it.

The Government also took the view that migration agents should meet the cost of regulation because they were likely to benefit from the development of a more cohesive and reputable industry, in the medium to long term, and because of the need for budget discipline. Part of the revenue from the registration fees will be provided to community based migration advice agencies. Fee levels are dealt with in the accompanying tax Bills.
There was a need to minimise the risk of anti-competitive behaviour that might result from restricting entry into the industry. This has been achieved in a number of ways.

Resources will be directed to the investigation of complaints rather than erecting in the legislation entry barriers at too high a level. The composition of the migration agents registration board has been deliberately mixed so that both industry and consumer interests are represented. Disclosure of interest provisions has been made.
I turn now to the details of the scheme.

A central feature of the scheme is the establishment of a Migration Agents Registration Board, which will have the power to issue warnings, to suspend, to deregister and to refuse applications for registration. It will comprise ministerially appointed representatives from industry, the legal profession, the ethnic community (which has a strong consumer interest in the services provided by migration agents) and the Immigration Review Tribunal. It will be chaired by the Secretary of my Department or a nominee of the Secretary.
Applications and any consequential investigations will be conducted in the strictest confidence.

The registration process has been designed to allow fast-tracking of applicants by the Secretary of my Department. However, this can occur only in accordance with carefully specified circumstances involving little discretion. If any of a range of concerns are triggered, such as complaints being lodged against an applicant or questions of character being raised, then the board must deal with the case. Nevertheless, I consider that most applications will be able to be approved under the fast-track route.

A registration process involving basic checks of integrity will be introduced. To be eligible for registration an applicant must be at least 18 years of age; be an Australian citizen or an Australian permanent resident; be a person of integrity; and meet certain other entrance requirements. The applicant also must not be an undischarged bankrupt and must endorse a prescribed code of conduct.

Members of the public will have the opportunity to lodge complaints within a six week gazettal period before applicants can be registered. After registration the public will be able to lodge complaints at any time and will have the benefit of the code of conduct to guide their expectations of agent behaviour.
I referred above to a code of conduct. This is a critical element of the scheme. This document is still subject to refinement in the light of ongoing consultations.

The code will go beyond a listing of general objectives often associated with such a document. It will delineate a range of unacceptable behaviour to provide a guide to agents and consumers alike. While the code explicitly does not seek to be exhaustive, its scope will be such that it would be difficult for those acting unprofessionally or unethically to claim ignorance as a defence. This should make it easier for the board to perform its functions and deter unacceptable behaviour.
The code will be prescribed by regulation. It will be capable of adjustment in response to input from migration agents and consumers alike.
Decisions on registration have the potential to very significantly affect the livelihood of individuals.
Accordingly, the Bill allows for appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal where agents are dissatisfied with adverse decisions by the board.
The Government has carefully considered the activities which should be regulated by this legislation.

Broad definitions have been adopted to minimise avoidance. In essence, a migration agent is defined to be a person who uses knowledge of, or skill in, migration law and procedure to assist in the making of an application for a visa or entry permit or for refugee status. It extends to advice and assistance relating to adverse decisions on applications, whether in a court or before review bodies.
I note that the qualification of knowledge and experience is an important one because it excludes those providing more mechanical assistance, such as typists and interpreters.

Because of the significant role played by solicitors and barristers in providing immigration assistance those who provide such assistance will need to apply for registration. Clearly, a regulatory scheme which missed these members of the legal profession would be deficient.
There also have been concerns that serious complaints have been made against some members of the legal profession without its self-regulatory mechanisms responding with adequate timeliness or vigour.

Solicitors and barristers will not need to register in respect of their activities before the courts or if they are providing general legal migration advice unrelated to the completion and lodgment of applications. Registration will, however, be required in relation to the making of visa or entry applications under the migration Act. The board also will be able to investigate complaints against lawyers arising from the provision of immigration legal assistance to allow cases to be effectively referred to professional associations for possible disciplinary action.
I would like to make one further point on the extension of this scheme to some activities of the legal profession.

The registration arrangements proposed by the Government will be evaluated after two years. While there will be a range of issues that will need to be carefully considered at that time, the government will closely examine any progress made by the legal profession in strengthening its self-regulatory mechanisms. In the meantime, the Government hopes to maintain a close dialogue with the legal profession which made some useful contributions to the development of the scheme, although it opposed any coverage of barristers and solicitors. Similarly, the Government will continue its close dialogue with the Migration Institute of Australia which has already taken steps to develop training courses and a fellowship scheme that promises to lead to higher professional standards and improved self-regulation.
The scheme is backed up by tough penalties reflecting the Government's concerns.
I would now like to turn briefly to a number of implementation issues.
The Government has been concerned not to disrupt the activities of migration agents, many of whom offer a valuable service.
This will be facilitated by the fast-track provisions that I referred to earlier.

The transition provisions also have been framed to allow those who are currently practising as migration agents to lodge an application and to continue practising while their applications are being determined. This is because, like most such schemes when they are introduced, there initially will be a large number of applications needing to be determined.
In order that consumers and agents alike are aware of the scheme, extensive publicity is planned. Steps will be taken to provide agents with advance warning of changes to the code of conduct.
In conclusion, this Bill arises because of problems that former legislative measures and self-regulation have not been able to remedy. Accordingly, the Government is taking on that challenge.

However, the introduction of this regulatory scheme may well act as a catalyst in drawing together migration agents in a way which will encourage self-regulation and provide future governments greater flexibility in addressing the underlying issues. This is reflected in the sunset provisions of the Act and my comments on the review of the scheme at the end of a two-year period.
I present the explanatory memorandum for the Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.
MIGRATION AGENTS REGISTRATION (APPLICATION) LEVY BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: This Bill seeks to impose a levy on an individual's making of a registration application. The Bill exempts an applicant who proposes to give immigration assistance to entrance applicants only in a capacity as an employee of, or a voluntary worker for, a person or organisation that does not charge entrance applicants a fee, nor require any other reward from them, for the giving of such assistance.

SPEECH.PARA: This reflects the Government's view that, while there is a need for voluntary agencies to be subject to the code of conduct and other provisions of the Bill, payment of the levy by such agencies would be inappropriate.

The levy of $500 is imposed on an individual in the following circumstances. First, when the individual proposes to give immigration assistance in the capacity of an employee of a registered agent. Second, when the individual proposes to provide immigration assistance in the capacity of an employee of a partnership at least one of whose members is a registered agent. Third, when the individual proposes to provide immigration advice in the capacity of the employee of a corporation at least one of whose executive officers is a registered agent. In any other case the levy is $1,000.
I present the explanatory memorandum for the Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.
MIGRATION AGENTS REGISTRATION (RENEWAL) LEVY BILL 1992

This Bill seeks to impose a levy on renewal of an individual's registration as a registered agent. The Bill exempts a registered agent who gives immigration assistance to entrance applicants only in a capacity as an employee of, or a voluntary worker for, a person or organisation that does not charge entrance applicants a fee, nor require any other reward from them, for the giving of such assistance.

This reflects the Government's view that, while there is a need for voluntary agencies to be subject to the code of conduct and other provisions of the Bill, payment of the levy by such agencies would be inappropriate.

The levy of $500 is payable by an individual in the following circumstances. First, when the individual whose registration is renewed and who gives immigration assistance in the capacity of an employee of a registered agent. Second, when the individual provides immigration assistance in the capacity of an employee of a partnership at least one of whose members is a registered agent. Third, when the individual provides such advice in the capacity of the employee of a corporation at least one of whose executive officers is a registered agent. In any other case the levy is $1,000.
I present the explanatory memorandum for the Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 26 May, on motion by Senator Tate:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not be opposing the passage of the Trade Practices Amendment Bill 1992, which at last clarifies the long confused position in Australia with respect to product liability. The de facto international standard with respect to product liability is contained in the European Community directive of 1985.

PARA.TAB: The Government's basic approach, with which the Opposition agrees, is that Australian consumers who are injured by defective goods should be placed in a position which is no less advantageous than that enjoyed generally by their European counterparts in the same situation. A fundamental part of the EC directive, contained in article 4, is that the onus of proof is on the claimant. Article 4 states that:

SPEECH.PARA: The injured person shall be required to prove the damage, the defect and the causal relationship between the defect and the damage.

The coalition has always supported this approach and has consistently expressed serious reservations about any proposal which tampers with the onus of proof. If manufacturers' products are assumed to be defective unless they are proved to be otherwise, it imposes an unreasonable burden on manufacturers and would lead to higher insurance premiums and product costs.

PARA.TAB: Since the European Community directive of 1985 on product liability, the issue has been under examination in Australia. It has been the subject of reports by the National Consumer Affairs Advisory Council, the Australian Law Reform Commission and the Industry Commission. The Australian Law Reform Commission in its 1989 report recommended a system of strict liability which would shift the allocation of loss to manufacturers. In March 1991 the coalition welcomed the Government's decision—two years in coming—that it would not accept the ALRC's 1989 proposals. We recognised the need for a balance to be struck between the right of consumers to recover damages for injury suffered as a result of defective products and the need to ensure that any proposal adopted did not unnecessarily adversely affect manufacturers and act as a potential disincentive to manufacturing investment. Since then the Government has struggled to find the right balance.

In 1991 the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, announced a proposal that he called a compromise position, in which the onus of proof was to be shared between the claimant and the defendant manufacturer. What he was proposing was a reversal of the onus of proof, relying on the conclusion reached by the Industry Commission that it would be more economically efficient to require the manufacturer to show that a defect does not exist. Although Senator Tate maintained at the time that this proposal represented the de facto situation in Europe, in our view it clearly did not.

In November last year Senator Tate announced that the Bill would be redrafted so that, where all the circumstances of an injury point to a defect in the product causing the damage, that inference should be drawn. This proposal was reflected in the Trade Practices Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991, which was introduced in December. The Opposition was still not satisfied with this revised proposal, although it was encouraging that the Government appeared to have abandoned its attempt to reverse the onus of proof. However, the revised proposal still imposed an unnecessary burden on manufacturers and, moreover, it was still not in line with the EC directive.

The Minister put forward yet another revised Bill in April this year. This proposal was a variation on the theme of drawing inferences, where in all the circumstances it is reasonable to infer that loss was caused by a defect in goods. Once again, the Opposition could not support the proposal because, if the law in Australia is to match that under the EC directive, the onus of proof should simply be on the plaintiff.

In the end, good sense prevailed, and the Minister was brought to task by his backbench caucus committee, which took the view that the onus of proof ought not to be on the manufacturers. As I indicated, Senator Tate was forced to withdraw those provisions. As we read the Bill now, in its much revised final form, the onus of proof is on the claimant, in line with the EC directive. The Bill is therefore acceptable to the coalition and we will not be opposing its passage.

The Bill amends the Trade Practices Act by introducing a new part VA, which provides a regime of strict liability. A person who is injured or dies or suffers property damage as a result of a defective product has a right to compensation against the manufacturer. The claimant need not prove negligence on the part of the manufacturer. Pursuant to proposed section 75AC, goods have a defect if their safety is not such as persons generally are entitled to expect. In assessing safety, regard is to be had to all the relevant circumstances, a number of which are specifically provided in the Bill.

Pursuant to subsection 75AC(3), a product is not to be inferred to be defective simply because, after it was supplied, safer goods were provided. That is sensible. Although the regime is one of strict liability, we note that a number of defences are provided. They appear to be appropriate. Proposed section 75AL provides further that, where a defendant raises the defence that goods were defective only because of compliance with a Commonwealth mandatory standard, the defendant must then serve a notice of action on the Commonwealth. In such cases, it will be the Commonwealth and not the manufacturer who is liable to compensate the aggrieved consumer.

Proposed section 75AN provides that contributory acts or omissions by the claimant will reduce the amount of compensation payable by an appropriate amount. That seems to be a proper provision. A limitation period of three years is provided for in proposed section 75AO, and time begins to run from when the person became aware, or ought reasonably to have become aware, of the alleged loss. The action must commence within 10 years of the supply of the defective goods by the manufacturer. I think the Minister was seeking 20 years but has been brought back to a more reasonable period.

Proposed section 75AQ provides that the Trade Practices Commission may commence an action on behalf of one or more persons who have suffered loss, provided that the written consent of each person is obtained. Such a form of representative action also seems to be sensible in the circumstances. Pursuant to proposed section 75AR, the operation of other laws and remedies is preserved. There has been some public debate about that. It means that a manufacturer would have to look to obligations in contract and tort under part II of the Trade Practices Act and now part VA. From time to time we have questioned whether that is not becoming unreasonable. Nevertheless, we have decided not to press our objection on this occasion. There would seem to be little doubt that this provision will overtake most of the other remedies available.

In conclusion, the coalition welcomes the Government's acceptance at long last that the onus of proof should rest with the claimant, as is the case under the EC directive, and not with the manufacturer. We only regret that the Government has taken such a tortuous path in coming to the position which the coalition has consistently maintained since the issue of product liability first emerged years ago.

I note that three of the matters are still on the agenda for public debate. They received earlier support from Senator Tate. He is now proposing that they should go to a Senate committee for further examination at an appropriate time. These include the question of extraterritoriality, giving overseas consumers the right to sue Australian manufacturers over defective products; the period of repose—a delightful expression—which the Minister believes should be up to 20 years after manufacture to allow complaints to be made; and the so-called Aussie battler provision—another delightful expression—which is designed to ensure that when a consumer's claim is reasonable he or she should be guaranteed his or her day in court. It seems to be a last gasp attempt by the Minister to reintroduce some further inference provision in the Bill, such as that which has been taken out by his colleagues and which we have argued for a long time should be taken out.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which has been taken out by your colleagues.

—I think the Minister's Caucus committee took it out, but on our advice. There has been a long debate on that issue, and we wonder whether there is much value in it going to a committee. We wonder about the extraterritoriality and the period of repose, but we appreciate the important work done, particularly by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, under the able chairmanship of Senator Barney Cooney. If the Committee were disposed to take a further look at these issues—it has recently been looking at other aspects of trade practices law—we would not object to that. I raise in passing some qualification, now that there have been years of debate on these issues and we have finally reached a resolution, as to whether going back into the thought chamber of the Committee would be a productive use of time.

PARA.TAB: With that reservation, I confirm that the Bill is acceptable to the coalition in its present form. We therefore do not oppose its passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will also be supporting the passage of the Trade Practices Amendment Bill 1992 with reservations, which I will outline in the course of my contribution to the debate. It is important legislation, which is the first thing to be said about it. In demonstrating that it is important legislation, I will be showing that it has been a long time coming, and expressing severe reservations about it. It has been a long time coming. We have known for a considerable length of time that there are problems with product caused injury. These problems have begun to be articulated and documented as part of the moves towards appropriate legislation for product liability and consumer protection thereby.

PARA.TAB: In 1985-86 a survey of consumer opinion was conducted for the Trade Practices Commission. It found that in the few years preceding that survey 7 per cent of respondents or members of their households had suffered physical injury or illness as a consequence of goods, and 3 per cent of this number regarded the injury as resulting in permanent incapacity of some kind. A much larger proportion had some complaint about the quality or performance of goods. In relation to injury, illness and incapacity, it has been estimated that the figures indicate around 10,300 permanent injuries or illnesses for the whole of Australia for the few years covered by the survey, and around 500 deaths for the same period.

The Australian Consumers Association put out a report, An Arm and a Leg, early in 1989 which resulted from the survey work that was done in the preceding years. It was also a national injury surveillance and prevention project—a pilot scheme gathering data from the casualty departments of selected hospitals which produced figures for this report. On the basis of that data, the report concluded that an estimated 1,800 to 3,600 children are injured each year as a result of physical product failure with a higher, but unfortunately unquantifiable, number injured because of unsafe design. Figures for adults injured as a result of physical product failure ranged between 9,500 and 19,000. Even taking the most conservative estimates and trying not to be emotional about the particularly poignant tragedy of children killed and injured in this way, there is clearly a problem to be addressed. So we find ourselves here today with this legislation, legislation about which I will be expressing some reservations.

One of the frustrating difficulties in this whole process in this period of time has been the difficulty in getting comprehensive statistical data. We have relied a great deal on the Australian Consumers Association whose magazine Choice identifies an average of 50 unsafe products each year. We should remember that Choice only tests a minute proportion of the products that are actually available on the market. Again, that is an indication of the need for this legislation.

Unsafe products continue to be produced, sold and used many years after hazards have been identified and in spite of government moves from time to time against such products. Unless moves are made by government specific to manufacturers' products, manufacturers continue to produce them, even though very often there are known faults in those products. Manufacturers are always reluctant to announce recalls and they are not always efficiently conducted.

We are getting legislation now because it is realised that obviously there are deficiencies in the present law, and the present law has failed to meet the needs of consumers. The Australian Consumers Association has been of assistance in looking at some of those inadequacies. An analysis of the Trade Practices Commission's survey done by the Australian Consumers Association indicated that for people surveyed the cost of taking legal proceedings was a strong deterrent to pursuing a claim for compensation. The varied rights of compensation meant that proceedings were less likely to be pursued where the injured person had neither bought nor owned the product—the innocent third party issue. The length of time and the stress involved in legal proceedings often deterred people from taking action.

In this debate I do not want to ignore previous reforms made to the law here in Australia. Quite clearly, we have reached the stage where it is agreed that the inadequacies need to be met. Perhaps the debate now is about the extent to which the inadequacies of the present law are being met by this legislation. Therefore, it is probably worth looking at the evolution from those earlier dates that I have mentioned to the legislation that is now before us.

I want to mention the joint Australian Law Reform Commission and Victorian Law Reform Commission reports of 1989 and the Industry Commission assessment of those reports in 1990 as part of that evolutionary process. As Senator Hill has mentioned, legislation was then proposed by Senator Tate in his capacity as the Minister. In May 1991, as a consequence of his announcements at that point, the Minister was congratulated by consumer groups and by the Democrats for the announcement that under new laws the onus of proving whether or not a product was defective would be on the manufacturer of the product.

If I am going to speak about the evolution of this legislation from the ideal—in our view, anyway—presented by the Law Reform Commission's report, we have to mention, as the first of the blows, the reversal by Minister Tate of that commitment of May 1991. We wish to make a complaint about the feeling of the consumer movement that there was a lack of consultation in that process; we acknowledge the pressure of business and industry groups leading to that decision. If congratulations were to be forthcoming for the change of that decision, they would have to go to the then shadow Minister for consumer affairs, Peter Costello, who at that point congratulated the Minister on his position. The effect of that back down will be devastating to many consumers.

I believe that we can say that the onus of proof is now in the wrong place. The model that is being used is the lowest common denominator that can be found in the area of product liability. I would have thought—and I have argued at other times in other places—that a manufacturer would want, for all good business and economic reasons, to be seen to be standing behind the product that is produced by that manufacturer. It is an enormous deficiency of the legislation that the onus of proof remains with the consumer as a result of this legislation. That was the first step backwards in the evolution of this legislation.

We were then treated to quite a public exercise of pressure on the Government generally and, of course, on the responsible Minister at the time, Senator Tate, particularly as we came into 1992. It concluded with the situation which we now have where not only has the onus of proof been placed in the wrong place but also key and controversial elements of the Bill have been taken out of the legislation and sent off to a committee.

In the Minister's press release on 7 May announcing that move, following the Caucus committee's decision, the Minister was, I think, as honest as we will ever see a parliamentarian, and particularly a Minister, when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: And on the three issues opposed by business, I will have my day in court—or rather in committee—to argue for their inclusion.

There are two bits of commendable honesty there: firstly, making it quite clear why these provisions are taken out—because business does not want them in there; and, secondly, telling his Government and his Caucus, quite bravely, that he is going to continue to argue for them. More power to his arm. I just note here that that Minister will not be the Minister in the Committee, but as a senator, of course, he is quite free to go along to the Committee and have his day in court, and I hope he does. I will probably be there, even though I am no longer on the inestimable Senator Cooney's Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee, on which I served for a number of years.

PARA.TAB: I look forward to seeing Senator Tate argue for those controversial elements. I will outline them. There is the extraterritoriality element, giving overseas consumers the right to sue Australian manufacturers over defective products; there is the period of repose, which Senator Tate had proposed to be 20 years after manufacture; and there are the Aussie battler provisions, designed to ensure that where in all the circumstances of the case the consumer's claim is reasonable the consumer should be guaranteed his or her day in court.

We are now in the hands of a new Minister. Senator Tate, I believe, is still the representing Minister in this chamber. I am sure that he will play a key role, but I am equally confident that Minister McHugh will argue for these provisions if her public record on matters such as this is anything to go by, and I am sure it is.

I do not think this is the end of the matter—at least I hope it is not. As I say, I have had some experience on the Committee to which these issues have been referred. Its record shows a committee that has deliberated in the interests of the public in general. It is a committee which I believe will do useful work in this area. But I feel that this Bill needs to be put forward in the name of Mr Peter Costello, the former shadow Minister in the other place, rather than in any Government Minister's name because I guess he is the one to whom the victory has gone. Incidentally, I wonder where Senator Aulich is in this debate. I felt sure we would hear him in the chamber, as he has clearly been a front runner in putting aside many of the interests of consumers in this country and watering down a piece of legislation which, as I said, is tremendously important to consumers and, I think, to the reputation of business and industry. I do not think it enhances the reputation of business and industry in this country that they have not been prepared to stand behind their products, products which they freely release in the community, with a number of constraints, of course, under other relevant legislation.

It is obvious from the very few figures I have cited—there are many more; this is a difficult time of the year and one cannot go into enormous depth and detail—that market forces do not protect consumers. They particularly do not protect children or those innocent third parties who too often are injured or killed by defective products. Our reputation internationally is not enhanced by the back down, particularly on the extraterritoriality question.

As I said, we are not opposing this legislation. We are forced to see it as a step in the right direction—but merely that. I have a specific question for the Minister which I will put on the record now. He may wish to take time to answer it—we can possibly do it in the committee stage. Because legislation tends eventually to run very quickly through the chamber in these last two or three weeks, there has not been time for the Minister to answer a question which was posed by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee—another committee chaired by the inestimable Senator Cooney and on which I happened to serve for a second time during my time in this Parliament. It is a question that relates to clause 4, the proposed new section 75AH, which proposes to insert a new part 5A into the Trade Practices Act dealing with the survival of liability actions.

The Scrutiny of Bills Committee is concerned. I refer to the Alert Digest to be tabled today—I hope I am not breaching privilege of the Senate. I will not quote it; I will just paraphrase the concern. Since the Trade Practices Act contains no similar provision in relation to the survival of liability in relation to other actions under the Act, the question is whether the insertion of this specific provision under this section of the Act dealing with product liability is likely to call into question survivability on actions in other sections of the legislation, for instance, under section 52A, misleading and deceptive conduct. There is a concern that, having been specific about survivability in this area, interpretation may well be made—particularly, I would imagine, by someone against whom an action is being taken under other sections of the Act; they may well be looking for such an interpretation from a smart QC somewhere—that survivability only exists under this legislation if it is specified, as it is in this section, the product liability section.

I would like the Minister to look at this. In the normal course of events I am sure the Committee would have been supplied with a response from the Minister in due course, but it is something which concerns me and it did obviously concern the Committee. We would not want to see the Trade Practices Act affected in any negative way by the insertion of a new section on product liability, which, of course, we strongly support.

In Senator Hill's contribution, when he talked about the evolution that has led to this legislation he mentioned that we had finally reached a Bill which was `acceptable to the Opposition'. I have already made that point. But I remind the Government and the listening public—all 250 of them, if there are that many listening today—and place on record that the Government did not need the Opposition's support for this legislation. A lot is said about the Democrats' role in holding the balance of power in the Senate. There is a lot of misinterpretation, misinformation and even malicious misinformation about that situation.

I want to make it quite clear that in this case the Government did not need to water down the legislation in order to have it pass the Parliament. The Democrats supported strong legislation. They were much happier with Minister Tate's initial position and legislation and would have expedited its passage through the Senate. What the Government believed it needed, and certainly wanted, was the approval, the pat on the head, from business and industry in this country, who have cried foul quite unjustifiably. They are not prepared to stand by their products—watering down a piece of vital legislation.

This Government has not been prepared to stand up against the business lobby. That does not surprise us. The Labor governments of Prime Minister Hawke and now Prime Minister Keating have demonstrated time and again that almost their top priority in government is to be on the right side of their business mates. This week we have seen it again with pay TV and airline sales. This product liability law is just another example. It will not be lost on the electorate in the coming Federal election. This Government has definitely shown a lack of intestinal fortitude when it comes to standing up for the rights of ordinary Australians against the heavy business and industry lobby in this country.

I emphasise that we could have had stronger legislation. The numbers were there for it within the Parliament and, I believe, outside in the community, given the figures I quoted earlier of numbers of children and adults killed and injured by defective products over the years, numbers that we really cannot quantify. I think the Government stands condemned for its approach and its cave-in on this one. Of course, this is not the first time the Labor Party in government has done the Liberal Party's work for it with privatisation, deregulation, corporatisation and cave-in.

So it is not with a great deal of pleasure that I support this legislation. It is an advance. A great deal has been put into the hands of the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee, and the Democrats will continue to pursue this question. No government, whether this or a future one, will be allowed to ignore a report that might come from that Committee urging a stronger stance, as I am confident it will, or the voice of consumers out in the community. We should not forget that, while business and industry might be the squeaky wheel, and on this occasion it has got the oil, consumers have the numbers. The Democrats will support this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —By agreement, speakers on this side of the House are limiting the contributions they make in order that we may get through our legislative timetable, so I am speaking on this matter for a shorter time than I would normally do. If I may say right at the outset, this is an issue I have followed since the original proposition surfaced out of one of the consumer groups Senator Powell mentioned. I think we have to put on the record that it is misinformation to say that it is industry which calls the tune—or that it is the squeaky wheel, as Senator Powell called it. In fact, the consumer groups, funded very largely by government and taxpayers' money, have had a disproportionate say in the development of this initiative in particular and, indeed, others that come before the Parliament.

PARA.TAB: When we look at the history of this legislation we see that it began as a piece of draconian legislation where there was to be no defence whatsoever. If anyone was injured by any product, then strict liability was the result and damages flowed. The only plea one could enter was one of mitigation as to the size of the damages. That issue was discussed early on and did not come to us in the form of a Bill. Many people pre-empted the wisdom of adopting that course and pointed to the sorts of things that have happened in the United States, where they have developed their product liability `remedies' through their common law system as distinct from a legislative framework. Quite frankly, it has resulted in whole industries being put out of business. The most obvious example is small aircraft, which are simply no longer manufactured.

The social philosophy behind this legislation was that, somehow, one had to make manufacturers wear the cost of whatever damage might result from any manufactured good. That is a piece of socialist nonsense and was finally rejected, but not until we had much debate. An economic impact statement was made on the original proposals which really torpedoed them.

We have gone through several stages of drafting of the legislation before us. I would particularly like to congratulate the shadow Attorney-General, Mr Peter Costello, for the work he has done in negotiating and in pointing out the damaging results to the economy had the onus of proof been shifted, as was proposed by the original draft section 75AL, together with other provisions imposing new liability on manufacturers for imports. Mr Costello has done a first class job in bringing about changes to the Bill. As my colleague Senator Hill has said, the Opposition will not be opposing the legislation.

There are, however, a couple of other points I want to put on the record. I particularly want to draw comparison with the directive of the European Commission as it has been enacted by some, but not all, European Community members. Basically, the standard that has been adopted is the German standard. Indeed, the British Parliament passed legislation pursuant to the Commission's directive. The Commission held that the British legislation did not match up to the directive as it meant it to be fulfilled. It threatened the British Parliament by saying, `Either you change your legislation or we will take it to the European Court of Justice'.

Quite interestingly, there is not a political federation in the European Community; it has imposed upon itself a legal federation, the consequences of which it is still working through in terms of sovereignty and how it is going to establish a political framework. Here we say that we are matching the European standard, which is really the German interpretation of that standard. When I had discussions in Germany with some of its legislators, I asked how the legislation was operating, and they said that they could afford it. That was before their economy started to suffer something of a recession after the unification of East and West Germany. We will have to see what the future of that legislation is.

If we look at the Bill before us, we see that in some important respects the breadth of the current proposed law goes beyond the European standard and will impose stricter obligations on Australian producers than are imposed on their European counterparts. To this extent the Government cannot properly make the claim, as the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) has done in the second reading speech, that the introduction of a regime consistent with the directive will ensure that no undue impediments to trade are imposed. The words of an article written at the end of last year by Dr Ellen Beerworth of Mallesons Stephen Jaques go to the underlying philosophy of the Bill. She said, very simply, that the Bill will cost local companies millions of dollars and create damaging uncertainties for companies trying to protect their legal positions.

I must say that I have a problem with the concept of strict liability in the way it is being imposed. The contractual liabilities, the provisions of the Trade Practices Act as they presently exist and, of course, the tortious remedy of negligence I still think are good remedies for matters concerning damage to individuals caused by products that are faulty. To conclude my contribution I quote Dr Beerworth because I think her remarks are good:

SPEECH.PARA: The reforms . . . are inevitable because we are now conditioned by the very long period of public debate in this country, and by the very successful lobbying of the consumer protectionists, to believe that substantial reforms are necessary.

Again, referring to Senator Powell's remarks, we have to realise that in an economy such as ours we depend for our standard of living on the production of goods and services and the creation of wealth in which we may all then share. In this sort of legislation, which is brought about by pressure groups, lobby groups, who have their own power base largely funded by the taxpayer, we are starting to see an uneven balance. Nonetheless, I again congratulate Mr Costello for the fine negotiating work he did so that we have finally received a Bill which the Opposition will not oppose.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been mentioned during this excellent debate that it may be appropriate to refer to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs three matters which are not in the Trade Practices Amendment Bill but which are closely related—as it were, first cousins—to the matters that are in the Bill. I will quickly go through them. The first issue is whether there ought to be a period of repose in respect of any injuries that arise from the use of a defective implement and, if so, what that period should be. The second issue is whether people other than Australians who are injured overseas should be able to sue in respect of injuries resulting from defects in products which are manufactured in Australia. The third issue relates to the eternal question of the onus of proof and where that ought to lie.

PARA.TAB: I would be happy, as would other Government members of the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee, to take those matters on board. I raise this matter so that it can be considered by the coalition. The Deputy Chair of the Committee, Senator Vanstone, is very learned in this field, as she is in most fields of the law, and no doubt she will be able to tell the party room the issues involved. Senator Hill, who is also a lawyer, will be able to do that as well. As far as the Democrats are concerned, I have spoken to both Senator Powell and Senator Spindler and no doubt they will want to raise in the party room the issue of whether these matters should be referred to the Committee. As I have said, Government members of the Committee would be happy to have this issue referred to the Committee for further consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank those senators who joined in the debate on the Trade Practices Amendment Bill. This very important Bill will change the regime of product liability so far as manufacturers in Australia are concerned. It is in fact a very significant advance. The law which evolved out of the marketplace, the common law of England, provided for the costs of damage to property or injury to a person to be shifted from that unfortunate injured party to the manufacturer. This law, which is expressed in terms of contract law and tort law of negligence, modified by a statute here or a statute there, will now be supplemented in Australia by a law which will make it very clear that if a manufacturer puts a defective product into the marketplace and that defective product causes an injury, the manufacturer will have to pay compensation to that person who has suffered bodily injury or some damage to property.

PARA.TAB: This is a very reasonable proposition. I think it was necessary to depart from some of the earlier suggestions that emerged from law reform commissions and so on which had foreshadowed an attempt to bring about a regime where, simply, the fact that injury related to a product would be enough to require the manufacturer to pay compensation. We say, `No, it ought to be a defective product; it ought to be a product which does not meet the standards of safety which the community generally is entitled to expect'. It seems to me to be reasonable to say that a manufacturer should bear liability only in that situation. But if that situation does arise and the product does not meet the standard of safety which the community generally is entitled to expect and an injury occurs, then putting that product into the marketplace is an act which should bear financial consequences.

When I say that this is a reasonable proposition, I contrast it with the US situation, to which Senator Bishop quite rightly pointed. The product liability regime there is coupled with a regime which is highly favourable to plaintiffs. There are contingency fees and jury awards of damages, including punitive damages. There is a rule as to costs whereby a person can take a manufacturer defendant to court. That manufacturer defendant might be faced with, let us say, $2m in costs and successfully defend the claim but then have to pay the costs anyway. So the regime in the United States is one which we certainly would not wish to follow. It has had a disastrous impact on sectors of the manufacturing industry in the United States. Therefore, where do we look?

The European Community, which is a major manufacturing power and a major trading area of the world community, has certainly put forward a directive which has the sorts of elements we were looking for. Other areas, such as northern Asia—Japan, Taiwan and South Korea—are also showing an interest in taking up the European directive as the model for their laws relating to product liability. So we have taken that particular model and adapted it to Australian conditions. This is what has been put into the Bill now before us.

These measures will be salutary for Australian manufacturers. On the one hand, when they export, for example, into the European Community or into northern Asian markets which will adopt this regime, they will know from their Australian experience the sort of standard which they might be required to reach. On the other hand, if they are engaged in world competitive manufacturing and therefore exporting into various markets, it seems to me that Australian consumers should have exactly the same rights in respect of compensation for any damage to property or bodily injury as would be the case for consumers in the countries to which exports go.

The adoption of the European directive is a very sensible move. I am quite confident that it will lead to a situation where Australian manufacturers, rather than actually paying out great amounts of money to their insurers for claims brought under this Bill, will look to their design processes, their quality control processes and their whole manufacturing process. They will look to the way in which they put goods into the marketplace—the information and warnings that accompany such goods. They will upgrade their operation in a way which will not only reduce their insurance premiums but also bring them into conformity with the expectations underlying Parliament's passing of this legislation so that goods are not put into the marketplace which deviate from the standard of safety which the community generally is entitled to expect.

For all the reasons that have been put forward, I believe that the Bill deserves the support of the Senate. I understand Senator Powell's concern that certain matters have been deleted from the Bill, but they do not affect the substance of the reform which is being undertaken. I also believe that the courts will have regard to the jurisprudence which will emerge in the European Community, particularly from those English courts which adopt a more robust approach to the principle of res ipsa loquitur, namely, that the thing speaks for itself; that an inference can be drawn from the way in which a particular accident has occurred. If the Australian courts have a more sympathetic attitude to that principle—which, as I say, is adopted in the negligence law of the English courts in a more robust way than here in Australia—then we will make a significant advance.

That matter and others are to be considered by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs—this was alluded to by the eminent Chairman of the Committee, Senator Cooney, in his contribution to the debate this morning—so that we might have a full discussion in the public arena. Manufacturers and consumer lobby groups can put forward their point of view in a way which is not hidden—not by way of the sort of lobbying which can occur around the corridors—but open and on the Hansard record so that it can be properly assessed by the senators on that Committee. I am sure that they will do their job in a non-partisan way in order to ensure that we have the best regime possible for Australia.

That has been a consideration. Whilst I do not anticipate that in the near future the Opposition would accede to government at the Federal level here in Australia, I think it is extremely important for the manufacturing sector and for insurance purposes in Australia that there be a confidence that whatever legislation is put in place to do with product liability will survive for a considerable time. It would not be a good thing for the manufacturing sector in Australia, which is as such an employer of Australians, to have uncertainty about possible amendment in the future and be without, as I say, strong bipartisan support. I believe that that is why the Senate committee process is a useful way in trying to gather that sort of support.

I believe that this particular legislation will advance very considerably the rights of those Australians who suffer bodily injury or some loss in relation to their property occasioned by a product being put into the marketplace which does not meet the standard of safety which persons generally are entitled to expect. If a manufacturer does not design the product correctly, does not have adequate quality control processes during the manufacturing stage and does not accompany the product with sufficient and adequate information and warnings as it goes into the marketplace to be purchased, a manufacturer will have to bear the costs of such injury as is occasioned by that defective product.

That seems to me to be a very sensible principle. It strips away many of the hurdles, difficulties and impediments raised by the common law which have disabled otherwise worthy claimants from pursuing properly through the legal process claims for compensation. This will advance their interests in a way which I believe is very important. I therefore commend the Bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) may have been advised that we have one concern that has just been brought to our attention concerning the extraterritorial effect. It is a matter that was raised by Clayton Utz, Solicitors and Attorneys, by letter to the Minister dated 2 June. I understand that the solicitors have now received oral advice from senior counsel which confirms the basis of its concern. Its letter to the Minister—unfortunately I have not had a copy of that letter until just now—reads:

SPEECH.PARA: In the Second Reading Speech circulated in company with the Trade Practices Amendment Bill 1992, you stated that three provisions, including the provision under which overseas consumers were given the right to sue Australian manufacturers of defective products had been removed from the Bill. You foreshadowed that these amendments could be examined by a Senate Committee.
We have been dealing with that issue today.

Whilst the amendment proposed for s5(1) of the Trade Practices Act has been deleted from the Bill, the Schedule to the Bill contains an amendment to s6(2)(c), the effect of which is to give overseas consumers the right to sue Australian manufacturers of defective products. In order to give effect to the Government's announced intention that the extra-territorial provisions can be considered by the Senate Committee, this amendment should also be deleted from the Bill.

Paragraph 6(2)(c) in the schedule simply provides that after `that Part' insert `or in Part VA'. Whilst the Minister was closing the debate on the second reading, I hope he did not mind us having a brief discussion with his advisers. I understand that the legal opinion of the Crown is that it is a complex matter and somewhat ambiguous. In those circumstances, unless the Minister is very persuasive in his reply to these comments, I suggest that the safest course of action is that that part of the schedule also be removed and given to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for consideration. I am not sure whether there would be any other inadvertent consequence from that removal; the Minister might address that. Alternatively, he might consider that this particular issue should be adjourned until later in the day rather than take up time of the chamber at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The best advice I have is that the part in the schedule to which Senator Hill refers does not have the impact or effect it is claimed to have in that letter from Clayton Utz. All I can say is that there is an absolute undertaking by the Government that this particular part of the legislation should not have any extraterritorial application in the sense that we have discussed during the last several weeks. I think we would need to get proper advice. I think Senator Hill said he is relying on an oral opinion; Clayton Utz is relying on an oral opinion itself.
—But I gather Mr Ellicott has given an oral opinion concerning this advice, and it is to be put in writing in due course.

—That may well be the case. I think Senator Hill can accept that undertaking from me. In fact, we have tried in the body of the Bill to achieve that policy objective. If there is anything in the schedule which would negate or contradict that policy objective, of course we would remove, delete or amend it or in some way absolutely achieve that policy objective. There is no attempt at subterfuge or deception at all. I think that is accepted by everyone, because no-one picked this up until 5.30 yesterday evening.

PARA.TAB: I would actually prefer, at least on the initial advice I have, to press ahead with the Bill; then receive the written advice from Mr Ellicott; get our own written advice from the Chief General Counsel of the Commonwealth; and see where we stand on it, getting the Parliamentary Counsel to come in on the discussions. If by the time it gets to the other place we need to move an amendment—and we will have full discussions with the Opposition—we would do that and bring the amendment back. But I do not see any point in waiting here for a day or two in order to get all these written opinions. I believe we can deal with it that way.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall be very brief, because I know that we have a time constraint. I think it is important that we as legislators reflect that when we enact legislation it needs to be certain. We are placed on notice that there is already a dispute about the effect of the Trade Practices Amendment Bill. I accept Senator Tate's undertaking that should the defect in the Bill, as pointed out by Clayton Utz and senior counsel's opinion, be upheld, he will move to amend the legislation. I think it is incumbent upon us that we try to pass legislation and get it right the first time up. Too many times we see legislation that has to come back to be fixed up. I think that as legislators we have that responsibility.

—I accept the responsibility. Nevertheless, as a matter of process, on the best advice available to me the suggestion put forward as to an alleged effect of a part of the schedule is not correct. On that basis, I want to press ahead. But I do give an absolute undertaking to the Senate that if, over the course of the next 24 hours or 36 hours as this matter goes to the other place, we get a concurrence of opinion between Mr Ellicott, QC and the Chief General Counsel, we will move an amendment in the other place and bring it back accordingly.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bishop can take it from me that, given a very clear policy objective and given that that matter of extraterritoriality should go to a Senate committee and not be determined by legislation at this time, if there is any question of an extraterritorial impact as it emerges from a consideration by the Chief General Counsel of what Mr Ellicott has to say, then we will amend accordingly—if there is a question of probability about whether it has this effect or not, or if there is a bit of shading one way or another. I think that is not a bad undertaking.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats will accept that undertaking from the Minister. On clause 75AH, I ask whether the Minister has an answer to my question about the survival of liability actions.

—Senator Powell has raised a section which it is intended to place in this Act. If passed by the Parliament, it would have the effect of providing for the application of State and Territory laws about the survival of causes of action vested in persons who die to cases brought under this product liability reform, although State Acts provide that all causes of action vested in a person at the time of his or her death survive for the benefit of the estate. That is an important provision within the Bill.

PARA.TAB: I think Senator Powell is asking whether, because it is expressly provided for in relation to this product liability part of the Trade Practices Act as proposed, that has any implications for the survivability of causes of action, or the application of State laws providing for the survivability of causes of action which arise under other parts of the Trade Practices Act.

The advisers with me today indicate that they understand the point Senator Powell is making so far as rules of construction are concerned. They have been unable to find in the short time available whether other parts of the Trade Practices Act were enacted with an expectation that the State or Territory laws would apply without express provision to that effect; for example, to section 52. On the face of it and at first blush it is hard to see how an action for misleading or deceptive conduct would be one that would need to survive the death of the person bringing that action, or who would otherwise bring that action.

We need to give some further thought to it. It is certainly not the intention to disturb any existing provision or rule of interpretation which would allow the application of those State Acts, if they do apply, apart from the insertion of this particular provision. We need to get further advice on that. All I can say is that it is not the intention by inserting this provision about survival of liability to disturb any existing survival rights that do exist, if indeed they do exist, in relation to other parts of the Trade Practices Act. We will have a look at it with that policy in mind.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment.
