TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition supports the National Crime Authority Amendment Bill 1992. However, I wish to make a few remarks in respect of this Bill. The second reading speech by the then Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senate Tate) basically seeks to indicate that the Authority is faced with a sudden problem in that if two of the existing members do not have their appointments extended for a further year, the work they are currently doing on certain references will suffer—and that, presumably, will undoubtedly be the case—and that the Authority will not have the consistency of membership that it really does require to operate effectively.

PARA.TAB: The lack of consistency in membership of the Authority is a matter that the current Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority has drawn attention to, as the Minister rightly points out. That was done in the Committee's recent report, Who is to Guard the Guards?. I raise the matter now to indicate that that report is not the first time this matter has been raised; it was the last time it has been raised. It has been raised by nearly every composition of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority since it was originally formed. As I am informed by past members of the Committee, the lack of continuity in membership has been an ongoing problem.

Here we are in early June, knowing that the membership of two particular members of the Authority expires on 30 June this year, and that if this Bill is not passed then the Authority's membership will suffer this lack of continuity. Suddenly we have this Bill brought in to accommodate that problem to allow both of those members to be reappointed. It is worth noting perhaps that neither the Chairman nor any of the members can have their appointments extended past a four-year total. Nonetheless, these two particular members who were appointed for three years can now be reappointed for a further year.

This is an old problem. The Government has known since the commencement of the appointment of these two members that their membership would expire in June of this year. It is not as though it suddenly discovered that a few weeks ago; it is something that was known from the very beginning of their appointments. There have been other changes in the Authority that have made the retirement of two of its members a more difficult proposition. The former chairman of the Authority, Mr Justice Phillips, resigned on 17 December last year. That is not when he announced his retirement but that is when it took effect. The new chairman, Mr Thomas Sherman, took up his position on 26 February. Although there is another member—Mr Malcolm Gray, who is based in Adelaide—Mr Sherman and Mr Gray between them do not have a very extensive experience of Authority matters or of what has been happening over the last three years within the Authority. That might be a very good argument for extending the terms of Mr Cusack and Mr Leckie, but it does not address the problem of which we have known for a long time. There must be some other way by which the Government could have got around the problem of continuity of membership of the Authority: for example, by appointing someone else or by having people working for the Authority who knew that they were going to take up positions when Mr Leckie and Mr Cusack retired.

There is probably no other way out at this stage, but I am seeking to draw the Minister's attention to the fact that the problem has been recognised for a long time. This Bill is not the only possible resolution of the matter—or would not have been had attention been given to it earlier—but it is probably the only possible resolution now simply because the Government has left it until now. There were other ways in which to organise better continuity within the Authority.

An additional point is that all the Bill does is postpone the problem. It may well be true—although I doubt it—that, after a further year of appointment for Mr Cusack and Mr Leckie, Mr Sherman and Mr Gray will have gained more extensive experience of Authority operations. That would be a good thing and would provide for greater continuity. Nonetheless, there would still be the problem of one half of the membership leaving next year rather than this year. That leaves the problem of continuity in not having planned to stagger the departure of these two gentlemen by reappointing, for example, one and not the other.

Last but not least, it is a matter of regret that we find ourselves in this situation when there is a Standing Committee of Privileges inquiry under way, the outcome of which may have some impact on either gentleman. This chamber is being asked to endorse—and we are in fact endorsing—the appointments without knowing the outcome of that inquiry. That is also a matter of regret.

The coalition supports the Bill, but I underline my view, as the Deputy Chairman of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, that the Government could and should have given attention to providing better continuity of membership in other ways. I will be interested to see whether there is some explanation by the Government as to whether it did think of other ways and, if so, why they were discarded and why we now find ourselves a few weeks before the terms of the two gentlemen expire being asked to extend their membership of the Authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the National Crime Authority Amendment Bill 1992 is to amend section 37 to allow for the reappointment of two of the current members of the Authority while keeping their terms within the overall limit of four years as provided by statute. I agree with the comment made by Senator Vanstone, that the Government has placed itself in a somewhat embarrassing position in having to do that with a great deal of haste. While it is certainly true that the action the Government is now taking is in response, or could be said to be in response, to a recommendation made by the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority in its report titled Who is to Guard the Guards?, the matter has been raised on numerous occasions before and it was very apparent that the problem would arise.

PARA.TAB: At the moment it has arisen because the three-year terms of both Mr Cusack, QC, and Mr Leckie, expire on 30 June 1992. Both members are heavily involved in current references. Mr Sherman has only recently been appointed as Chairman. Although Mr Gray, QC, has been a member for almost 12 months, he has necessarily been confined to a limited aspect of the Authority's operation. For these reasons, as well as Mr Justice Phillips's unexpected resignation, the Authority would lack members with any significant tenure and experience.

This measure has been given some additional urgency by the difficulties that were experienced in the hand-over of the chairmanship of the National Crime Authority from Mr Justice Stewart to Mr Faris, which gave rise to the so-called Ark report episode where we finished up with two versions of the same report, one purportedly authorised by the previous Chairman and the other authorised by the new Chairman. It is clear that such embarrassing, inefficient and certainly undesirable situations must be avoided. While we would have liked to get the Government to act a lot sooner on this matter, the Australian Democrats do not raise any objection to this Bill and will support it, for the reasons outlined.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise, Mr Acting Deputy President. I did not realise that the National Crime Authority Amendment Bill was coming on. To the extent that it is being brought on now, for the convenience of the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) and, presumably, the chamber—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Burns)—Yes, without much opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief. It serves little purpose to retrace the purpose of the Bill, other than to say that, if we do not reflect on history, we are bound to repeat the mistakes of it.
—Can I write that down?
—No doubt the Minister will read that in Hansard with the same diligence and enthusiasm as he reads everything else I say.

PARA.TAB: We find ourselves in a situation now where the operation of the National Crime Authority would in some way be considerably impaired in the event that this legislation does not succeed, as the term of office of two of the present members of the NCA expires on 30 June 1992 and both members are heavily involved in current references. They are Mr Cusack and Mr Leckie.

I seem to remember having voted against the National Crime Authority Bill when it was first introduced very many years ago because I thought it was debasing the federalist approach to law enforcement agencies and I believed that there were other appropriate mechanisms for the gathering of information on law enforcement in Australia. However, having said that, I have been as enthusiastic as anybody to ensure that it succeeds.

The Authority's history has been a very sorry one almost from day one. Perhaps from the very beginning the problem was that there was competition between the Government and the Opposition as to who could introduce the most draconian legislation, because law and order was an issue. When that took place, there was almost an obligation upon the Chairman of the NCA to get some scalps straightaway to justify the NCA being set up. Initially there seemed to be a pursuit of short term objectives so that the existence of the creature could be justified both by the Authority and by the Government.

As we have lurched out of that circumstance, all sorts of other crises have occurred along the way—whether they have been with the Chairman or with the members; whether they have been with internal dissatisfaction, lack of morale, lack of success, lack of direction, lack of purpose, lack of understanding of the objectives; whether they have been with duplication of other law enforcement authorities. The whole range of matters has in many respects been the cause of the abysmal failure of the NCA.

That all changed in many respects with the appointment of Mr Justice Phillips to the Chairman's position. I hope that the good work that he undertook will be built on by the present Chairman; but the fact that now, because of current legislation, the very operations of the NCA will be in some peril if this legislation is not passed, is simply a further reflection of the problems of the NCA. I hope from this point on that the operations of the NCA will become more predictable, the quality of the members will be of the standard to ensure that it will be an effective operation and, in due course, the timing of their appointments and their retirement will not in any way inhibit the functioning of the NCA. I hope that simple matters such as that can be put in place to ensure its effective operation. To the extent that the legislation does what it does, I support the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank those senators who have contributed to the debate on this Bill, which is to do with ensuring that there is continuity in the leadership of the National Crime Authority. It is a law enforcement body which has federalist features in that it was established precisely to overcome many of the territorial—
—It is a bit of a hybrid.

—It is a bit of a hybrid, but it was designed to overcome many of the territorial inhibitions on effective law enforcement work in Australia where organised criminal activity had no regard to State boundaries. It was necessary that law enforcement agencies should be able to operate across State boundaries. In its core legislation, the National Crime Authority is designed precisely to provide a mechanism which enables jurisdictions to cooperate in giving references to the Authority so that it can pursue organised criminal activity wherever it might occur within Australia. When we were establishing the National Crime Authority, it was also extremely important to note some overseas experience. In particular, I recall when I chaired the Senate Committee which came up with the final draft of a National Crime Authority-type approach—
—The halcyon days.

—That is right; they were good days. The honourable senator may have been a member. Honourable senators will recall that we had many discussions about the influence—I will not put an adjective in front of it—of J. Edgar Hoover on the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the lesson that might be learned from allowing a person to exercise such extraordinary power of investigation for a long period within a democracy. It was therefore determined that the tenure of office of the members of the Authority should really be only three years—I think three years was decided upon.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps that is a little short, but we were very conscious of the need to guard against the concentration of intelligence gathering and memory, and therefore the capacity to know a tremendous amount over perhaps decades or generations of people's activity within a democracy, if the position were to be held by one person, vested with extraordinary powers. At the time the National Crime Authority was established, it was endowed with powers which were not available to any other police force or law enforcement agency in Australia. This was particularly so, so far as taking evidence without regard to the usual rules relating to the protection privilege against self-incrimination was concerned.

So that was the reason for the imposition of what now perhaps looks to be an arbitrary and certainly is a short term of office for the members of the Authority. It has created some problems in flexibility when there is a coincidence in the ending of the terms of office of several members of the National Crime Authority. The fact that the terms of office of Mr Cusack, QC and Mr Leckie conclude on the same day would not really have raised a problem if Mr Justice Phillips had continued as Chairman of the Authority; he would have given the experience and continuity that was required. But, of course, we know that he has been appointed Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of Victoria.

Mr Tom Sherman has been Chairman of the Authority for three or four months only, and while Mr Grey is over in Adelaide, I think, working on a particular reference, and certainly has more restricted experience in dealing with references by the National Crime Authority, it is thought to be prudent to guard against the loss of that experience and expertise and to seek the Parliament's concurrence, therefore, in providing for the sort of provision which would allow Mr Cusack, QC, and Mr Leckie to continue for a year. Therefore, Mr Acting Deputy President, I certainly commend this Bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
Debate resumed from 7 May, on motion by Senator Bolkus:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill 1992, which seeks to amend some of the changes made to the funding and disclosure provisions by the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Act 1991. The Opposition will not be opposing this Bill, but I would like to make a few remarks about it.

PARA.TAB: The Bill is a technical piece of legislation and its main purpose is to ease the accounting workload for political parties created by the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Act. Honourable senators will remember that one of the major thrusts of that Act was to ban advertising on radio and television of political parties during election campaigns. It was responsible for the longest continuous debate in this chamber since 1964. However, this particular Bill does not touch the broadcast aspects, but simply the disclosure aspects.

The Act introduced in 1992 introduced greater financial reporting requirements for political parties and third parties. In particular, it required registered political parties to lodge annual returns detailing all income expenditure and debts. In the months since the Act came into operation, it has become obvious that the Government has yet again created an administrative nightmare for political parties and their branches in trying to comply with those reporting requirements. It must be remembered that all branches are made up of volunteers, and the people most likely to be affected are the non-Labor political parties in Australia because their branches are so important to them. They are so unimportant to the Labor Party, which relies almost entirely for its support and the preselection of its candidates on the trade union movement.

Under the existing Act, political parties need to record the identity of every person or organisation who pays to, receives from, or is owed money by the party, regardless of how small that sum might be. The data must be collected and collated to determine that the total sum paid to, received by, or owed by the party exceeds the $1,500 limit, which triggers the identification requirements for disclosure. The revised division 5A incorporated in this Bill, which exempts the reporting of sums of less than $100 received by a party during a fundraising event, and the disclosure of sums of less than $100 owed by the parties, will go some way towards easing the administrative burden of complying with the disclosure provisions.

Similarly, new section 314AB allows registered political parties 20 weeks instead of the existing eight weeks to lodge their annual returns at the end of the financial year. This is a more realistic timeframe in which to prepare those reports. The Opposition welcomes the provision of new section 314AD, which will protect the privacy of party employees by exempting details of their wages and salaries from the party's reporting requirements.

I could not help but note that the Labor Government has made life a little easier for itself and for its trade union benefactors by removing the obligation to detail the names and addresses of executives of registered industrial organisations, that is, trade unions, in their returns to the Electoral Commission. However, I do understand that, from a practical point of view, it is a requirement that the Electoral Commissioner has really never had to call on, and for that reason we will not be opposing it.

Nevertheless, despite the amendments in the Bill, the Government's funding and disclosure legislation still remains flawed and inadequate. On the one hand, the reporting requirements are so onerous that they will deter honest people from donating to a political party, while, on the other hand, there are such large gaps in some of the disclosure laws that it is possible to drive the proverbial truck through them.

The Government pays plenty of lip-service to the notion of full accountability of political funding and expenditure, but its laws are neither fair nor equitable. This was canvassed in December 1991 on the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill. As was pointed out at that time, the coalition, the Liberal and National parties, support full, fair and equitable disclosure of political donations. To achieve this, we believe that disclosure laws must ensure that a level playing field exists between the parties, including in regard to taxation, so that no party enjoys a tax advantage over the others. There should be severe penalties if any donor to a political party is singled out for punitive action as a result of making that donation, and donations should be voluntary.

The Labor Government has turned a blind eye to these issues, which are essential for fair and just funding and disclosure laws. There is no level playing field between the parties. When I say `the parties', I mean the Labor Party as against any other political party in this country, whether it be the Liberal Party, the National Party, the Democrats or any other group. It enjoys that unfair financial advantage because of its special relationship with the trade unions. As everybody is aware, there are two arms to the Labor Party. One is the industrial arm, which is the trade union movement, and the other is the political arm, which is the ALP in government or in Parliament.

The ALP benefits greatly from the current regime, under which its main benefactor, the trade union movement, can make tax free donations to the party. It is not generally recognised in the community that all income received by trade unions is tax free money. A trade union would pay no tax if it owned, for example, the Gold Coast casino or a part of it. If a trade union sells a major building which it owns in the central business district of any capital city, it does not pay capital gains tax. In my State of Queensland, unions are absolved from paying land tax. Yet the trade union movement is a major organisation in Australia with major investments and it is given a privileged status. Again, in my home State of Queensland the ALP headquarters are located in the Trades and Labor Council building at West End. Not only does that show the ownership of the Australian Labor Party by the trade union movement, but it also shows the special tax benefits that accrue to the Labor Party by that association.

Honourable senators opposite point out that the income tax exemption also applies to other professional and trade organisations. But these associations, unlike the trade unions, are not affiliated with any political party, nor do they act as a conduit for funds to a political party. Simply in affiliation fees, my calculation—and I mentioned this figure last time—indicates that the ALP picks up, around Australia every year, an amount of about $5m.

The coalition believes that funding and disclosure provisions must ensure that donations to parties are voluntary. No such safeguard exists at present. In fact, the Labor Party profits handsomely from the de facto compulsory donations of ordinary workers when people are forced to be members of a union or not have a job, as is the case in every closed shop throughout Australia. It occurs across the board in the mining industry, for example; it occurs across the board in the major building industry—I am not talking about the home ownership building industry; it occurs across the board in such places as the waterfront.

The worker's union dues are tax deductible to him, and I do not object to that. But then that tax deductibility is passed on to the ALP by way of affiliation fees, which vary from place to place, I understand, but are $2.10 or thereabouts per head.

It would also be interesting to know why that affiliation does occur. The close relationship between the two is well recognised. We saw this not so long ago in Queensland, when the Premier of Queensland, Mr Wayne Goss, attended a function organised by only a handful—one handful—of people from the Federated Clerks Union, which agreed to affiliate with the ALP. This is in the Cooke report, which Senator Kernot, by her smile, has read. The question was asked, `Why did you affiliate?', the cost being about $30,000. The answer given was, `Well, we did not actually go and get all the unionists' approval to do this, but we affiliated because it gave us ready access to Ministers and an ability to influence government policy'. If that is not the puppeteer working on the puppets, what is? It makes a joke of claims made by people on the other side as to the sorts of controls that may be exercised on our side of politics.

This is tantamount to a compulsory donation, regardless of whether the employee supports the ALP. It is very interesting to look at the figures. Of those people who are members of the trade union movement, some 40 to 45 per cent vote for the Liberal Party. Yet, against their wishes, they are being compelled to support a political party of which they do not approve. If the trade union movement wants to make donations to the ALP and play politics, as the ACTU is planning to do, that must be disclosed. This raises another interesting point.

We have read just recently that the ACTU is planning to spend some $10m in a campaign against the coalition to oppose the Fightback package, doing so with basically a tax free status. I am simply making the point that groups that support the other political parties in Australia do not have the luxury of being able to claim tax deductibility. I must say, however, that in the amendments to the Bill last year minor amounts were allowed, which would be of some benefit to the other parties. That is a step in the right direction.

Another important condition of the full, fair and equitable disclosure is that donors must be protected against coercion and intimidation. Every time I have raised this, people have said to me, `It does not really exist. You are making it up'. Anyone with any experience of the world out there knows the nonsense involved in that. I might also say that to some degree it is a human reaction. It is not necessarily an evil reaction.

I can tell a story against myself right here and now. About a year ago I saw a list of donors to the Australian Labor Party. One of the people on the top of that list, who had made a major donation, was someone I knew very well. Because it was disclosed, two things went through my mind. Firstly, I thought, `I can never have a decent conversation with that person again'. That is a human reaction. Secondly, I thought, `Why did he pay that money and what is he going to get out of it?'. That is the sort of thing that happens. People who normally donate to non-Labor parties will say outright, `The reason we do not want it disclosed is that we do not want to be intimidated by a militant trade union or by a hostile government'. Again I say this in a non-political way because it occurs across the board.

The problem of disclosure and intimidation is very real. I hope that, with the tightened up penalties that we put in the Bill in 1991, sooner or later someone will be picked up for that. It will enable people to feel more confident about donating to a political party simply because they can believe in the direction that is being taken.

Let me give a little example. I am not in the business of fundraising. That is not our job. I do not think I am good at it, either. I do not like asking people for money. A businessman told me that if he gave a $20 donation to the Liberal Party, in his honest opinion, the unions would ensure that $200,000 worth of damage was done to his company. That is not a story that I am throwing around here for political purposes; it is a genuine belief held by people in society. We had the example in debate here some time ago of Senator Ray warning Lindsay Fox that, while he had had good industrial relations in the past, he may not expect to have them in the future if it were known that he had given a substantial donation to the Liberal Party.

A little old lady pensioner from far north Queensland sent me through the mail a donation of $10 but she said specifically that she did not want a receipt because she did not want anyone to know she had given it to me in case she was singled out for some sort of discrimination in the small country town from which she came. I just highlight those matters.

I have indicated that we will not be opposing the legislation. Adequate disclosure laws must include severe penalties to protect donors from thuggery. The legislation is not controversial but it is more offensive for what it omits than for what it contains. We will be addressing some of those things in government. Why does the Government not remedy these glaring omissions? The answer is simply that the Labor Party is not really fair dinkum about fairness and equity. It is pragmatic. It will do whatever needs to be done to win an election. The only concern of the Labor Party is to save an endangered animal from extinction. This should appeal to the Australian Democrats.

This is a mangy beast which the people of Australia will put down at the next election to rid themselves of the misery the creature has caused. It is a last, desperate attempt to create an unfair advantage for the Labor Party that it hopes will save it from electoral oblivion. If the Keating Labor Government thought it had enough money and popularity to win the next election, it would dump all this legislation and its intended political advertising bans laws tomorrow.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a procedural matter before Question Time. We are presuming that the Foreign Minister is today to finally table all the Marshall Islands documents. I was wondering whether he might table them before Question Time rather than at the end of Question Time in order that we could have a look at them.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

—I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. When is the Minister going to table the documents that we have sought for so long? The Minister indicated yesterday that he had the documents; his Department had compiled them. What is the reason for the further delay?

—I will table them as soon as I can, hopefully tomorrow. The reason for the delay is that Opposition senators occupied the whole of yesterday afternoon, or the greater part of it. Last night and this morning I have had the New Zealand Foreign Minister in town and I have been wholly preoccupied with that. I am not going to table any documents until I have had a chance to peruse the documents in question and satisfy myself that FOI criteria have been properly applied. The Opposition will just have to curb its racing hormones and wait.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister for the basis upon which he raises the question of freedom of information. Surely the Senate is entitled to the documents, being the whole of the documents. If there are matters of personal confidentiality or matters of that type, then there are well acknowledged procedures to ensure that they are excised or brought to the attention of an individual on a confidential basis. On what basis is the Minister applying this criterion, saying that these documents to which the Senate should be entitled need to go through an FOI testing procedure?

—I have made it perfectly clear on a number of occasions that I will be applying FOI criteria. That implies necessarily having regard to judicial process in operation here or elsewhere. It implies having regard to confidentiality and private matters. It requires having regard to Australia's international relations and the effect upon them. It requires having regard to a whole heap of other things that ought to be well known to be in the text of the legislation.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I ask for your guidance on this point, because the natural corollary of what Senator Evans has to say is that without FOI legislation—
—Mr President, there is no point of order. Senator Bishop is not even pretending to raise a point of order.
—Order!

—The difficulty is that the corollary of what Senator Evans is putting to the Senate is that the Senate is not entitled to information in its own right and that if FOI legislation did not exist, then we would not be entitled to any information. Under present rulings on the record, Mr President—
—What point of order are you raising now?

—The point of order, Mr President, is that on the record there are rulings whereby the Senate has required a Minister to make information available. Indeed, Mr President, it is important that that point of order be upheld and that information be made available to the Senate because the Senate asked for it, and not pursuant to any legislation—
—You are a disgrace! You are a total disgrace.

—Order! This is not a point of order and it is not a matter for me to decide; it is a matter for the Senate to decide. What I am concerned about is senators increasingly taking spurious points of order to make debating points at Question Time. I am extremely reluctant to take any action which would result in the use of a particular standing order, but I think that this is an issue, particularly on broadcast days, about which something will have to be done.
—I raise a point of order. Senator Bolkus, in an interjection to Senator Bishop, said, `You're a disgrace', and I ask him to withdraw.
—Order! I ask Senator Bolkus to withdraw.
—I did call Senator Bishop a disgrace. I honestly believe that. If it is outside the Standing Orders, I will withdraw. But I do not believe it is outside the Standing Orders, Mr President.

—I direct a question to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to yesterday's major announcements on aviation policy. In relation to those announcements, can the Minister advise the Senate what the current position is on negotiations with the New Zealand Government on the arrangements for trans-Tasman aviation?

PARA.TAB: Senator O'Chee interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Just remain calm, Chicken Little; the sky is not going to fall in. We have a very good front row over here. I am pleased to advise the Senate that today the governments of Australia and New Zealand announced an agreement to implement major changes in aviation relations between Australia and New Zealand. This agreement follows detailed discussions between me and the New Zealand Minister for Transport, Mr Storey, and between officials of our respective countries.

PARA.TAB: The issues involved are complex, but agreement has been reached on key elements of a package to be phased in over the next three years. The first phase of the revised arrangements, to be formalised in a memorandum of understanding which will be signed next week, will commence in November of this year when a number of trans-Tasman city pairs become available for passenger services to Australasian carriers other than Qantas and Air New Zealand. These pairs will initially focus on routes not currently served by existing carriers, which could include services from Melbourne to New Zealand's international gateways.

Multiple designation of all trans-Tasman city pairs available for international services, and any other combinations approved by the two governments, will be phased in over the next three years. At the same time, Australian and New Zealand airlines will be permitted to increase progressively the number of destinations served and the flights offered in markets beyond each country. We have agreed with the New Zealand Government to review by 30 June 1993 the commitment to allow full access for New Zealand airlines to the Australian domestic market from November 1994. The review will examine whether an earlier timetable is achievable in light of progress on the deregulation of trans-Tasman services.

Increased competition on the trans-Tasman will be of major benefit to consumers from both nations. It will promote trade and commerce between the two countries and the development of our respective travel and tourism industries. The promotion and development of tourism and trade to our two countries as a regional destination are particularly important in improving our marketing efforts in the Asian region.

This agreement represents an important step towards the establishment of a single aviation market which is a common goal of both the Australian and New Zealand governments. The aviation relationship between Australia and New Zealand—already one of the most liberal in the world—now features completely market driven capacity determination on services within and between the two countries; an all-points exchange of international gateways, allowing airlines to operate to any international airport in the territory of the other government; multiple designation of dedicated freight services; phased multiple designation of scheduled passenger airlines, with full multiple designation no later than November 1994; virtually no government control over air fares; a liberal approach to passenger and freight charters; and an exchange of rights which allows Australian and New Zealand airlines to operate in competition with each other in third country markets.

This agreement represents another major achievement of this Government in aviation policy. The gap between this Government's real achievements in aviation and the Opposition's years of neglect grows wider.

I refer to the Minister's brief explanation yesterday following Question Time in which he stated that the Attorney-General, Mr Duffy, had said during Question Time in the other place that exchanges had taken place between his Department and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade relating to the arrest of Mr Symons. I ask: why did the Minister fail to inform the Senate that the Attorney-General yesterday also referred `to a short conversation at a chance meeting on 16 May between a member of the Department of the Attorney-General and a member of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, where there was a discussion about the timing of matters which took place in the Marshall Islands'? I note that this was one day after Mr Lamb had sent the memo to the Department which detailed Senator Richardson's involvement in Mr Symons's business activities. I also ask: who were the individuals involved in this chance meeting and what precisely was discussed?

—There is a supplementary background note to the matter I read to the Senate from the Attorney-General yesterday which bears upon this question. I am not sure that there is anything confidential about this. It is in the following terms: there is no record of any other consultations between the two departments in the files of the Attorney-General's Department. In a short conversation at a chance meeting on Saturday, 16 May, between Geoffrey Dabb, FAS, Criminal and Security Law Division, and Mr David Tough, the former First Secretary in Suva, there was discussion about the knowledge of the Suva Embassy about the matter at the time of Mr Symons's dealings in the Marshalls.

PARA.TAB: That is just a matter of a conversation; it is not a matter of anything in respect of which there is any record on the departmental files. I will seek from the Attorney-General any information he is further able to give me as to the substance of that which does not infringe questions of proper confidentiality.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Perhaps the Minister can confirm that he will ascertain whether there is any memo in existence and, if so, that that would be tabled.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Associated Pulp and Paper Mills: Dispute

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Industrial Relations been drawn to reports that the parent company of APPM has had meetings during the Burnie dispute with senior members of the Federal Opposition, including Dr Hewson and John Howard? Is this the same Mr Howard who only yesterday was being very noisy about the need for `parliamentarians on both sides, State and Federal' to stay out of this dispute? Is there any indication so far that the involvement of Dr Hewson and Mr Howard has helped bring about a fair and orderly conclusion to this dispute?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have seen the reports. Mr Howard said yesterday that 13 days ago in Sydney he met with Mr Wade, the chief executive officer of North Broken Hill Peko, the holding company owning APPM. That is one meeting to which Mr Howard has confessed. It is now reported that two weeks before the meeting 13 days ago to which Mr Howard has confessed he met Mr Bill Paisley, the chief executive officer of APPM, and Mr Chris Oldfield, the public relations officer of APPM, in Canberra. Apparently APPM came to Canberra for that meeting. That is a meeting Mr Howard has not confessed to but has now reported.

PARA.TAB: It has also been reported to me that Dr Hewson met Mr Wade on 14 May in Melbourne. Apparently Dr Hewson went to Melbourne for that meeting, which took place in the company's headquarters in Melbourne. There is a touch of burlesque almost about this meeting because the report I have received says that APPM scheduled a press conference for its own headquarters but shifted it to the Radisson Hotel because the press might spring Dr Hewson leaving the APPM premises. They are the meetings we have been told about by Mr Howard or that have been reported or that we have been informed about to this point. We do not know what other contact has been made.

My Department reported on 13 May—13 May is the day before Dr Hewson met APPM—that the situation was rapidly deteriorating and had become unstable in this dispute. On the same day, Dr Hewson chastised Premier Ray Groom of Tasmania publicly for supporting APPM. From that time, the dispute has gone downhill.

I refer to the second question I have been asked. On 14 May—the day Dr Hewson met APPM—Mr Howard made his first statement that, `Politicians should butt out of this dispute'. Mr Howard has made at least four formal statements and many comments of that type since. These were aimed at Premier Ray Groom and at me, on behalf of this Government, despite the fact that we speak for governments with a responsibility for the public interest. While Mr Howard was calling on politicians to butt out, it is now clear that he and Dr Hewson had met the company before that and had met the company since. What we have here is a clear case of two faces—a public face of innocence to the community and a conspiring face of complicity with the company.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order. Mr President, I seek your advice. Is there any requirement for the Minister to tell the truth in answers?
—Order!

—Mr President, I wish to speak to the point of order. A senator may interrupt another senator on only two grounds—first, to call a quorum or, secondly, to raise a point of order or a matter of privilege. A senator is not permitted to seek your advice on some matter as to content. Mr President, I ask you to look at standing order 203 and consider dealing with Senator Walters appropriately under paragraph (a) of that standing order.
—Order! There is no point of order. I have warned senators about spurious points of order and I will act.

—It is clear that while Mr Howard was calling on politicians to butt out, he was involved in discussions with the company over this dispute. What we now have is a clear case of Mr Howard having two faces—one face of innocence to the community, calling on people not to be involved, and another face of complicity with the company, being directly involved. There are two words in the English language which describe that type of behaviour—`hypocrisy' and `duplicity'.

PARA.TAB: I refer to the third question asked of me. No, none of these actions has helped settle this dispute. Last Sunday, the Premier of Tasmania, Ray Groom, and I, in the public interest, tried to settle that dispute. Mr Howard accused us as governments of meddling in that dispute. The truth is that Mr Howard is the meddler. This dispute is now very serious; it has not been settled; and during the period of his secret involvement, it has got worse.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer to the report released two days ago by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, entitled Australia's Environment: Issues and Facts. Among many other things, it states that Australians produce more greenhouse gases and rubbish per person than almost any other nation; consume three times more energy per person than the global average; and have degraded or destroyed more than half their native forests and soils. Does the Minister accept that the Bureau of Statistics figures are evidence that our patterns of production and consumption are unsustainable? If not, why not? Secondly, is he aware that South Korea, one of several countries to recognise that environmental problems create markets for solutions, has launched a 10-year, $1 billion plan to develop and commercialise green technologies? Finally, does the Minister accept that Australian industry must be restructured in accordance with principles of ecologically sustainable development if it is to compete in the twenty-first century marketplace and that it is time he developed an ambitious new industry plan to set the ball rolling?

—Somebody once said that people can use statistics like a drunk uses a lamppost—for support rather than illumination. That is what Senator Coulter has done with this question. The Australian community and government have a generally sensible consciousness of environmental issues.
—Including the farmers?

—Yes, including the farmers. We produce one per cent of the world's greenhouse gases. To change that into a per capita figure, as Senator Coulter has done, is not a fair measure because we have been a resource rich country and have been developing industries on the basis of natural resources for a long time. There can be no immediate change in that process—in my view, there ought not to be—provided we are conscious of the many problems associated with the dissemination of greenhouse gases and the climate warming effects which may follow.

PARA.TAB: It is all very well to say that South Korea has embarked on a project of investing some $1 billion in green technologies, as Senator Coulter calls them. That is undoubtedly true. Taiwan has done the same. All these countries have much larger population problems than Australia. They have been developing industries at a very rapid rate without any regard at all to environmental factors. It is natural that South Korea, confronted as it is with many environmental problems, should adopt the approach it has to green technologies. Of course, there are other countries which have done the same sort of thing.

We as a nation have to adjust over a period to the difficulties which we may confront as a result of environmental concerns in light of available evidence at the time. That is not to be obtained by the sort of sleight of hand that Senator Coulter has displayed in using the ABS figures.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you mean `sleight' of hand?

—Senator Alston is at it again. I said sleight of hand. In Australia, the Government and a number of industries have given a lot of attention to development of industries involved with waste management—that is an ongoing process—just as the Koreans have done. We have done the same sort of thing. A number of large Australian companies are now involved in the development of waste management divisions. A lot of small high technology companies are also involved in that.

PARA.TAB: I apprehend the burden of Senator Coulter's question as being that we should close down the coal industry, the aluminium industry and a number of others and start producing purely high technology equipment and so on. That is the loopy bourgeois green agenda, if Senator Coulter does not mind my saying so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Am I to assume that this book produced by the Australian Bureau of Statistics will be another one that will be withdrawn because the Government does not like the material that is in it, similar to what we have seen with the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories? The statistics which I quoted were not like the lamppost used by a drunken man; they were statistics taken directly out of this book. In light of the Minister's reply, is it not a fact that the very expensive exercise which the previous Prime Minister embarked upon to develop a pattern for ecologically sustainable development was futile and a waste of money and the Government has no intention whatsoever of implementing any part of it?

—I do not want to repeat the story again for one person—Senator Coulter—who did not understand it. The book, the statistics, will not be withdrawn. I have no objection to the book; I have an objection to Senator Coulter. My objection to Senator Coulter is simply that he used those figures for the purpose of mounting a particular argument which happens to suit him. To say that a country in which a lot of industry is based on low energy costs produces one per cent of the world's greenhouse and then translate that into a per capita figure, as if there was something particularly immoral about that, is a very poor way of dealing with what are undoubtedly valid statistics.

PARA.TAB: I used the expression `bourgeois green' before. What those in the Democrats ultimately have to decide is whether this country is to develop as a middle class green society, exporting all its problems to countries which have less capacity to cope with them than we do. If that is what they want, they ought to say so. But that is what they are about. The whole question of greenhouse and climate change is a global problem. What this `fairies at the bottom of the garden' party is about is solving global problems at Australia's expense.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories. I draw the Minister's attention to a proposed development called the Harbour City Canal Estate on the Creery Wetlands at Mandurah in Western Australia. Firstly, is the Minister aware of the proposed development? Secondly, has the Minister's Department fully investigated the ecological values of the Creery Wetlands and the implications of the proposed development? Thirdly, if so, what are the results of these investigations? Fourthly, have the investigations of the ecological values shown that the entire Creery Wetlands should be included on the list of Wetlands of International Importance? Fifthly, does the proposed development contravene Australia's obligations as a signatory to the Ramsar Convention on Wetlands of International Importance? Finally, what action is the Government taking to ensure that any development in the region does not contravene Australia's obligations under the Ramsar Convention?
—As it happens I am right across this.
—There is a lot of you to go across, too.

—I have enough fat jokes of my own without Senator Hill adding to them. The Minister for the Environment has provided me with the following information. Issues relating to the proposed canal estate known as the Harbour City development at the Creery Wetlands are principally a matter for the Government of Western Australia. However, the Commonwealth Government does have an interest in the proposal on environmental grounds. The Commonwealth's principal concerns are in relation to Australia's obligations under international treaties as mentioned by Senator Chamarette—the bilateral agreement with the governments of Japan and China for the protection of migratory birds and the Ramsar Convention.

PARA.TAB: The Creery Wetlands form part of the Peel-Yalgorup system, which was listed as a wetland of international importance under the Ramsar Convention in 1990. The proposed Harbour City development site lies on private land immediately adjacent to this wetland and, as such, there may be potential for negative impacts on the Ramsar site environment. Under the Ramsar Convention, the principal expectation is that sites, once listed as internationally important, will be managed in a way that protects the ecological characteristics for which they were recognised. Any action taken that results in the deterioration of these ecological characteristics is considered a violation of the convention.

Under the Japan-Australia and China-Australia migratory birds agreement, Australia is obliged to protect certain migratory bird species in their important habitat areas. The Creery Wetlands are important for up to 25 species of migratory birds included in the annexes to JAMBA and CAMBA.

The Western Australian Environment Protection Authority released a consultative environment review on the Harbour City development proposal for public comment on 20 April of this year. The Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service is currently liaising with the WAEPA and the Western Australian Department of Conservation and Land Management to ensure that the Commonwealth's environmental concerns and, in particular, Australia's international obligations, will be properly addressed in the review process.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer the Minister to a question asked in Question Time yesterday concerning export market development grants made to companies linked with Mr Greg Symons. I ask the Minister: how many other educational institutions are indebted to the Commonwealth with respect to overseas students unable to obtain visas to Australia; which of these have received export market development grants since the Government became aware of the problem in early 1990; is it a fact that the Government is seeking to recover some $60m from those institutions and that it has already lodged five actions under the Trade Practices Act to recover $25m; are those institutions still entitled to receive EMDG payments under the Minister's guidelines; why has the Government failed to develop a coordinated trade strategy; and what efforts will the Minister make to ensure that businesses indebted to the Commonwealth are not able to receive funds under the export market development grants scheme?

—Mr President, perhaps you will allow me to begin by congratulating Senator Bishop on my own behalf and that of my colleagues on her appointment, announced today by the Leader of the Opposition, as head of the flag task force. I understand that brings her up to twentieth in line for appointment as Parliamentary Secretary and thirty-fifth now in line for the front bench. It is a matter of very considerable gratification to all of us to see that. So, to Senator Bishop I say: well done. I think that ought not to pass without acknowledgment.

PARA.TAB: I am not in a position to give detailed information as to the numbers of educational institutions that are being sued or that are in other ways the subject of Senator Bishop's question so far as indebtedness in relation to the China students matter is concerned. That is obviously a question that should be directed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, and I ask Senator Bishop to direct accordingly those parts of her question that are within that Minister's responsibility to that Minister and not to me.

It is the case that there is a significant sum of money presently being sought through the courts by the Commonwealth through the Department of Employment, Education and Training in relation to those institutions. The precise amount in question is something she will have to elicit, as I have said, from the other Minister. As to the particular question of whether or not the EMDGs are payable to institutions that may be indebted to the Commonwealth, that is a matter that, as I said yesterday, I believe is governed by the express language of the EMDG Act, which creates an obligation upon the relevant authorities to pay them, once the entitlement to be paid is established according to statutory criteria. To the extent that that might open up a question of policy as to whether the legislation should be reviewed, that is an appropriate matter for the Government to contemplate. I have already said that yesterday; I cannot repeat it today.

I only make the point that these aspects of the legislation are endemic in its very framework. The Opposition agreed completely with the legislation and has never raised these questions before. So honourable senators opposite should not get on their high horse now about them because they have no credibility when they do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. It was difficult to hear parts of the Minister's answer due to the rabble on the other side, but then I expect that from those who denigrate the flag. I ask the Minister whether he will undertake to obtain the information he says he does not have at his fingertips; whether he will consult with his fellow Minister as to what he cannot of his own right have access to; and whether he will explain to us what action he has put in train to ensure that people who owe money to the Commonwealth are in fact not handed out EMDGs.
—I have already indicated that those questions are misdirected to me. I ask Senator Bishop to put those questions on notice, directed to the appropriate Minister.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the Minister's answer in the Senate yesterday on the March quarter national accounts and the now three consecutive quarters of positive economic growth in Australia. Can the Minister expand on the data on profits and household savings published over the past few days; and does he consider the concept of gross operating surplus to be a `meaningless concept' when considering the ability of the corporate sector to make profits and invest?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I gave an answer—at some length, I thought—about this topic. It clearly was not understood on the other side because at the end of Question Time it became quite clear that Senator Short—who is, I take it, the Opposition's principal economic spokesman in the Senate—needed some enlightening on this issue. I understand that Senator Short chastised me for leaving the Senate chamber and not listening to his words of wisdom. But I did have the opportunity to read them later.

PARA.TAB: I am surprised that Senator Short—a refugee from the Treasury and from the House of Representatives, with long experience in those institutions, who was washed up in the Senate and has floated back and forth here from front bench to back bench and again to front bench—should say something like that. Let me say this: it is quite clear that Senator Short does not understand the difference between gross operating surplus and net operating surplus, and that he has not read the ABS description of how this is done. He does not understand that comparing quarterly data without seasonal adjustment is very misleading.
Almost every statement that Senator Short made in the Senate at the end of Question Time yesterday was factually incorrect or misleading. For example, Senator Short said:

ANSWER.PARA: As a measure of the ability of the corporate sector to make profits and to invest and reinvest, the gross operating surplus is a meaningless concept.

If Senator Short were to look at the statistics for the March quarter, he would see, for example—having said yesterday that the accurate concept was one of taking into account interest and tax paid by businesses—that interest and taxes have nothing whatsoever to do with the difference between these two measures. If he does not believe me, he should look at the ABS Concept, Sources and Methods for the national accounts. One has to compare apples with apples or pears with pears. Senator Short does not choose to do that for a variety of reasons, which I will come to in a minute.

PARA.TAB: If he had listened to my answer the previous day he would have learnt that reduced interest costs, of course, have in fact contributed to an increase in company profits in the March quarter. That would be fairly obvious, I would have thought, to most people. Company profits after interest costs rose more than company profits before interest, of course. Because members of the Opposition in the Senate and in the House of Representatives opposed every interest rate cut that this Government presided over—and the fact that that has increased company profits is an unpalatable thing to them—I suppose Senator Short indulges in this argument.

Senator Short went on yesterday to discover a decline in the net operating surplus from $25 billion to $18.9 billion, not noticing, apparently, that the fall occurred in the seasonally unadjusted data.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, we have to read it now, do we?
—Yes, I have to read some of this; I am not ashamed of that. I am trying to give the Senate some information about some misleading stuff which was put to the Senate yesterday.
—Why don't you make a statement about it after Question Time?
—One could go on. Senator Short chose to make a speech about this issue yesterday.

PARA.TAB: The other thing I want to draw the Senate's attention to is Senator Short's comments on savings. He does not use seasonally adjusted data and, therefore, gets it completely wrong. Despite what Senator Short claimed yesterday, the household savings ratio increased from 4.5 to 4.9 per cent in seasonally adjusted terms. That is pretty poor evidence for Senator Short's conclusion that savings have collapsed in this country. That is what he said in this place yesterday as the Opposition spokesman on finance—savings have collapsed in this country. He ought to look at the evidence on a seasonally adjusted basis, which any person knowing anything about this in fact does.

Senator Short's exercise yesterday is one which has undoubtedly provoked the answer which I have just given. But people should not approach these issues on the basis of total misinformation, whether intentionally or otherwise. Senator Short ought to know something about the position of the savings ratio in this country, for example, without misleading the Senate.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. QUESTION.PARA: . . . we are not talking about minor order characters in the play being incompetent, being negligent or being corrupt. We are talking about that incompetence and that negligence, at least, leading up to the highest levels of the Department, with implications that should be obvious so far as the responsibility of the Minister himself is concerned.
I am sure the Minister will remember it, Mr President. I contrast this statement with his answer yesterday when he said:

It is not a matter of blaming anyone; it is not a matter of wrongdoing by anyone; it is not a matter of any default or wrongdoing in the system such as should attract `responsibility' by anyone, let alone ministerial responsibility.

In view of these statements, are we to take it that the Minister believes that the doctrine of ministerial responsibility applies only to situations involving tax fraud and not to major business migration scams which bring Australia's international reputation into disrepute?

TALK.START.PARA: —The only thing we can take from all of that is that Senator Walters, once again, has demonstrated a total incapacity—with the utmost respect to Senator Walters—to understand the difference between her elbow and another part of her anatomy when it comes to the simplest concepts. The concept of ministerial responsibility is one that only gets started when one has some particular blameworthy event, whether it is a matter of misleading Parliament or it is a matter of some other form of wrongdoing or default that occurs in a ministerial office or in a department or so far as the Minister himself is concerned. In this particular instance there is nothing that can be so described.

PARA.TAB: The only matter in issue that has been in issue so far as I personally am concerned is my answer in this Parliament to Senator Bishop when I said I had no knowledge of a particular state of affairs. That has not been demonstrated to amount to a misleading of Parliament because all the evidence that has been the subject of merciless working over in this place for the last two weeks has not demonstrated anything other than the accuracy of that statement by me.

I did not mislead the Parliament; therefore, there was no wrongdoing by anyone and, therefore, no question of responsibility for what led me to lack that state of knowledge comes into issue when one is talking about ministerial responsibility. I am sorry if that is too many words in too short a space of time and too abstract and too complex for Senator Walters to appreciate. I do apologise, but that is what ministerial responsibility is all about: wrongful acts and the question of attribution of blame for them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question and it is a very obvious one. Obviously the Minister believes—and I should like him to give us his view—that there is one standard applied to him and another standard applied to everyone else.
—Just like you want in this chamber.

—I accept Senator Ray's contribution; it is the most useful one I can think of in the circumstances. I do not accept the principle of double standards. I fully accept my responsibility not to mislead this place, and I fully accept the responsibility that properly is attached to me for any act of wrongdoing on my behalf or for that for which I should reasonably assume responsibility. I do not seek to avoid that; it is just not appropriate, not relevant, to any of the facts, any of the matters, that are in issue in this case. Senator Walters ought to be acutely aware of that by now if she was not at the outset.

—Is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce aware of comments by the new Chief Executive of BHP, Mr John Prescott, that the company is not optimistic about the future of its steel business, given the increasingly competitive state of world steel markets over the past 10 years? Secondly, given that BHP management is flagging a further expansion of its mining and minerals exploration activities and a possible withdrawal from steel production, what action will the Government take to ensure the viability of the local steel industry and prevent further massive job losses in Wollongong and Newcastle?

—I have not seen any comments by Mr Prescott to the effect that BHP is not optimistic about the future of the steel business. I have seen a number of comments by Mr Prescott that he is not optimistic about the immediate future of the steel business because of the downturn in demand which has occurred as a result of the recession and the fact that that is continuing—or certainly was continuing as of last month.
—You got it right the first time; there is no question about that.

—I repeat: it was continuing as of last month. I do not know what the figure is for this month, and nor does Senator Crane. There probably is world over-capacity in steelmaking, and I guess it is more likely than not that some major steelmakers around the world will withdraw from steelmaking activities or reduce their capacity. But BHP certainly would not say, and could not say, I believe, that it is concerned about competition internationally. BHP Steel has handled competition internationally very well. Its competitiveness is indicated by the fact that, whereas six or seven years ago it exported very little steel, its steel exports last year were worth $1 billion and will probably be higher this year. I think that is a fair measure of its international competitiveness in terms of the products which it actually exports.

PARA.TAB: I do not contemplate a withdrawal by BHP from the steel industry at all. Certainly, that has never been suggested to me by BHP senior steel executives in the process of the regular discussions which we have. Maybe it will contract in some areas in terms of some products; maybe it will change, as steel technology increasingly moves to mini-mill production and so on in some areas. I am not contemplating the second part of the honourable senator's question because I do not believe it to be correct.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. What action will be taken by the Australian Securities Commission against companies with which the Prime Minister is involved for alleged breaches of the corporations law?

—It is my confident expectation that the Australian Securities Commission would act in a most independent way and in accordance with its normal practice and principles in this regard. As I was outlining in a short form yesterday in answer to questions from Senator Baume and Senator Bishop, companies are required by the corporations law to lodge an annual return with the Australian Securities Commission not later than seven months after the end of the company's financial year. There is a penalty of $500 for failure to lodge an annual return.

PARA.TAB: I am advised that the usual practice of the Securities Commission is first to issue a warning notice to companies which have failed to lodge a return. If this does not elicit a response, a penalty notice is issued before proceeding to court action against the company's secretary. I understand that failure to lodge within the statutory period is a common occurrence in relation to private companies and that in the 1990-91 financial year there were up to 150,000 companies which failed to lodge an annual return.

I also understand that the ASC has not yet issued any warning or penalty notices with respect to those failures but anticipates that it will begin to issue penalty notices at the end of this month. Because of the large number of notices which it will issue, the notices will continue to be issued over the next three to four months. In practice, companies which lodge their annual returns after the due date but before a penalty notice is issued are not subject to any fine.

In relation to the company Euphron Pty Ltd, in common with other companies which have failed to lodge an annual return for 1990-91, a penalty notice will be issued if an annual return is not lodged in the meantime. As far as the Pleuron company is concerned—I was asked questions about that also yesterday—I was asked whether the Prime Minister's family company was required to pay a $500 penalty when it filed its return late on 23 April. The answer to that is no. I guess that must be in accordance with that normal practice that where companies lodge their annual returns after the due date but before a penalty notice is issued they are not subject to any final penalty.

I believe that the Australian Securities Commission will act in a very even-handed and independent way with the companies with which the Prime Minister is associated. I would expect it to do the same in relation to those companies with which Dr Hewson and Mr Reith are associated. It may be of interest to honourable senators to know that Dr Hewson has been late in lodging the returns of his companies as listed in the parliamentary register for the past 3 years.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport. Can the Minister inform the Senate of the state of negotiations between Australian National and the National Rail Corporation in relation to AN assets and the role of Australian National in the future? Further, is the issue of job security being addressed by the parties involved? What is the role of the trade union movement in these discussions?

—The Minister for Land Transport, Mr Brown, has provided me with the following information. The Commonwealth and the States have agreed to establish the National Rail Corporation to operate interstate rail freight services on a commercial basis. This will involve the transfer of functions and associated assets from rail systems such as Australian National to the NRC. All shareholders agreed to this and each now has obligations to fulfil under this agreement. The Commonwealth intends to fully meet these obligations.

PARA.TAB: The Minister has advised that a subcommittee of the board of NRC recently met with commissioners of Australian National to discuss arrangements, including timing, for the transfer of functions and associated assets to ensure that the transition is as smooth as possible. The Government will shortly be considering the future arrangements for those elements of Australian National that will not be transferred to the NRC.

The Government appreciates that Australian National is facing a difficult period as these functions and assets are transferred. However, the Government is assisting by ensuring that the residual operations will be well placed to deal with the future. For example, the Government is providing $3.5m to upgrade the Port Augusta workshops to improve its competitiveness in bidding for NRC work. I was pleased, when meeting the delegation from Port Augusta last night, to provide it with this information.

The NRC will take on only those employees it requires for its own operations. Employees who do not take up employment with the NRC will remain with Australian National. It is a regrettable feature of government railways in Australia that they are overstaffed. In this regard, Australian National is no exception. Australian National has reduced its work force from around 13,000 in 1978 to around 5,000 today. I expect that this trend will continue. To facilitate this, the Government agreed late last year to enhanced redundancy packages for employees of Australian National.

Rail unions and the ACTU have been closely involved in the establishment of the NRC. In addition, Australian National's rail unions have had detailed discussions with Australian National and the Government about arrangements for employees made surplus, including as a result of the establishment of the NRC.

Senator Button—The Prime Minister has provided the following response to the honourable senator's question.
At the Australian Labor Advisory Council meeting on 28 May 1992, there was a brief discussion concerning the Superannuation Guarantee Levy and the National Wage Case.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 31 March, Senator Alston asked a question about the current estimate of what he described as `effective protection' in relation to a number of items in the tariff schedules—babies' jumpsuits, Hyundai passenger cars, tennis shoes, et cetera. For the purpose of this answer, I have assumed that he was trying to ask what was the effective rate of assistance. I have provided an answer which sets out the effective rate of assistance and the nominal rate of assistance for those various things. I suspect that the effective rate of assistance is a decreasingly valuable measure of assistance to industries. I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

The chief forms of protection for these goods are tariffs and quotas. Quotas only apply to goods in the textiles, clothing and footwear industries. Items of a good subject to quota may be imported either within quota, or out of quota. While items imported out of quota attract a lower tariff rate, they also incur a flat levy on each item. The flat levy is generally large compared to the import price, and so the rate of duty payable is much more than on goods imported within quota.

Since import prices can vary over a wide range, rates of assistance expressed as a percentage of purchase price can be misleading where imports take place without a quota. Export facilitation and import credit schemes also provide protection to the passenger motor vehicle and textile, clothing and footwear industries, respectively. However, this assistance cannot be allocated to single products. Furthermore, effective rates of assistance (ERAs) are calculated as averages over industries, and do not apply to particular products in multi-product industries. Effective rates of assistance measure the net assistance to an industry's value added. Net assistance includes assistance to output and value adding factors, and the effect of government interventions (eg tariffs, excise taxes and input subsidies) on input costs.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: United Nations Conference on Environment and Development

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night when we were debating the Appropriation Bills, Senator Brownhill asked me a question relating to the cost of the Australian Commonwealth and State delegation to the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development. I undertook to give Senator Brownhill a response to that question as soon as I could. I now have that information available. I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
Final costs will not be known until after the Conference.
Minister and their staff will not be in Rio for the full two week period.

Several members of the delegation are officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade from missions in Brasilia, the United Nations in New York and the United Nations Geneva. Most of the support staff are from Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade missions in South America. The costs of attendance of these staff will be lower than the costs of Canberra based staff.
The cost of establishing and maintaining two delegation officers in Rio De Janeiro, one at the hotel at which the Australian delegation is staying and one at the Conference Centre, is $88,150.

The United Nations conference on Environment and Development is probably the most important event of its nature ever convened. Between 20,000 and 30,000 representatives, including some 130 heads of Government, are expected to attend.

The conference is undeniably an expensive exercise and the Government has been conscious of the costs in preparing for its participation. However the issues to be considered at the conference are of great consequence to Australia, touching on nearly every aspect of our social and economic life.

Australia's delegation compares favourably to delegations from nations of a similar population and level of economic development. Sweden, Finland and New Zealand, to give just three examples, are, on a per capita basis, sending much larger delegations.

Senator O'Chee claims that the preparatory conferences held before the conference should have "nutted out the details of the conference agenda". However important elements of Agenda 21 relating to funding, the atmosphere and technology transfer have yet to be finalised. Also, although the text of the Rio declaration was agreed at the final preparatory committee meeting, there is a very real chance that parties at the conference may seek to have the text reopened. It is extremely important under these circumstances for Australia to be represented by a delegation with expertise in the areas open for debate.

The delegation has 42 members and six support staff. The 42 members include four Ministers, three Federal and one State, four ministerial staff, the Shadow Minister for sustainable Development and Environment, and five non Government organisation representatives, one represented by Environment NGOS, two by the Business Council of Australia, one by ACFOA and one by the ACTU. The other 28 delegates represent the States (three) Local Government (one) six Federal Government Departments and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission.

Those answers have been provided to Senator Walters. I seek leave to incorporate them in Hansard.
Leave granted.
