SPEECH.PARA: RESPONSES TO SENATOR WALTER'S QUESTIONS
(A) Departmental letter of 3 February 1989 to State/Territory Departments—removal of clause from draft agreement
The clause in question read:

"where a private patient after admission wishes to become a public patient such a change will take effect from the patient's date of admission. A private patient may only become a public patient where he has obtained the consent of his treating medical practitioner;
Background

The clause was inserted in the draft in view of the Commonwealth's concern to avoid manipulation of the system by patients/doctors where patients were admitted for one or two days as private to allow the doctor to treat the patient in a private capacity and raise fee for service. The patient would then seek reclassification to public status. The end result would be the patient needing to meet, say $100-200, in lieu of private insurance contributions.

States indicated that they had the capacity to control this abuse and could monitor the situation to ensure that it would not occur. The Commonwealth accepted that given these circumstances there was no need for such a clause in the draft agreement.
(B) Correspondence with Hon J White, Tas Minister for Health—Patient election procedures
The Commonwealth took no further specific action as its understanding was that appropriate corrective action was taken by Tasmania.

The Department has no current complaints from patients or private health funds (who brought the matter to the Department's attention at the time given the effect on their benefit payouts). It was the Department's understanding, and still is, that the Private Funds did not have a continuing major concern.

While the Department has no specific evidence of continuing problems in Tasmania the Department intends raising the issue of patient election procedures with all States as part of the next round of meetings of Commonwealth/State Standing Committees on Medicare Agreements.
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH, HOUSING AND COMMUNITY SERVICES

PARA.TAB: Senator Walters asked (Hansard 3275) the cost of the convenience advertising account and the cost and arrangements made with venues for placement of advertising.

The convenience advertising strategy is used in the National AIDS Campaign (NAC) and involves the placement of small poster advertisements in toilets (or `conveniences') in order to reach specific audiences with education messages.

The convenience advertising strategy has been utilised in most of the major national HIV/AIDS education campaigns. These include those campaigns targeting gay and bisexual men, young heterosexuals, women, intravenous drug users, Aborigines and travellers. Different design and placement strategies have been used to meet particular campaign objectives.
The account is conducted through the Government Advertising Service and the master print placement agency.

The convenience advertising strategy is implemented through a company external to the Department, Convenience Advertising Australia Pty Ltd. Convenience messages are placed by securing sites on the back of toilet entrances and cubicle doors, as well as above urinals and hand driers. Advertisements in toilet stalls have more detailed messages whereas those advertisements outside toilet stalls are more visual in character. For each campaign, venues and sites are identified and selected on the basis of their potential to reach identified target groups.

Sites are secured by way of licence rental agreements between the venues and Convenience Advertising Australia Pty Ltd. Advertisements are placed in a plastic cover with high resistance to damage. Maintenance is conducted regularly by Convenience Advertising. A detailed site list is given at Attachment A.
The NAC has used convenience advertising as a strategy since December 1988, both as part of an integrated campaign strategy and for general education messages in a variety of venues.

More recently, the Department undertook a review of the agency which manages the medium on behalf of the Department. In a tendering process with four contenders, Convenience Advertising was the successful agency. It was chosen as the only company which could offer national coverage; its rates also offered the best value for money.
The National AIDS Campaign has utilised advertising as an HIV/AIDS communications medium in different venues and facilities for specific types of clientele.

The convenience advertising strategy has been used to reach specific target audiences in relevant settings, such as entertainment and gay venues, campus buildings, women's refuges and travel venues such as airports, hotels and hostels.
The placement of messages within `conveniences' also allows for more direct and specific communication messages suited for appropriate audiences.

The monthly cost of rental to the Department per site is $9.60. This includes placement, maintenance and replacement if necessary, plus a small contribution to the venue ($1.00 per site). Total site numbers are within the range of 5,000 to 7,000 to take into account venue closures and site acquisitions. The total cost for convenience advertising in the 1991-92 financial year is $725 294.30.

Small scale evaluations of the medium took place in 1989 and 1990. These indicated that level of exposure to and recall of advertisements is high and that the messages do reach those more at risk because of their practices.

A major evaluation of the medium is currently being conducted by the research company AGB Australia, which was chosen through a process of selective tender. The results of this evaluation will be available later this year.

The purpose of the evaluation is to assess the effectiveness of the convenience advertising strategy using the Travellers campaign as a focus. Elements of the evaluation task will include assessment of placement, reach, impact, and effectiveness.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)repudiates the repeated claims by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade that the exemption provisions of the Freedom of Information Act provide grounds for not producing documents to a House of the Parliament in relation to a matter of great public interest involving the proper conduct of government and the accountability of Ministers to the Parliament;

(2)calls upon the Minister to respond properly to the questions put to him in the Senate and to produce to the Senate by 12 noon tomorrow, 4 June, all relevant documents to enable the Senate to make a judgment on this matter; and
(3)resolves that the serious issues involved in the Minister's contentions be referred to the Standing Orders Committee for consideration and urgent report back to the Senate.

Senator Evans has refused on at least five occasions during the last two weeks to supply documents to the Senate on the grounds that he must first assess their confidentiality against FOI criteria—twice in Senate Question Time of 26 May 1992, once on 27 May, twice two days ago, once yesterday and once again today.

PARA.TAB: I have sought legal advice as to whether the Minister is entitled to withhold documents from the Senate subject to FOI criteria. This advice has suggested that there are no grounds for Senator Evans's actions. According to the advice, which I will seek to table in due course, the Freedom of Information Act does not have and does not contain anything which suggests that it has any application to the presentation of documents to the Senate by Ministers, whether in response to orders of the Senate for the production of documents or by ministerial decision in the absence of such orders. Not only this, but the advice from the Clerk of the Senate is that for Senator Evans to continue to evade the Senate's scrutiny under the guise of the Freedom of Information Act would `obviously be a very significant precedent' and that the argument for doing so would be `surprising'.

There can be little doubt that Senator Evans, as a silk of sorts, is aware of what is involved in these propositions, which, of course, clearly begs the question of what he has to hide in this matter. We view it as a matter of the utmost seriousness. This Government has had a long history of seeking to restrict access to public information. Perhaps the greatest irony of all is that for many years Senator Evans has been the great champion of the Bill of Rights; someone who, when not grandstanding about constitutional reform and rabbiting on about safeguarding democracy, has sought to build a reputation by espousing civil liberties propositions and, in particular, advancing the cause of freedom of information.

One only has to hark back to those days when Senator Evans was constantly springing to the defence of his mentor, the then Senator Murphy, later Mr Justice Murphy, seeking to uphold the supremacy of the Parliament, making a commitment to democratic ideals and, of course, furthering the people's right to know.

It therefore has to be a matter of great seriousness that we have in this instance a Minister of the Crown—a self-proclaimed academic world champion when it comes to an understanding of the law, and someone who is constantly seeking to remind us of how much he knows and what vast knowledge he has of all legal and obtuse propositions relating to civil liberties—suddenly coming in here and advancing what is clearly an intellectually dishonest proposition.

There is nothing whatever in any history of the Senate or in any academic writings to suggest that Senator Evans has the power to invoke the Freedom of Information Act in the way that he has been seeking to do. Indeed, not only would this be a very significant precedent if it were to get off the ground; it is also little more than an outrageous ambit claim. I suggest that it is utterly hypocritical. Indeed, I am sure that if we gave Senator Evans the chance, he would recite every High Court decision relating to civil liberties and particularly freedom of information.

Senator Evans knows full well that this is an entirely novel and juridically dishonest proposition. It goes to matters of the highest import. Quite clearly, the governance of the nation depends upon people not only having access to the final decision but also in many instances having the power to approach the Parliament and to seek further information. To suggest that somehow the elected representatives of the people can be constrained in the information they might seek by resolution of the Parliament by someone who simply invokes a novel proposition that somehow he is bound by freedom of information constraints or other statutory secrecy propositions is utterly intellectually dishonest.

I want to go back over some of Senator Evans's recent answers to show just how he has been attempting to get this claim off the ground in recent times. On 27 May, he was asked by Senator Hill about a file note of a conversation between the Minister's adviser and a departmental officer. The Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday I offered Senator Hill the opportunity to look at the file note in question on a confidential basis, pending an opportunity for me in turn to evaluate it for its releasability under FOI criteria.

Putting to one side the nonsense proposition that somehow Senator Hill should have accepted an opportunity to look at a file note on a confidential basis—lord knows what is meant to follow from that—would he have been entitled to communicate its contents to anyone or is he struck mute and therefore crippled by having been so silly as to approach the Minister and look at something on a confidential basis?

PARA.TAB: Putting that proposition aside, on what basis does the Minister claim that it is a matter for him to evaluate a document for its releasability under FOI criteria? If the Minister wants to stand up here, puff out his chest and say, `I am not showing you anything', let him do it. If he is going to say, `I am impressed by FOI criteria; I think that I now ought to follow those in guiding me as to what I release', let him do that. But no-one else has ever done that before. I suggest that if he is about to start doing that, we ought to ask ourselves a very serious question: why is he resorting to this tactic and stratagem at this stage? It is simply a desperate and spurious defence by a desperate Minister to ensure that as little as possible is made available to this Senate.

We have been very patient for some days in waiting for Senator Evans to finally come forward with a schedule of documents. What he was so gracious as to suggest at the start of Question Time was that he hoped to have this material available tomorrow. What is he really trying to do? We all know what he is trying to do. He is going to try to trot it out late in the afternoon and expect that we will be as slack as he is. He will bring it out at four o'clock. Nothing gets done after four o'clock on the last sitting day. Not only can one not be reading the papers but one certainly cannot be ringing Washington or approaching anyone else. One sits on one's hands, goes to sleep, and gets out of the place as quickly as one can.

So the strategy is obvious: he is hoping that somehow or other he can stall this so that there is no opportunity for parliamentary debate or scrutiny. That, in itself, I would have thought was unforgivable. But, even if we are graced with this schedule, Senator Evans is setting himself up to be able to say, `Well, here you are; I have excised all the relevant parts because I somehow claim that I am entitled to do this under FOI'.

Let us be perfectly clear: at the end of the day the Minister does not have to give us a thing. And if he chooses not to give us anything or to give us just a little, that is his decision and he will wear it, and be judged accordingly. But do not let him stand up here and pretend that somehow he is entitled to shelter behind statutory provisions—because he is not. Yet that is the defence he has been trying to mount in recent days. Again, he says:

SPEECH.PARA: I was giving him—
Senator Hill—
an opportunity to take a look at it—
the document—

before I had had time to look at it for reviewability on FOI grounds. Since yesterday I have had time to review the document on FOI grounds and I am perfectly happy now to table an abbreviated version of that document.
On 26 May—here we go again:
It may be appropriate to release the documents on FOI or other grounds;

That is true, particularly if the Minister is considering it in the context of an FOI request. But that has nothing to do with whether he hands over documents sought by members of the Opposition in the Senate. It is simply not open to the Minister to say, `I am considering them on FOI grounds', unless by that he means, `I am going to take it upon myself to impose FOI grounds on what is otherwise clearly unfettered ministerial responsibility'.

PARA.TAB: But the Minister should not be so devious as to somehow claim that he is constrained by FOI or other criteria. On 1 June, what we have is this:

SPEECH.PARA: I have already said to the Senate that my Department is presently actively involved in assessing documents by reference to FOI criteria.

Why should it be? Has the Minister asked them to do it? Has he said to them, `I have decided that nothing that does not meet FOI criteria ought to be released' or is he somehow pretending to them that they have to abide by FOI guidelines? We know that is a nonsense proposition. There is absolutely nothing in the FOI Act that in the slightest bears on the Minister's ability to release documents in this place—indeed, quite the contrary.

PARA.TAB: The Parliamentary Privileges Act of 1987, I would have thought, makes it crystal clear that he is not constrained in any way whatsoever, and the only possible way in which he might be is if there is an express statutory provision or, by necessary implication, he has to come to the conclusion that the Parliament intended to constrain him in that way. But I defy the Minister to refer us to any such proposition.
On 1 June again, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: These documents will be in the public domain as soon as my Department has had an opportunity to review it against FOI criteria.
Again, I make the same comment. On 2 June—and this is probably the high-water mark—he said:

I am constrained in what I can say about particular applications because of the secrecy provisions of the Australian Trade Commission Act and the Freedom of Information Act. I have no discretion to release documentation or, for that matter, any detailed information derived from such documentation concerning the business affairs of another person without first giving that person the opportunity to put a case. . .
On the same day, he said:

I am unable to say, consistently with the confidentiality provisions that govern this. Subject to Multiplex itself being prepared to release it, I am not in a position to say who the other members of the group were. But that is something in respect of which I think there is an FOI application,

Well so what! I am not sure that the Minister is the appropriate officer to be making the FOI decision. If the responsible officer decides that all those many restraints that operate in that legislation are sufficient to restrict the Minister's ability to make the document available, that is one thing. But that has nothing whatsoever to do with the Minister's power to respond fully to questions or requests or, indeed, demands by way of resolution of this chamber. If he chooses to do nothing, he does nothing but he says so explicitly on that basis. He does not hide behind this fiction that somehow we are now about to create a whole new set of defences which, in a sense, imply that the FOI Act governs the releasability of documents in the chamber—because it clearly does not.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would have been very nice if you had given us notice. Courtesy is not what you lot are very good at.

—I can assure Senator Evans that we are not here complaining about matters of courtesy. I wish to read a portion of the opinion before I seek leave to table it, because it really goes to the heart of the matter. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Freedom of Information Act does not have, and does not contain anything which suggests that it has, any application to the presentation of documents to the Senate by ministers . . . It might be argued that ministers could use the grounds for non-disclosure contained in the Freedom of Information Act as grounds on which they would claim a privilege against the disclosure of documents to a House of the Parliament. I am unaware of any such argument being explicitly advanced by a minister. It would be a most surprising argument, because, as you know, the grounds for non-disclosure under the act are numerous and broad, and it has not hitherto been asserted that they should have any application to the Houses. It would obviously be a very significant precedent for a minister to claim that the grounds contained in the act are grounds for refusing to produce documents to a House of the Parliament, and it would obviously be a highly significant concession if either House in any way conceded such a precedent.

The Clerk is not given to making off the cuff pontifications, in marked contradistinction to the Minister on the other side of the chamber. The Clerk has, I think, in very cautious and reasoned terms, spelt out an issue of the highest importance, and that is the supremacy of the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where has the Clerk done that?
—In the opinion which I will now table.
—It is normal courtesy to show it to the other side.
—I have been reading from it for the last three minutes, so Senator Evans should not be taken by surprise. I seek leave to table the document.
—Are you tabling the whole lot?
—Yes, I will table the whole lot. I seek leave to table the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I look forward in anxious anticipation to the way in which the Minister will respond to this matter. At the end of the day, if he says that there are many and varied defences in the freedom of information legislation which he regards as appropriate in this case, let him say so, but let it also be crystal clear that he is not bound by that legislation.

PARA.TAB: If he chooses to hide behind those provisions, the irresistible conclusion must be that he is doing it because he does not want to disclose to the Parliament that which he has the power to disclose to the Parliament. If that is so, we are entitled on this side—and, I would have thought, in the wider community—to assume that this whole teeth dragging exercise is simply going to go on and on, that Senator Evans is going to be dragged screaming into the public domain and that documents which we are entitled to will, one way or another, find their way into the public arena.

Documents should not have to be dragged out in this manner. It is quite specious when there is not a request made subject to FOI—and even if there is—to even refer to freedom of information in responding to a request from this chamber. If the Minister wants to advance the proposition that somehow there are fetters on the power of the Parliament, let me remind him of what the Senate itself resolved in 1975. It resolved:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the Senate affirms that it possesses the powers and privileges of the House of Commons as conferred by section 49 of the Constitution and has the power to summon persons to answer questions and produce documents, files and papers.

(2) That, subject to the determination of all just and proper claims of privilege which may be made by persons summoned, it is the obligation of all such persons to answer questions and produce documents.

That matter has been tested quite exhaustively in recent times in relation, again, to efforts by this Government to somehow claim that the National Crime Authority Act of 1984 constrains a parliamentary committee's power to seek documents from the National Crime Authority. The advice that has been given and tabled in this chamber on several occasions makes it clear that there are no such constraints.

PARA.TAB: Indeed, an opinion of the Solicitor-General conceded that a general statutory secrecy provision does not apply to inquiries by the Houses or their committees unless the provision in question is so framed as to have such an application. So the same principle clearly applies here.

Unless the Minister is able to point to some specific provision that limits the power of the Senate, the power of the Minister, the power of the Government, to provide information requested, then there is no basis on which he can refuse to do that. Indeed, we would ultimately welcome that matter being tested on the floor of the chamber.

But to voluntarily offer to disclose certain documents but withhold others because of some gratuitous reference to statutory provisions is not something that even a bush lawyer would seriously advance as a proposition to this chamber. If the world's greatest academic lawyer—on a self-assessment basis, I hasten to add—is to seriously try to argue that case, then we will be very interested in responding to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Alston's motion and the speech that went with it are a combination of something that is belated, premature and misguided—simultaneously.
—You oxymoron.
—Not an oxymoron; that is saying the same thing twice. Belated and premature and misguided—
—It is a stark and precise contradiction in terms.
—Okay. Well, you listen to what I am saying.
—Look it up in the dictionary.
—All right, I will. It is belated because on about half a dozen occasions—and they have all been read out, I think, with loving care by Senator Alston—
—What you had in mind was tautology.

—That is right, thank you. On about half a dozen occasions I have referred to FOI criteria as being the kind of criteria that I am prepared to apply in determining whether particular documents should be released. And for this issue to be raised now, after so many days of referring in those terms, without seeking clarification as to what I meant and as to whether I was relying explicitly on the terms of the FOI statute, is to be, simply, belated.

PARA.TAB: The speech—together with the motion that it goes with—is also premature because it anticipates a response from me over the next day or so and assumes a particular kind of response. It assumes the application by me of certain specific criteria, all of which assumptions are simply without any foundation until you have actually seen what it is that I am proposing to produce.

It is misguided because the whole intellectual apparatus—if I can dignify it with that description—on which Senator Alston erects his case is based, really, on a false premise. He would have clearly established that it was a false premise days ago if he had asked me a direct question as to whether, when referring to the FOI in general terms, as I have on a number of occasions, I really mean to be taken as calling in aid all the explicit provisions and all the specific processes that are associated with the FOI Act.

I do not for a moment claim, and I never have claimed, other than by shorthand inference, that the FOI Act is directly, literally, fully applicable to the position of a Minister producing documents in response to a request in the Senate. What I have simply been saying is that there are a number of confidentiality criteria that are appropriately applied in circumstances that I will come to in a moment, in accordance with conventions that I will come to in a moment and proper principles that I will come to in a moment.

There are a number of confidentiality criteria that are properly applied. A number of those criteria are set out in the FOI Act, but the FOI Act does not purport to be any kind of statement, either exhaustive or sharply defined, of what executive privilege properly can be claimed in these sorts of situations. It is a general guide to the kinds of things about which it is reasonable, or in respect of which it is reasonable, for governments to use as guidelines in responding to requests for information.

FOI itself does not impose, except in very specific and limited cases, bars to the disclosure of information. It simply establishes guidelines against which, if a government is so minded, it can refuse to disclose information.

FOI legislation is at best a rough guide to the kinds of confidentiality considerations that apply. I have never claimed it to be more than that. If I had been asked about it at any stage in the last ten days, I would have answered in those terms.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why have you chosen to mislead?

—I have not been asked that. All I have said, and I have said it on a number of occasions, is that I have been requested to supply to the Senate all the documents in the Department's possession relating to Symons and the Marshall Islands affair. I have said that I will do so to the extent that I reasonably can, having regard to proper confidentiality criteria. That is exactly what I propose to do. I was simply using `FOI' as convenient shorthand for proper confidentiality criteria.

PARA.TAB: What are the kinds of criteria that it is appropriate to apply in these cases? I will give some examples. In the first place, there are some instances where there is an explicit statutory prohibition on the disclosure of certain information, certainly without going through a particular defined statutory process. The EMDG Act is one such example. When one is looking at statutory secrecy requirements of that kind, it is always a matter to determine the way in which those statutory secrecy provisions interrelate to the particular language in the FOI Act. As I recall, section 38 of the FOI Act says that in certain instances the FOI Act's access provisions override the secrecy provisions that exist elsewhere. It is a matter of looking at the two bits of statutory language together.

It is in that context that I was referring to both the FOI Act and the EMDG Act. That is one of the things that I have not yet had time to look up. In its application to the EMDG documentation, I have not yet received all the documentation from Austrade, as it turns out, and that is one of the things to which I will have to have regard in the next day or so when working out what it is permissible for me to table in the Parliament. I know the general principle of commercial confidentiality and the disclosure of information specifically supplied under that legislation, but I have to look at the applicability of that principle in relation to each bit of paper on Austrade's files in relation to all these various matters. That is one kind of confidentiality issue about which I do not believe there can be any reasonable dispute.

Secondly, I have an obvious responsibility, which I do not propose to resile from in any way, to protect Australia's international interests where they are in any way put at risk by the disclosure of particular information. Whether such a claim can reasonably be made out is always a matter for close analysis and assessment in each case, but where I believe that such a claim can reasonably be made out I will rely upon that as a ground for non-disclosure. I am giving notice of that now. I do not know whether any particular documents or any data or any part of any of the documents in issue here do properly give rise to that claim. That is another one of the things I obviously have to look at.

Again, I have to have regard to the proper principles governing the conduct of court proceedings and not prejudice the position of any litigant, particularly any criminal defendant in court proceedings. It does not matter whether such court proceedings are applying in this country or elsewhere; it is a matter of proper, reasonable principles being appropriate and applicable to the situation. That obviously will be a relevant consideration in relation to material that I have described in general terms as consular material bearing upon the particular conduct of this court case.

Again, there are questions of personal privacy that can involve entirely personal matters—family matters and things of that kind—that crop up in the course of this documentation that do not bear upon any matter of public affairs or legitimate public interest but do involve invasion of the privacy of the individual concerned. It is perfectly appropriate that those sorts of considerations be taken into account. There are also questions of commercial confidentiality that are relevant so far as the commercial affairs of companies, particularly in relation to current matters, are concerned.

They are the kinds of issues. I do not state them in any exhaustive way; I do not state them in any comprehensive way. I do not state them in anything other than an illustrative way. They are legitimate things to which one can have regard. But these are the sorts of things to which one can have regard as being acknowledged over and over again in the affairs of this nation and in the affairs of the respective Houses of Parliament. There is an excellent discussion of this whole matter in the sixth edition of Odgers, at pages 906 and following, governing among other things an extended saga in which I was personally involved in 1982 in endeavouring to extract some documents from the then Government on matters relating to tax avoidance. I was met there with some very conspicuous obstruction by the government of the day—or what I regarded as obstruction. Whether I would so regard it now depends on all the circumstances of the case. The point is that everything depends on the particular circumstances of the case.

I draw the attention of honourable senators to those pages of Odgers to see for themselves the kinds of arguments, the kinds of criteria, that have been argued out in this place in recent memory so far as some honourable senators are concerned. I am sure this particular saga is engraved on Senator Walters's mind; it is certainly engraved on Senator Durack's mind and it is certainly engraved on mine. Do not let us have any nonsense about this. A properly argued case was put on that occasion. I was met with arguments coming from the Government which I did not on that occasion accept. But for those opposite to now be arguing that there is any absolute responsibility—I am not sure that they are—on the government of the day to produce documents does not sit very easily with their behaviour on that occasion and I draw that to their close attention.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are conceding FOI is irrelevant; you are relying on a series of other criteria. Is that right?

—They are not very well defined; they are considerations of executive privilege in relation to matters for which confidentiality can properly be claimed. It is a matter for argument in each case as to whether confidentiality is properly claimed.
—But they are utterly independent of FOI?

—I have already said that. Do not engage in tedious repetition. I have not called in aid the FOI Act and said that I am explicitly bound to follow the criteria or the process in the FOI Act. I have used the FOI Act simply as a shorthand way of referring to the kind of confidentiality criteria which are in issue. Until today, Senator Alston has not turned a hair. It is entirely belated for him to raise the issue in this way. If he had concerns about this, it would have been very helpful if he had put them on record much earlier.

PARA.TAB: I will indicate the kind of criteria which have been accepted by Senator Alston's side of politics in the past as appropriate for a government to take into account when confronting some request or purported direction for the tabling of papers. I refer to a passage at page 912 of the sixth edition of Odgers. It is an extract from a statement by a Minister in the Tasmanian House of Assembly. The significance of it in Federal terms is that, speaking in the House of Representatives on 31 October 1967, the then Prime Minister, Mr Holt, stated that he agreed with that Tasmanian statement and said that it might well be adopted as sound policy in the House of Representatives in the Australian Parliament. In relevant part the passage reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Considerations of public policy and a due regard for the interests of the State may require the Minister to withhold information either sought for or ordered to be returned. Were it otherwise, it would be impossible to carry on the Government with safety and honour. To disclose certain information may endanger the interests of the State or of individuals whose conduct or affairs are not in question, and to disclose information given in confidence would be dishonourable and, moreover, would stop any more information being given in confidence. The Minister concerned must of necessity take responsibility for decisions on these matters and so long as the House gives him its confidence its confidence must extend to such decisions. The same principles which apply to given information to the House apply to Select Committees. . .

Those are some of the general principles which are there laid out. The course of decision and discussion, as I have said, on some other matters that are also described in these pages is very instructive. I did not understand Senator Alston to be making any absolute claim. Perhaps if he were listening he would confirm what I am saying. If Senator Alston would do me the courtesy of listening to me it might be helpful. He has not shown me any other courtesy in the course of today, so I suppose it would be asking too much for him to break his duck at this stage. It is my understanding from what Senator Alston has said that he does readily accede to the proposition that I cannot be compelled to disclose certain information in respect of which I claim confidentiality, that I simply—as I understood Senator Alston to say in general terms—have to accept the political responsibility for doing so.

PARA.TAB: I simply say to the extent that I do claim confidentiality in relation to any documents in part or whole—and I have not made any such decision about any document at this stage—then I will accept the political responsibility for doing so. But I do have other responsibilities as a member of this Government to my country and to individuals and to businesses which may be unjustly calumniated or whose interests may be put at risk by the disclosure of certain information.

TALK.START.PARA: —And to the Senate.

—I accept that I have responsibilities to disclose as much information as I reasonably can, having proper regard to proper and legitimate principles of confidentiality of the kind that I have mentioned. It was because of my willingness to have my bona fides tested in relation to the particular minute which has occupied so much attention in recent times that I not only tabled the document with one sentence omitted—which had to do incidentally with a matter of private family confidentiality so far as the individual was concerned—but I also actually offered Senator Hill the opportunity to look at the document to satisfy himself that the particular sentence that had been blacked out was of a character which did not go to a matter of public affairs but to a legitimate matter of confidentiality. He indicated that he was uninterested in any such opportunity. I noted that. Fair enough; if that is the way he wants to respond, that is fine. But do not call into account my bona fides when I try to wrestle with the very difficult and sensitive responsibilities that I have, on the one hand, to the Senate and to the public interest to put as much of this material down as I reasonably can but, on the other hand, to my country and to other individuals and interests that might be prejudiced by unreasonable disclosure. It is always a difficult task in executive government to strike that particular balance, to do it properly. I will do my best to do so, I will do so with honesty and integrity, and I hope my bona fides will not be calumniated by motions of this kind without proper ground in the future.

PARA.TAB: So far as the timing of this is concerned, I simply have not yet had the time to work through the documents, to think about and apply the principles about which I have been talking today to each particular document, to each part of the document. Quite a significant stack of documents has by now accumulated, as I acknowledged last week, and it has just been impossible to go through them in the time available. At best, my Department's evaluation of this material which it has given me—most of it, not all of it so far—yesterday afternoon is a guide for the exercise of my judgment. I have asked it to have regard to the sorts of principles that are set out in the FOI legislation. I have not said it is a matter of being strictly bound by its provisions, because I frankly and fully acknowledge that it is not a matter of being strictly bound by it; it is a matter of applying the kinds of principles to which I refer.

So this motion, brought on without any advance knowledge, in breach of all courtesies of this place, is not something that I believe the Senate should accede to at this point. I have given an explanation of my position. I hope that the Australian Democrats in particular will appreciate and understand the sincerity with which I have put my position. I am not trying to diddle anybody. I am not trying in any way to avoid proper responsibilities in this case. I do have some other serious responsibilities as well as those simply to dump everything on the table. I will try to exercise those responsibilities as expeditiously as I possibly can. I will certainly endeavour to meet the deadline that is being suggested or proposed, but I cannot absolutely guarantee at this stage that I will be able to. I will try but I cannot guarantee it; I will do my best. I will certainly do my best to disclose as much information as I possibly can, consistent only with the kinds of limitations which I described.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems to me that there are a couple of issues here that need to be teased out. As the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) has said—and I was pleased to hear him say it—the Freedom of Information Act does not apply literally to the question of the revelation of information by a Minister in this place. That seems to me to answer the first point which has been raised by the Opposition in putting forward this motion.

PARA.TAB: However, the Minister then went on to say on several occasions that nonetheless he was applying the provisions of the FOI legislation to the information which was sought from him. We would accept—and I am sure the Opposition would also accept—that all information is not to be revealed in this place. The Minister has just outlined that there are a variety of circumstances under which information is not to be revealed. Equally, the Minister must accept that nowhere has the Senate said that the provisions which surround the release of information within the FOI legislation are the appropriate provisions to be used in this place.

The sections which he read from Odgers were very, very general. They certainly did not contain any specific criteria by which that would be measured. I certainly formed the impression, on those several occasions on which he invoked the FOI criteria in answer to a question, that he was in fact literally using those criteria as the criteria which were appropriate in this place. It seems to me that that is a matter to be determined by the Senate. It is not a matter to be determined by a Minister. If he were simply using it as shorthand, he should have made it quite explicit that it was shorthand for a set of criteria which were not exhaustively to be applied but were simply a guide.

Perhaps a matter which this Senate needs to determine is what criteria should guide a Minister in relation to releasing information. Perhaps the provisions within the FOI legislation are appropriate, but it certainly has not been determined by the Senate. Therefore, I think the second leg of what the Opposition has put up does stand. We must accept what the Minister has said; that literally the law does not apply within the Senate. Nonetheless, it is for the Senate to determine the appropriate criteria by which information is to be guarded, if it is not to be released as a consequence of a question in this place.

As to the time that has been set within this motion of 12 noon tomorrow, I certainly accept what the Minister has said—that he would seek to provide the information at that time. But I do think that in the replies given by the Minister there is an implication—a dangerous one if it is allowed to stand unchallenged—that the FOI provisions are perhaps appropriate ones. That is to be determined by the Senate, not by the Minister, and it should not be allowed to pass into history so that it becomes a precedent for Ministers seeking guidance in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coulter has taken up very reasonably in his speech all of the concerns that we in the Opposition have on this matter and which Senator Alston has introduced; that is, the three matters which are a part of this motion. Senator Evans in his speech did all that he could to back away from any possibility that he was altering the precedents on the answering of questions or the providing of documents in the Senate by Ministers. Indeed, he was doing everything he could in his speech to support the Standing Orders of the Senate. He did not in any way dispute the advice tabled by the Clerk of the Senate and he has himself, as a Minister, referred to various pages of Odgers' Australian Senate Practice to try to consolidate the fact that he does not want to set any precedent or go to any new element in the procedures of the Senate. Those kinds of assurances are welcome today, but they were not made at any point during the last several weeks.
—I wasn't asked about them. I was not asked once on that subject.

—But I say to the Minister that there were instances of Senator Evans referring to the Freedom of Information Act and the criteria under that Act as the ones that would literally guide him. He now says `not literally', and also he has backed away from any assumption or claim that there is any requirement of limitation by the Freedom of Information Act upon any Minister or, indeed, anyone in the Senate.

PARA.TAB: The motion moved by Senator Alston can be readily accepted by the Senate to make sure that there is no ambiguity in the procedures of the Senate and in the requirements of the Senate of this Minister. I accept his genuine assurance that he will bring the documents that we have been asking for by noon tomorrow, because it is the last sitting day on which we can ask questions of this Minister on a matter of public importance. We will see where we are by noon tomorrow and in Question Time or any subsequent debate which might follow tomorrow.

With regard to the reference to the Standing Orders committee, I mention for the first time in this debate standing orders 72, 73 and 74 in chapter 11 of our Senate Standing Orders relating to questions seeking information. I refer also to standing order 164 which refers to the tabling of documents and orders for the production of documents in chapter 26 of the Standing Orders. Given the statements made by the Minister in recent days, certainly any senator could interpret that he was seeking to make a precedent and to limit what a Minister's answer or tabling of documents would be in relation to these Standing Orders that I have just cited. That would be most improper. It is not the right of any one senator or any one Minister to subtract from or add to the Standing Orders of the Senate and it is for that reason that any such matter ought to be referred to the appropriate body, the Standing Orders committee, for consideration and report.

I do not need to go further on any of the three matters in the motion. They have been addressed in a very parallel way by Senator Coulter on behalf of the Democrats and Senator Alston, who moved this motion on behalf of the Opposition. I would add that to pass this motion in all three parts would not offend the Minister's speech here today, but would in fact underline the kinds of assurances which he has given to us in response.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us make clear what has been said by Senator Evans. Simply, what he has said here today, and what he has been saying all through his answers to the various questions which have been put, is that there is a concept of confidentiality, and that this Senate itself has adopted the position of saying that there are certain things which should not be revealed.

PARA.TAB: It is quite clear that if Senator Evans came in with the file that is looked for there may or may not be—and that is still to be established—matters of confidentiality which would affect other people. That is a concept that this Senate and the people now in it have adopted. If we go back to 10 May 1990 when Senator Tate, who is one of the most honourable senators ever to have taken his place in this chamber, which would not be denied by anyone—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a searing indictment of the rest.
—I said `one of them'.
—What about me?

—If Senator Faulkner gets into trouble, we might have to say that about him as well. On that day a strong and virulent attack was made on Senator Tate because he innocently spoke about some people who were on trial in Sydney in respect of drugs or heroin which had been imported from Thailand. Honourable senators may remember that; it was the Yooyen case.
—I do not think he wants to be reminded about this.

—He does not mind being reminded of it, because it is an illustration of how Senator Alston—who was one of the most virulent in his attack—attacked him for revealing something that he said should have been kept confidential. Indeed, Senator Alston wanted him to resign his ministry for doing that.

PARA.TAB: Senator Alston came in here today and said, `Well, look, confidentiality does not mean a thing; reveal everything that you want to reveal. Just get out any sort of documents you want; we will not worry about that'. The Opposition wants everything to be made public, irrespective of whether it affects commercial confidentiality, puts people involved in court cases at risk or may put at risk our international relationships. That does not matter to Opposition senators.

How can those opposite be so confident that everything should be made available today, 3 June 1992, when, on 10 May 1990, they were prepared to see a very honourable man and a great Minister stripped of his ministry for breaching confidentiality? Where is the consistency in those two positions? Senator Evans is saying, `Give me an opportunity to look at these documents' to ensure that the sort of confidentiality that those opposite wanted to preserve on 10 May 1990 is not breached by what he will reveal when he does put forward the papers that they are looking for.

I listened to Senator Evans's argument. He said that the concept of confidentiality is common in many areas. Certain documents do not have to be revealed in court cases. Another area in which that concept of confidentiality is illustrated is the Freedom of Information Act. Senator Alston, who has appeared in many cases dealing with the provisions of the Freedom of Information Act, knows that there are confidentiality provisions in that statute.

All Senator Evans is saying is that that concept is illustrated in very many areas. It is wrong to take him as saying that he is relying in this chamber on the provisions of the Freedom of Information Act. I would be quite against that. Unless the Parliament is very specifically included, I do not think the Freedom of Information Act can in any way stop what we deal with in this place. I would be against any proposition that an Act would stop the Senate from investigating matters that should properly be investigated.

As a body with wide powers, we have to be careful about what we make public so that people's reputations are not needlessly destroyed—although, of course, nobody in this chamber would want to destroy anybody's reputation. We have to be careful that we do not prejudice our international relationships and we have to be careful that we do not needlessly squander a commercial reputation that somebody has built up. That is all the Minister is saying. He is saying, `Let us embrace the past concepts'. He is asking for the opportunity to go through the documents so that, when they are put down in this chamber, none of us can feel that we have in any way done the wrong thing by those various categories of people that I have mentioned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt that Senator Cooney is a first-class barrister, because if the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Evans) said the sorts of things that Senator Cooney alleges the Minister was saying, we would not be having this debate. The problem is that the Minister has not been saying those things at all.

PARA.TAB: The Minister has now said on at least half a dozen occasions—it might have even been seven or eight—that, in effect, if the material he has in his office does not comply with the freedom of information regulations, he will not be tabling it in the Senate. That is what he has been saying in his answers. I agree that today he backed away from those claims. Today, when speaking to Senator Alston's motion, the Minister put the much more reasonable proposition that the freedom of information regulations simply give him some guideline for the sorts of matters that he ought to be taking into account.

But the matter involves not only the freedom of information regulations. The Minister has drawn attention to the very important pages in Odgers' Australian Senate Practice, which set out in great detail the debates on these matters which have taken place until today. Today, the Senate had the privilege of receiving from our Clerk a document which sets out this matter very succinctly. I refer to the third paragraph of the Clerk's letter to Senator Alston, which says:

SPEECH.PARA: The question of whether there are any grounds on which ministers can decline to present documents to either House of the Parliament in response to orders of a House is one which has never been resolved—
It is all right the Minister saying what he will take into account and all the rest of it, but as the Clerk goes on to say:
and basically it cannot be resolved because it always turns itself into a political question.

That point is mentioned in Odgers. Very frequently, the question of whether a Minister reveals information becomes a political question as to whether the Government should be exposing itself to some severe criticism—maybe even a censure—by a House of the Parliament.

PARA.TAB: I was very interested to hear the Minister say that one of the factors he would take into account would be the consequences for Australia's international position. One only has to realise the depth of such a statement to come to appreciate that if, for example, the material which the Minister has were to reveal that a Minister of this Government in some way or other had behaved crookedly, that would be a matter of international concern which the Government may very well try to hide. But such a statement ought to be revealed.

The Minister made reference to a statement made to the Tasmanian House of Assembly in 1960 with approval, but he did not quote it all. I will quote the last paragraph of that statement, which is set out on page 912 of Odgers where the then Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: I desire to make it clear to the House, however, that the Government has no wish to withhold from the House any information it is entitled to and that Ministers will not, without very good reason, refuse it any information.

If the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has in his possession documents which in some way or other reveal that a Minister of this Government has acted so improperly that it is a matter of international incident, notwithstanding the fact that that may very well damage our international reputation, it is a document which has to be revealed to the Parliament. That is the point I wanted to make.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had a look at this motion and I have considered the contributions that have been made. It is my view that this motion is worthy of support. I say that for the simple reason that it is important to ensure that this Parliament, and this Parliament alone, has the responsibility of safeguarding the intent of its Standing Orders and its powers. We need this responsibility not for the purpose of satisfying the egos of members of the Senate who sit in this chamber, but for the very important purpose of exercising our audit and control functions over the executive government on behalf of the people of Australia.

PARA.TAB: If we take the view, as has been taken by the Minister until today, that the freedom of information regulations should determine what should or should not be tabled in the Senate, clearly we are not doing our duty. We would be allowing the executive government, which determines those regulations, to determine what is or is not placed on the table of the Parliament. What Senator Cooney has said is not relevant. None of us in this chamber wants to see material tabled in this Senate—in other words, made public—which is private and confidential, which would affect an individual citizen and offend, interfere with and violate that citizen's right to privacy. That also goes for commercial-in-confidence material.

The Minister has said today that he will use the FOI provisions as a guide to some of these things. He should realise that he may use them as a guide, but that he is held responsible by this Parliament for his duty to table a document which has been called for in a full and fair manner. In short, it is not for any outside body to determine this matter.

While I am on my feet, might I say that that is one of the reasons why I did not vote for the motion yesterday to request the Government to establish a judicial inquiry into, amongst other things, what should or should not be the proper conduct of Ministers. In my view, that is not an appropriate decision to be made by a judicial inquiry; it is a matter which, fairly and squarely, should be dealt with in this Parliament. I believe that I am taking a consistent approach to this matter. Therefore, I will be supporting the motion as moved by Senator Alston.

TALK.START.PARA: —On every occasion Senator Evans has referred to his own integrity as being one of the most important aspects of this whole affair. He has asked us to rely on his integrity and not to doubt it. I have been here for a fair while—
—You sure have.

—Yes, and Senator Harradine will remember because we came to this place together. We remember that referendum where this very same Minister, who at that time was the Attorney-General in charge of the referendum, chose to flout—indeed, ignore completely—the law under which the referendum should have proceeded. Senator Evans put money aside and hid it, if you like.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crowley)—Senator Walters, I do not like it. Would you like to find a different word?

TALK.START.PARA: —Which one?
—`Hid'.

—I am sorry, Madam Acting Deputy President, but that is what he did; he hid it in the slush fund of the then Minister for Finance. It was not referred to at all in any way, and it cannot be described in any way other than that it was hidden. For those of us who were supporting the No case, no money was appropriated at all.

PARA.TAB: When we asked the then Attorney-General how come the money for the Yes case had not been put up front in the Appropriation Bills but hidden in the slush fund of the Minister for Finance, he—the Minister who asks us to rely on his integrity—said, `Nobody asked me'. He was relying on the fact that nobody would ask him. He asks us to rely on his integrity. He sounds quite reasonable when he puts it across to the people listening on air that he is a man of integrity.

I refer to another occasion, not quite as dramatic, which I remember well, as may some of the longer serving senators, during an Estimate committee in the old Parliament House. Senator Evans was in the chamber, where the Estimates committee was being held. Unfortunately for him, he had the microphone right in front of him. I remember that Senator Kilgariff asked one of the officers of Senator Evans's Department for some information. The officer said, `I am sorry, I haven't got it with me, Senator Kilgariff, can I take it on notice?'.

Senator Kilgariff, because he was perhaps one of the more polite senators that this chamber has ever seen, said, `Yes, certainly. Take it on notice and get it for me as soon as you can'. Senator Evans, not realising that the microphone was right in front of him, whispered to his officer, `Don't hurry; take as long as you possibly can'. Of course, Senator Evans was unaware that that was broadcast all over the old Parliament House. I was listening to the broadcast in my room.

TALK.START.PARA: —And rushed down, no doubt.

—Senator Tate has no doubt about it—I rushed down to the Estimates committee and said exactly what had occurred. Senator Evans did not attempt to deny it because everyone all over Parliament House would also have heard this Minister who asks us to rely on his integrity.

PARA.TAB: Let me go back a little further. Senator Harradine will also remember this because it relates to the Franklin Dam in Tasmania. I refer to the integrity of Senator Evans who was the Attorney-General at that time. Senator Harradine will remember that Senator Evans sent the F111 spy planes over western Tasmania to take photographs of the natives. He considered that the Tasmanian people would be frightened by an F111 flying over the western coast. The then Attorney-General of Australia gave instructions to the pilot of the F111 to be as inconspicuous as possible, and those instructions to the pilot were tabled in this Senate. I ask Senator Tate: we do not have many F111s flying over the west coast of Tasmania, do we? Very few. I asked whether the Attorney-General had suggested that the pilot fly backwards so he did not look as though he was arriving.

This is the Minister who is asking this chamber to rely on his integrity. It seems to me to be an extraordinary situation that we should be asked to rely on his integrity when he makes the decision of what this chamber should receive under freedom of information. I certainly could not, I have been here too long and I know him too well, and so do so many of my colleagues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I want to touch on a few of the comments made by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) because I think they are relevant, notwithstanding the fact that we have clearly successfully headed off a ham-fisted attempt to water down and whittle away the powers of the Parliament. Senator Evans was able to keep a straight face when saying to this chamber that he had never seriously contemplated invoking FOI; indeed, all he was doing was using a shorthand expression. He was trying to say, in effect, that there are a series of criteria which guide the exercise of ministerial discretion, that these are sometimes enshrined in legislation, such as the Freedom of Information Act, and that therefore he was simply using that as a shorthand form of referring to general criteria.

PARA.TAB: I find it quite breathtaking to hear such a limp defence from Senator Evans. When I enunciated the various examples of where he had clearly relied on FOI in the most explicit terms, I was referring to instances such as this one, on 27 May, when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday I offered Senator Hill the opportunity to look at the file note in question on a confidential basis, pending an opportunity for me in turn to evaluate it for its releasability under FOI criteria.

It simply defies imagination. It is sophistry of the highest order to pretend that all he was doing was using a shorthand expression to suggest that somehow he was going to invoke the usual guidelines that might be relevant to the exercise of ministerial discretion. He was unequivocally intending to rely upon the FOI provisions. To have the cheek to say, `You're both premature and belated because no-one has picked me up on this in the last week' is absolutely no defence at all. He was basically trying to get away with it. He thought that, if he said it often enough, when the time came he would table these documents—a few whites amongst all the black pieces—and say, `No-one ever suggested this was improper; I have exercised FOI criteria. If you thought that was wrong, you should have told me'. But, of course, by then the Parliament would have risen for a week, the heat would be off, hopefully the journalists would have lost interest and he would have won the game. That is the thought process involved. It is utterly specious. Quite clearly, Senator Evans has known from the outset that FOI has no relevance at all. Yet he has consistently and repeatedly trotted it out in such a way as to make a bald assertion that he is entitled to rely on it.

PARA.TAB: I welcome the abject and humiliating back-down which we have seen today, but it still does not—as Senator Coulter rightly points out—absolve the Minister from a responsibility to cooperate with the Senate. I want to be quite clear on this. I notice that Senator Evans is no longer with us. I suppose if one asked, `What's the most impertinent way of contributing to a debate when you are the subject matter of it?', the answer would have to be, `To walk out half way through'. Yet this is the very person who accused me of discourtesy in not listening to what he was saying. In fact, I heard what he had to say and I want to respond to it now.

The Minister was suggesting that somehow we were not for a moment saying that he did not have all these powers and that therefore the Senate is very seriously constrained in terms of what it can do. He is absolutely wrong. That is not the correct state of affairs. The ultimate power resides in the Senate and it can resolve to compel the production of documentation and, indeed, witnesses—quite unconstrained. The practical reality is that both sides of politics acknowledge from time to time that there may be good cause why one would withhold certain material, whether it be on the grounds of national interest, national security, commercial-in-confidence, the jeopardising of relations between States and a whole range of other things. But it is not for the Minister to simply invoke those and say, `Here you are, I have given you what I deem to be your entitlement'.

When push comes to shove, at the end of the day the Senate has an unfettered power to demand documents. Senator Evans can huff and puff as much as he likes. I am sure he would thrive, if he were in my position, on arguing very vigorously that nothing ought to constrain the power of the Senate. No-one would ever force the production of documents irrespective of the consequences. If they did, they would bear the political odium. There are practical constraints, if not legal ones, and they operate very effectively in the main. But it is simply not on for a Minister to unilaterally take it upon himself to decide what is and what is not disclosable.

Such defences as its not being in the national interest, or even commercial-in-confidence, can cover a multitude of sins. Anyone who has the slightest interest in being uncooperative can invoke all sorts of defences. That is why these things are tested in the courts of law. At one stage Senator Evans was suggesting that rights of natural justice ought to be accorded to anyone who might be the subject of an adverse comment. We know that that is a preposterous nonsense. That might be a requirement in administrative law. One may well have legal rights to pursue, but the Parliament is not so constrained. Senators and members have absolute privilege. At their peril, they will act irresponsibly but at the end of the day they are entitled to raise matters that in their judgment are very serious ones and they ought not to be limited simply because a Minister of the Crown thinks that it is proper to so limit them.

I welcome the Minister's complete and utter repudiation of the claim. I therefore agree that the first part of the motion is no longer relevant because Senator Evans, by his own admissions, has walked away as fast as he could from a proposition that he has been seriously advancing for the last week or so. Therefore, I think we have achieved progress. But we have not obtained any assurances from him in relation to the second part of the motion. I therefore urge the Senate to support it in its entirety. Otherwise we will not be able to obtain access to material which has already been outstanding for more than a week.

Last Tuesday week the Minister spelt out that there were four categories of documents, that he was having a schedule prepared and that he hoped to be able to provide them shortly. Surely if there is one thing that Senator Evans ought to have learnt from the experience of the last couple of months it is that one cannot have a department and an office sitting back doing nothing. I will not make judgments about whether that is the reality. But I know that that is the Minister's defence—that somehow his officers chose not to do anything or if they did they did not tell him, and certainly he made sure that he was never made aware of any of the vital information.

Surely, since the balloon has gone up, the highest priority for Senator Evans has been to try to straighten this matter out and to get all that material to the Parliament as quickly as possible. To pretend that somehow a week is not long enough and say that he hopes that maybe by tomorrow he will be in a position to produce the documents but cannot guarantee it is simply not good enough. After all, producing a schedule does not require anyone to laboriously summarise every document; it simply requires the documents to be itemised. Lawyers prepare affidavits of documents that go on for hundreds of pages. That could be knocked together in a few days.

There cannot be any justification for Senator Evans delaying beyond tomorrow lunchtime. I therefore urge the Senate to require him to cooperate in those express terms. If we are able to ensure that the Senate's position is clear and unequivocal, Senator Evans in turn will be at last brought to heel and made to accept the fact that the Senate does have the power to take these actions. If at the end of the day he is prepared to discuss the matters with us, there is always room for negotiation about what is ultimately disclosable. But that has certainly not been the case to date and we are more anxious than ever to have the matter proceed.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Alston's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Coulter on 3 June 1992 relating to the environment.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not wish to delay the Senate very long. As the Senate will realise, the Democrats—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I point out to all honourable senators standing that Senator Coulter is on his feet. Either resume your seats or leave the chamber.

—The Democrats have not used this facility very often but I think Senator Button's reply today demands that we make some response. Senator Button's methods of answering questions when he is faced with the difficulties that he was in today are several. They are, firstly, not to answer the question at all; secondly, to seek an interjection and then seek to answer the interjection rather than the question; and thirdly, to seek to denigrate the person who has asked the question.

PARA.TAB: The question related to the publication by the Australian Bureau of Statistics of very relevant information on the condition of Australia's environment. Senator Button sought to rubbish me in his reply by saying that I was grasping at statistics like a drunk grasping at a lamppost. Those statistics were quoted from the book of the Australian Bureau of Statistics. They were not in any way distorted. They were quoted exactly from that publication. I think it is appropriate that the Minister look seriously at those statistics—statistics, incidentally, which he quoted later in relation to employment figures.

One can only draw the conclusion from Senator Button's reply to me that this Government has, indeed, turned its back on a pattern of ecologically sustainable development. Having spent an enormous amount of money, having set up nine committees which sat over a long period of time, and having involved the efforts of a large number of people both within the bureaucracy and outside, this Government is now saying, `We cannot afford to go down that road'. The Minister has to recognise that we cannot afford not to go down that road. The further we move away from ecologically sustainable patterns of development, the longer it will take and the more expensive it will be for our descendants, the worse will be the environment they inherit and the less able they will be to address the very serious industrial as well as environmental problems that we face.

It is not necessary to bargain the environment against economics. There are patterns of development which will satisfactorily provide employment, address the problem of foreign debt and, at the same time, move us towards a pattern of ecological sustainability. Senator Button seems either unable or unwilling to understand it. Certainly his answer to the question today indicates that he is unable to understand that question and unwilling to address it.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: UNITED NATIONS CONFERENCE ON ENVIRONMENT AND DEVELOPMENT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement made by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) on 3 June 1992 relating to the cost of sending 49 persons to the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note the statement made by the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) on 3 June 1992 relating to the report of Estimates Committee E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tate and I came to an agreement yesterday during the debate on the Appropriation Bills that, rather than hold up those Bills, the answers to a number of questions would be presented to me at lunchtime today. By far the majority of them I only received at five minutes to two, and I will not respond to those. If need be, I will take them up in the next set of Estimates hearings in September.

PARA.TAB: However, one answer was presented to me much earlier and I would like to deal with it. It relates to Medibank Private brochures that were given to me. During the Estimates Committee hearings I spoke about the deal that was done between Medibank Private and the Public Sector Union. I believed that that special deal had been taken up by the Public Sector Union and Medibank Private. When I called it a deal in the Estimates Committee hearing Mr McNeil said:

SPEECH.PARA: The package which has been said to be a special deal between Medibank Private and the PSU is, in fact, a table which is generally available to the public. It is available to anyone who wants to walk into the Medibank—
I showed some amusement at that, and Mr McNeil said:
I am sorry, Senator; it is. The table is available to other people besides PSU members.

We did not have the brochures at that stage. The brochure that I have now been given is directed solely at the Public Sector Union and, indeed, has a sticker on it saying, `PSU members only'. That is in complete contravention of the law. Medibank Private has indeed broken the law in this regard.

PARA.TAB: The Department says that that is only a technicality and that other funds have done the same. I would like to read very briefly the section that covers the breaking of that law. Section 73B(1)(b) states:

SPEECH.PARA: The organisation will include details of all tables of benefits in a brochure which shall be freely available and on display at any of its offices or outlets to any contributor or to any member of the public who is eligible to become a contributor.

These details, obviously, were not in the main brochure. This is a special brochure put out by the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services which, when opened, makes very clear that it applies to the Public Sector Union. It says, `Enjoy the PSU Advantage'. As I have already pointed out, Medibank Private is breaking the law by doing that.

PARA.TAB: In his answer to me, Senator Tate said that the Public Sector Union brochure is currently being reprinted to remove the exclusive `PSU members only' logo—that is the round logo in the corner of the front page. He also said:

SPEECH.PARA: The PSU has been advised that this is in breach of the non-exclusivity clause of the agreement between the PSU and Medibank Private.

It would appear that it was not Medibank Private which drew up the brochure; it would appear that it was the union which did that. I said it was a deal between the Public Sector Union and Medibank Private. Mr McNeil assured me in the Estimates that it was not a deal done between them and that it was open to everyone. Yet we find that Medibank Private got the Public Sector Union to draw up the brochure. The PSU did that and, without knowing the law associated with this, the PSU breached the law.

PARA.TAB: But it is more than that. The answer I have is that the Public Sector Union has been told that it has to change this brochure, and that it breaches the clause of the agreement between the Public Sector Union and Medibank Private. The PSU has not been told that it also broke the law with the agreement. I have been sent, and have here, a photostat copy of the redesigned cover of the brochure, but that redesigned cover is also breaking the law. It states `QUALITY HEALTH COVER' and, `A PUBLIC SECTOR UNION ADVANTAGE PRODUCT'. It again shows just one table—the advantage table for the Public Sector Union.

I asked how much the original glossy brochure cost—the brochure set up by the Public Sector Union that is illegal. The answer I received was $50,000. I was also told that that $50,000 covered the redesigned cover of the brochure which is also definitely breaking the law. I have been sent a copy of the cover, and have been very generously told that I can have a copy of the whole brochure on Friday, 5 June. I ask now how much more money of the contributors to Medibank Private is going to be wasted because that brochure cannot be used either. That new pamphlet cannot be used because the law says that there will be only one brochure and all tables will be in that particular brochure.

I do not know whether at this late stage the Minister is able to give me additional information arising from my questions—this is the problem we have when we pass appropriations when we have not got all the answers, I suppose. Could he find out how much that new brochure that is also going to be illegal will cost? I hope I still get one tomorrow. Also, how long has this pamphlet been in existence? How many have been handed out? Where have they gone? Has the Public Sector Union handed them out? On how many other occasions has Medibank Private broken the law?

I was told in the answer that it is true that Medibank Private—and, it would seem, some other health funds—are technically in breach of the National Health Act, as the Commonwealth Department of Health, Housing and Community Services wrote to all funds by way of a circular on 27 April. It was in breach of the Act well before that letter went out from the Commonwealth Department of Health, yet the Department says Medibank Private has only been in breach since the Commonwealth Department sent out that note. It has been in breach ever since the Act was passed.

The questions I would like answered are: how long has this brochure been out? Was it handed around by the Public Sector Union or by Medibank Private? How long has Medibank Private been breaching the Act, breaking the law of the land? On how many other occasions has it broken the law by having single pamphlets rather than the one pamphlet? That will probably be all, but I suppose I can take it up again in the next Estimates hearings. Of course, by that time it will be all too late.

The main reason for raising this is that I believe Medibank Private has behaved extremely irresponsibly for some time. As I indicated in Estimates, Medibank Private in Victoria transferred funds out of Victoria into New South Wales, Queensland, South Australia and Western Australia.
