It had been doing very well in Victoria, so it transferred $22.3m in 1983-84 out of Victoria into other States to help other States. It then lost $21.8m in 1989-90 and another $41m in 1991. So what did it do? It got Medibank Private in other States to transfer money back into Victoria. The shenanigans of the money passing around from State to State ended up in predatory pricing in Victoria whereby Victoria's Medibank Private undercut all the other major funds. It undercut the lot. When it was increasing its membership by undercutting all the other funds, it then had to be subsidised from other funds to make its loss into a profit.

It seems to me to be an incredible situation for Medibank Private to be doing that with the funds, breaking the law in this situation, and no action being taken against it. I would be very grateful if the Minister could tell me when this pamphlet was first printed and why Medibank Private is printing yet another—this one I have here—since it received a letter on 27 April from the Department which advised that the Act requires that all funds include details of all tables available in the one brochure.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can certainly find the details that Senator Walters is seeking in relation to the publication of the brochure to which she has been referring. I think it is a fair point that was raised last night to bring to the attention of the Senate the requirements of section 73B(1)(b) of the National Health Act. Indeed, it has been the subject of a circular from the Department to, as I understand it, all registered health benefits organisations, drawing to their attention the need to have details of all available tables contained within one brochure.

PARA.TAB: I said last night that I would not venture a legal opinion, though I did advise the managers of Medibank Private to seek one as a matter of urgency to ensure that they acted in accordance with the law and not simply in accordance with departmental circulars, accepted practice or whatever it might be. But I hazard the observation that it appears that what is required is that when one walks into a Medibank Private office there should be available for contributors or would-be contributors at least a brochure—a sort of catalogue or summary of all the various tables that might be taken up by a contributor. Whether it precludes a separate brochure dealing with one table, I do not know, but that is something on which quite clearly Medibank Private's manager should get urgent advice in order to be able to ensure that it conforms with the law. That would lead to different conclusions as to whether it was still valid to print what was formerly a PSU exclusivity type brochure. We will seek the further information. I assure Senator Walters that the general question of conformity with the National Health Act has been vigorously drawn to the attention of Medibank managers.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Beahan relating to the Australian Securities Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Tate today replied to a dorothy dix question from his own side relating to a question I had asked yesterday about the late lodgment of company returns by a group of companies in which Mr Keating, the Prime Minister, is either an owner, a half owner or a shareholder indirectly. I note that Senator Tate's response today duplicates this response given by Mr Keating in the House of Representatives, minus the invective. I thank Senator Tate for his good taste in that respect. I will deal with the invective later by way of a personal explanation, because Mr Keating not only misled but also told a deliberate untruth, I think I am allowed to say—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crowley)—No, Senator Baume, I rule that you may not. I ask you to withdraw that comment, please.

TALK.START.PARA: —He told an untruth.
—No, the suggestion that the Prime Minister deliberately misled.
—I left out the word deliberate, Madam Acting Deputy President.
—Could you withdraw the word misled?
—No, Madam Acting Deputy President, I will not; I will definitely not.
—Have I misunderstood? I am now a bit confused about what was said. I am ruling that you said the words `told a deliberate untruth'.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I withdrew the word deliberate and said `an untruth'. Please do not jump to the defence of this man in this way. It is not proper. This man got up and claimed under parliamentary privilege—he does not have the guts to say it outside—that I avoided prosecution over Patrick Partners only on a technicality. That is not simply an untruth; that is a blatant lie. It is disgraceful for the Prime Minister to respond when he has been caught the way he has been over his ownership of a company which hides a half ownership in another company and his declaration does not reveal the extent of that ownership. The fact is that Mr Keating has been shown to be a closet millionaire socialist who has been outed. That is his problem. He has a $1m mansion in Elizabeth Bay; a half a million dollar investment company which is heavily involved in the pig industry; and an antique collection which is alleged to be worth very large amounts of money. On that basis, in the House of Representatives, he asked `Where did Dr Hewson's money come from?'. Let us ask Mr Keating. Let he who is without sin cast the first stone. Where did Mr Keating's money come from? How did this man who claims to have been a battler, who came up through the working class and who comes from Bankstown suddenly become a closet socialist millionaire who has been outed? It is a very interesting question. Maybe with Mr Keating's new found enthusiasm for revealing things about other people, he will reveal a few things about himself.

PARA.TAB: The question of Patrick Partners was dealt with very thoroughly indeed in a report by Mr Masterman. All this happened back in 1975. Maybe Mr Keating does not have a long enough memory to recall what happened. In 1975 there was an inquiry into Patrick Partners which found that I was totally clear of any suggestion of knowledge that Patrick Partners had some financial difficulties at the time it was accepting deposits.

The report said that `he was satisfied that all the partners (with the exception of Mr Baume)'—and those brackets, by the way, are conveniently forgotten whenever the more disgusting elements of the Labor Party try to smear me—were aware, in his view, of the state of their finances at the time they were accepting deposits. I did not know because I had not been there for five months. It is a pity I had not been there for six months. I had not been there for five months. I was never an owner-partner of the firm. I was what is called a staff partner; I was an employee with the name `partner' on the top of the letterhead. There are many legal firms and accountancy firms around town in that situation. For smart alecs to try to drag this up to try to protect themselves from their own activities is absolutely disgraceful.

The interesting feature of Senator Tate's response yesterday, when I raised this matter of companies in the group in which Mr Keating has invested this enormously large amount of money for a battler who just has a job as a politician and no high paid activities on the public record, was that he said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is a matter entirely within the jurisdiction and discretion of the Australian Securities Commission.

Is it not marvellous? It was all within the discretion of the Securities Commission. Today, though, Senator Tate has been sufficiently active to be able to tell us that one of Dr Hewson's family companies put in a return on, I think he said, 3 February and it was due to go in on 31 January. Maybe Senator Tate does not realise that there was a weekend in between. That was a horrendous matter!He had enough interest and information to find out that kind of nonsensical situation. He did not have enough energy or enthusiasm to find out what happened to some serious, absolutely disgraceful, appalling delays. It is not a question of hiding from the public for a few weeks or a few months. I might agree with the Government: a few weeks or a few months can well be inconsequential; although, if one were the Prime Minister, one would think that one would be seeking to set a decent sort of standard. As the Minister said, something like 150,000 companies put in their reports a little bit late.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many?

—About 150,000, and apparently that does not worry the Government. The Government's rules are honoured more in the breach than the acceptance. But the important matter, the matter of substance in this—and no doubt Senator Ray will be fascinated by this—relates to the companies in the Brown and Hatton Group which have not submitted an annual return for three years. Senator Ray, is that a matter of substance?

PARA.TAB: We have a clear situation: Olympia Refrigeration Sales Pty Ltd lodged no return for three years. Senator Tate is not sufficiently enthusiastic to find out about that. But he is sufficiently enthusiastic to find out about Dr Hewson's one being three days late—including a weekend.

What about Jensay Pty Ltd, another in the group? The important point is that this is a major group of companies that has dealings with the public and which, by the way, I understand is involved in an up to $300,000 legal disagreement with Goodman Fielder Wattie, a company of some substance around this place. I understand that the dispute is over the terms of its purchase of piggeries in 1988; about whether it should be required to maintain the purchases of stockfeed from Goodman Fielder Wattie. This is a major business. It is a disgrace that companies in a major group dealing with the public in substantial amounts of money should not have filed annual returns.

Family companies, which basically one might expect deal mainly with themselves, may well be of little interest to the public. They have little relationship with the public, except in, say, exceptional circumstances, and maybe the same pressures are not on them to report in time. But it is disgraceful that the reports of companies of a major corporate group—as I understand it, there is something like $10m worth of piggeries—are not timely.

Maybe they have shuffled the assets between the group. Who knows? We do not know because we have not seen the company returns for these companies. Quite frankly, this is not good enough. I would have hoped that the Minister in his response about delays in filing would have expressed some governmental concern about the fact that the requirements are being universally flouted. It may well be of little matter that they are universally flouted in respect of small family companies. But what is of major concern to me is where members of large financial groups have large external obligations and where some of those returns show that there have been secured debts incurred.

I simply want to conclude by saying that today in the other place this outed closet millionaire socialist Prime Minister accused Mr Howard and Dr Hewson of being traitors to their modest family backgrounds. This was a typical example of the way in which Mr Keating preaches class war. He did this while hypocritically pretending to be the guardian of the working class from his mansion in Elizabeth Bay, with his half a million dollars worth of pigs having their snouts in the trough—and I am not talking about his colleagues; I am talking about his real live pigs—along with his huge collection of antiques.

It is incredible that this kind of silly diversion has been presented as some kind of fightback to the fact that the Prime Minister has been caught out by basically putting in a return about his interests which does not in any way reflect the substance of that investment. I regret that the Minister for Justice got himself embroiled in this by repeating this matter.

I do look forward to seeing returns from these companies that have not made returns yet, if in fact this kind of debate has promoted concern about this. I also look forward to seeing what kind of legal matter takes place, as I understand it, in four weeks time in the Federal Court in respect of the Brown and Hatton Group, in which I understand Mr J. J. Brown is still involved in some way, along with his colleague, Mr Keating. I understand that his group has lodged some kind of counterclaim.

It will be interesting to see what the situation really is. But maybe that will prompt these companies, some of which have not reported for three years, to at last make their reports to the Australian Securities Commission. One would hope that the Government will encourage them to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise only briefly because I did put a fair amount on the record in the Senate during Question Time. But I do want to say that no doubt it would be a matter of concern for the Australian Securities Commission that so many companies—up to 150,000 companies—failed to lodge an annual return. It is not for me to direct, and nor would the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) direct, the Australian Securities Commission as to how it should deal with that phenomenon. I think it is fair to say that all I was recounting to the Senate was the general practice of the Australian Securities Commission, which is to issue penalty notices, warning notices and such like, and to try to deal with the matter in an administrative way rather than by exacting penalties if in fact there can be compliance within a reasonable time.

PARA.TAB: What has been interesting about Senator Baume's contribution is the admission that in relation to what he called small family companies there may not be the same weight to be attached to the failure to lodge a return. I doubt whether he would have made that admission had we not exposed during Question Time today the failure of Dr Hewson and Mr Peter Reith to ensure that companies with which they were associated had lodged their returns by the due date. This exercise is now coming to a close in the sense that there is an admission by the spokesman for the Opposition on this matter—the person who has led the running on it—that if indeed the Prime Minister's family company did not lodge a return by the due date then, in Senator Baume's words, `that may well be regarded as a matter of little consequence'. It was certainly made into a matter of major consequence by the Opposition yesterday and beaten up into a tremendously exciting story, as Senator Baume hoped that it would be. Now, because there is some balance in the situation, he thinks that it ought to be regarded by the Australian public as a matter of little consequence—

TALK.START.PARA: —I said it `may' be regarded.
—I believe that the honourable senator is on the right track in saying that it ought to be regarded in that way.
—Don't misquote me, Senator; I said it `may' be regarded.

—I think that the honourable senator is suggesting that it may be regarded as such by any fair-minded person. I hope that the honourable senator would regard the Australian electorate as composed of fair-minded people in this regard, but I think he was pandering to some of the baser instincts in a very few of them yesterday.

PARA.TAB: I believe that these matters are best left with the Australian Securities Commission. There is an obligation upon all those associated with companies to lodge their returns by the due date. I believe that we are now in a position, perhaps as a result of this publicity, where this fact is brought home not only to members of the Government and Opposition and those in high public life but also to all those associated with the 150,000 companies which have failed to lodge their returns in a timely way.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to comment firstly on the matter of noting questions after Question Time. During the time of the Fraser Government probably five questions were noted in eight years, and probably in the first—
—We didn't have cause to; people told the truth.

—I think everyone in the chamber would concede that it is not that simple. It is always done by leave. In this session we have had many more questions noted. One could argue that that is because of a Minister's response, but those opposite would know deep in their hearts that it is a new tactic. That is the way this chamber works. At one stage, at our behest, we used to have petitions read out for 55 minutes, so we chopped the head off that one. Then the next tactic crops up, such as speaking on money Bills for hours on end, and the head is chopped off that one.
—It is the democratic process.

—Yes, it is, and no-one would seek to halt the reserve power of the Senate to do it, but to do it as consistently and for as long as we have in the last few weeks is something at which the Procedure Committee should look. I accept in part that this process could be substituted by matters of public importance. If we are to do that, we should formalise it in some way and work out who should do what. I make that point because wherever there is a little hole in the Senate dyke water will flood through.
—If you answered the questions properly we wouldn't have need to.

—I remember the days of 1982—most people here cannot but Senator Teague and Senator Walters can—and of sitting in the chamber when answers were not given to many questions because the then government was under siege over the bottom-of-the-harbour scheme.

PARA.TAB: Let me make a second point. Senator Baume has heard of the allegations about Patrick Partners. I think that some of the insults thrown across the chamber over the years with regard to that company have not been fair to him. This would be an even more serious problem were he himself not so prone to throw allegations across the chamber. I recognise that he normally has a very thick hide. If there is one thing that I normally like about Senator Baume it is that he really dishes it out and when it is dished back most times he sits there and cops it. I am not saying that he should cop all the abuse in that regard. People still ask questions of him about his role in Patrick Partners, not as to whether he was culpable or showed due diligence—I have no idea about that—

TALK.START.PARA: —The report did. It exonerated me.

—I have never read the report and I suspect that I never will. Senator Baume came into this chamber and raised the issue of lateness of returns. As Senator Tate pointed out, whoever has done that is in good or bad company with 150,000 other private company owners.

PARA.TAB: The interesting thing is what happened in the other place today. The former leader twice over of the Liberal Party was somehow suckered into asking the Prime Minister a question and for the second time in the last 12 months he was made to look the biggest mug in history, because what is good for the goose turned out to be good for the gander. Rather than just the Prime Minister or the Prime Minister's private company failing to report, we find the same thing when we look at Brintmar Holdings and Co. It is true to say that it only missed lodging a return on time by a short period this year, but if one looks past this year and into the back years one sees that it missed by six weeks or more to get the return in on time. I do not know whether culpability is measured by the length of time—

TALK.START.PARA: —I asked that of Senator Tate yesterday.

—This is one matter for sensible debate. Senator Baume raised this issue yesterday in a sneaky way, thinking, `I'll go and give the Prime Minister a bloody nose over this'. What Senator Baume did not know at the time was that he was going to cop a counterpunch back. I score this particular brawl about a draw.
—Except the Prime Minister has been outed.

—I will come back to that remark in a moment. Senator Baume went on, a little more outrageously, to say, `Is this being done because money has been moved around?'. I call on the honourable senator to take up his own challenge. He has criticised the Prime Minister for not going outside the House and saying these things. There is the door; the honourable senator can go outside and say these things. He will not, and I would not seriously ask him to.
—Ask what—where the money came from?

—Senator Baume asked, `Are these returns late because they have been juggling money around between them?' or `moving money around', to use his exact words. If he wants to use those words and still have credibility when he criticises others for what he regards as smearing, he should go outside that door and then we will start to believe him. Until he does, we will not believe him.

PARA.TAB: I also note that the shadow Treasurer has a company that was 10 months late with one of its returns. If the honourable senator is to be straightforward on these matters, I suppose that he should get up on his feet and criticise the shadow Treasurer for that. That is not expected in politics because politics is an adversarial system in which one side attacks another and never makes admissions about its own side.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would think that the Prime Minister never got a personal letter from the Commissioner saying, `Pay your last year's tax as well as this'.
—Senator Walters, you have been warned by the President today—
—I have not!
—You have been spoken to by the President.
—I have, but I have not been warned, so let us have some truth.
—Just make sure that you are not warned.

—The only other point that I should make is that the argument about who is making money and where, when there are no allegations of impropriety going either way, is the sort of class politics that I detest. I admit that I have never owned a share in my life; I have never been a company director. I do not resent at all Dr Hewson or Mr Keating having a lot of money. However, the public has a right to know in broad terms the general financial position of a politician so that it can make a judgment about whether they are exercising due independence in their decision making. We have a rough idea about that with Cabinet Ministers who put in two returns—one general which we all see, and one specific for the Prime Minister to see. We know about the members of the House of Representatives. We do not know about the rest of the honourable senators here because it always gets tied up in bureaucratic tape. Apparently, no-one opposes it, but no-one will progress it through; and we wonder why.

PARA.TAB: I conclude on the point on which I started. This chamber has to seriously look at the matter of noting answers to questions because it is done by leave. No-one wants to go to the point where we refuse leave all the time, nor does one want to destroy this as a device for proper democratic discussion in this chamber. But there is no unlimited right to discussion in this chamber; we all know that. We have to look at whether there is a more appropriate device whereby we can at least not inhibit too much the legislative program or the other business of the Senate. It is now 5.20 p.m. and we are still taking note of answers to questions that were finalised at 3 o'clock. I do not think that for the future that is a particularly good idea.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond very briefly to what Senator Ray has said about the procedure of taking note of answers to questions. It is absolute and utter nonsense to say that this is something which should not be done on any occasion and that it has now got out of hand. The thing that has now got out of hand at Question Time, particularly on broadcast days, is the total and utter misrepresentation of Liberal and National Party policy, and that is the thing that at some stage we have to refute.

PARA.TAB: If those opposite as a government continue to do that, unfortunately for their program, we will continue to put the record straight. So really the answer is clearly in their hands in terms of what they want to do. If those opposite want to continue to peddle the line that a goods and services tax adds 15 per cent on top of everything and that health and education will be more expensive, along with pharmaceuticals and everything else, when they know that those things are all going to be zero rated, they have to cop the consequences. They really have the answer in their hands. If they want to make sure that they give factual and correct answers, even if they are answers to their dorothy dixers, then so be it. But they have total and utter misrepresentation of industrial relations. Senator Cook is sitting there today and he constantly and utterly—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. That is a fallacious piece of nonsense.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Order on my left! Allow the honourable senator to make his point of order.
—My point of order is that I was just accused of misrepresenting my own portfolio. That is not true and I think Senator Knowles should withdraw the remark.

—There was so much noise in the chamber that I did not fully hear Senator Knowles's comment. There is a standing order which covers the particular matter that Senator Cook raises but, not having properly heard what was said, I ask Senator Knowles to continue.

—What I did say, if Senator Cook would like to clean his ears out, is that he in fact regularly misrepresents our industrial relations policy; he wilfully and intentionally misrepresents our industrial relations policy. If he wishes to continue doing that, and a whole range of other misrepresentation, then he and the Government can cop the consequences and not squeal about it, because that is the situation that honourable senators opposite have brought this Government to. We have a situation where Senator Evans is trying to bypass the Senate and where Senator Richardson was trying to bypass the Senate and those opposite expect us not to respond. This is just absolutely and utterly extraordinary.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators opposite, whether it be Senator Ray, Senator Cook or anyone else, should not come in here saying that we cannot have our say in this democratic chamber because we will continue to have our say. We are sick to death of being muzzled by this Government. We are sick to death of regularly having, on broadcast days, the lies peddled about the Fightback package which unfortunately are reported in some sycophantic way by the majority of the media. Therefore it is up to us in this chamber to put the record straight. It is a question of honesty and it is a question of propriety and it is a question of whether the Government is going to start to tell the truth at Question Time. If it does not, we will continue to stand up for what is right. Surely it is our right to put the record straight.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly on the matter that Senator Knowles raised in response to the comments made by Senator Ray on the issue of taking note of answers to questions after Question Time. Senator Ray was right in saying that this is a procedure which, in recent months, has been perhaps more extensively used than previously in this chamber. I detected from what Senator Ray said that he did not think that that was altogether a bad thing. I was pleased that he noted that on many occasions this procedure of taking note of an answer after Question Time did, in effect, replace other matters that we have the right to bring before this chamber, in particular, matters of public importance.

PARA.TAB: I put on the record my belief—and this endorses Senator Knowles's remarks—that this has been a very important development in the procedures of the Senate. It has led to a very genuine debate after Question Time. In many ways, the debate during that hour or so when we take note of answers—which probably occurs on most days, I suspect—is important because it is in response to issues which the Government has raised during Question Time.

Rather curiously, Senator Ray thought this whole matter could probably be considered by the Standing Committee on Procedure. I am not altogether sure why that should be the case. I have no particular reason to object to that, but it is fairly clear to me that senators on both sides of the chamber show a willingness to use this particular time in the Senate. The senator on the other side of the chamber who tends to speak most in the debates on the taking note of answers is in the chamber now—Senator Cook. I can recall earlier this week, or perhaps at the end of last week—as the time goes by, it is sometimes hard to remember—that Senator Cook took up close to a full half hour after Question Time making further points.

The other point I wish to raise in the chamber now is made in light of Senator Ray's comment—with which I said I agreed—that this was a new procedure. The other new procedure which has come about, which was not raised by Senator Ray, is the astonishingly low number of questions answered in the course of Question Time. I had cause in this chamber the other night to bring to the attention of the Senate that, over the period of the Hawke-Keating Government, it has answered, on average, six fewer questions per day than all the other governments for which we have statistics on record. Senator Cook would be interested to know that six fewer questions each day over the seven-day parliamentary cycle is 42 fewer questions over that period. That means that, if this Government had come reasonably close to answering the number of questions that all other governments for which we have statistics on record were able to answer, every senator in this chamber would probably have a chance to ask at least one and sometimes two further questions during the course of a seven-day parliamentary cycle.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kemp, I remind you that the motion before the Chair is that the Senate take note of Senator Tate's answer.
—That is right but this matter was raised by Senator Ray.
—I am not quite sure about the number of questions, but keep going. I am fairly mellow this afternoon.

—I am very pleased to hear that. You are looking mellow too, I might say. Thank you for your kind indulgence. I am close to finishing. If the Standing Committee on Procedure is going to look at taking note of answers to questions, as a matter of high priority—fundamental priority—the Committee has to look at why this Government so notably fails to answer anywhere near the number of questions that all other governments have been able to answer.

PARA.TAB: If Senator Ray wants to put taking note of answers to questions on the agenda, I would certainly like to again put on the agenda the very poor performance of Government Ministers in Question Time—the very long and tedious answers, which at times are clearly designed to be very provocative. I do not object to that. This is the nature of the parliamentary procedure. We expect provocative answers. However, when Senator Cook makes provocative comments about our policies and about our leaders, I am sure that he would be the first to expect us on this side of the chamber to respond with vigour.
