TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General, report No. 38 of 1991-92, Efficiency Audit, Department of Defence, Management of Army Training Areas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate has before it the Auditor-General's report No. 38 for 1991-92 entitled Department of Defence, Management of Army Training Areas. It is always interesting to have a report by the Australian National Audit Office. They are always valuable, because they are usually very thoroughly done.

PARA.TAB: As I have said over many years in this chamber, the application of the Australian National Audit Office to military affairs is often constrained by the approach that the Audit Office brings to what is essentially not a commercial venture. There are, of course, excellent accountants in the Audit Office who tend to look at things in terms of balance sheets and see things in a commercial way. If there is one thing the Department of Defence is not, it is a commercial operation. That does not deny the need for accurate cost accounting for Defence. Those who have listened to me over the years would know that I have always made a plea for more accurate cost accounting for the Department of Defence.

We simply must know what it is costing to provide a certain capability in the Defence Force. We do not have that precise information. A simple example is the questions I have asked over the years in relation to the VIP squadron at Fairbairn providing VIP transport for the Parliament and dignitaries. The best one can get from the Air Force or the Department of Defence on the cost of that squadron is a rough approximation from the number of personnel involved, the lease costs of the aircraft and the fuel bill. It is really quite imprecise and will not give us the sort of data that we need to make an accurate assessment.

As we move to higher technology and, therefore, far more expensive capital equipment programs with the Australian Defence Force, the need to be able to measure costs accurately becomes more and more important. Having said that, we must not let the cost accountants make decisions. They must be there in an advisory capacity, providing information as to what services cost. They must not be in a position where they can say, `You can't afford that', which is always the risk when these people are around. They are collectors of information; they are not approvers of what equipment should be bought.

At the end of the day, defence is a very expensive activity. It must be efficient if we are going to maintain an adequate Defence Force and the Australian public must get value for money. There is a place for the Australian National Audit Office to be continually overseeing what the Department is doing. I hope that it uses a little more sophistication in its assessment techniques than it has up to the present time.

The report deals with army training areas. I would like to make a few general observations on that at the start. First of all, all services need training areas. The defence forces have to exercise their personnel, they have to exercise using their equipment and they have to have live firing exercises on ranges which demand reasonably extensive safety zones.

The Australian Defence Force is not part of the civilian world. To look at its assets—whether it is in terms of equipment or land—through the eyes of normal commercial practice is quite inappropriate, because the Australian Defence Force expands and contracts according to the strategic situations that we find ourselves in from time to time. At the moment we are in a period of contraction, but it would only need some slight change in the environment for the activities and resources diverted to defence to increase and increase quite considerably. In more passive times, the requirements would diminish.

The assets that we require in the form of land do change from time to time but, in the long term, there is a degree of predicability that we will certainly need them. The actual extent to which we need them varies from time to time. Superimposed on that is the changing technology of modern weapons systems. The size of ranges increase, as do safety areas. In the debate on the motion of the Australian Democrats about Shoalwater Bay, I spoke of how, with the introduction of laser guided and precision guided munitions, et cetera, the size of safety ranges goes up four, five or 10 times what is required for high explosives. If precision guided munitions are going to be used with laser guidance, the safety distances will go up very considerably. So the area of land needed also goes up.

The Australian Defence Force is in the business of defending this country into the foreseeable future. Any thinking about its land use resources must be measured in terms of centuries, not years or decades. We really have very few training areas in Australia for the defence forces. All the training areas are defined in this document before us. Of the areas on the east coast, Shoalwater Bay is the only large training area. The high range area at Dotswood station is used by Lavarack barracks in Townsville. We have also areas in the Wide Bay district, but they are really quite a deal smaller than Shoalwater Bay. One or two training areas are used on the west coast. There is also an area used by Tindal in the Northern Territory. In aggregate, we really have very few large training areas within Australia.

We need a variety of terrain in training areas. The forces cannot be trained in one area, because one can literally reach the stage where the troops know every tree, gully and rock. It is therefore very difficult to introduce variety into training.

Training areas also have to be accessible because there is a great economic cost in moving troops and equipment to them. Most equipment, whether it be tanks or APCs, is pretty heavy; ammunition is also a very heavy commodity. The cost of moving a regiment out of Holsworthy in the west of Sydney up to Shoalwater Bay for an exercise would easily run into hundreds of thousands or even millions of dollars. So the availability of areas close to main camp sites becomes very important. In addition, from the point of view of maintenance of the environment, it is important that there are enough training areas so that troops are not moving over the same piece of ground the whole time.

It follows from that that the Australian Defence Force needs a long term policy for land use which should be measured in terms of centuries, not today's needs. If the ADF sees a requirement for exercises in the next five or 10 years, it should not have to go out and buy land and relinquish it after the exercises are over.

I have been in the Senate for 14 years during which time my major interest has been in defence. One of my constant interests has been the need to get a long term land requirement and land usage program for the Australian defence forces. Unless we define what areas we need and acquire that land while it is available, in another 10 or 20 years it just will not be available at an economic cost.

By and large, the training areas that we want for the defence forces are not in urban areas. The only requirement in urban areas is land which is used for residential or administrative purposes. In rural areas, where the principal requirement is, we rarely need high value land. We certainly do not need high value agricultural or farming land. Most of the training areas that are acquired are on grazing land—usually, the less desirable grazing land—or crown land. By and large, crown land has remained as such because it is not terribly useful.

I support the point raised in the Auditor-General's report that the requirements of the Australian Defence Force in the years ahead should be defined. We should move to acquire that land. The report tends to look at this matter on an instant use basis. In particular, the report says that the training area in Western Australia, which was acquired in 1978, has never been used for large formation exercises. That cuts no ice with me at all. I am looking well into the next century. We will certainly use this area at a future date.

The other thing that must be emphasised is the need for size. I have talked about being able to introduce variety into training—that we cannot have soldiers knowing exactly where every tree is so that in day or night they can just move blindfolded through an area.

The other very important point is that, given the dry and friable nature of Australian soils, once exercises start and troops and vehicles are moved—particularly tracked vehicles which are chosen for cross-country use—a great deal of damage can be done if troops run over precisely the same area all the time. The Army has followed a practice of having large training areas, of using areas in sequence and, just as a farmer does with fallow fields, letting them recover for years before moving back into them.

Against that background and by way of introduction, I will deal with the key findings in the front of this report, because they cover in an encapsulated form what the report is all about. The first point that the Auditor-General makes is that there was inadequate control at the corporate level over the Army's training estate of 1.37 million hectares. That really relates to what I was talking about with respect to long term land usage.

The second point deals with unexploded ordnance in former training areas. The Auditor-General is apparently not clear about the fact that the Army, above all the other services, has a very real interest in knowing the location of unexploded ordnance such as unexploded bombs and shells. After all, trucks and APCs run over these areas. There may have been a more casual approach in the past 40 or 50 years, particularly with the high intensity training that took place during the Second World War, to where ordnance was fired.

In modern practice, the services are very careful to watch the fall of shot and to determine that fired shells do go off. If they do not, they go out and look for them. They do not always find them, but they certainly have a vested interest in finding and detonating explosives so that they are not a threat to anyone later on. One always has to remember that there is always a cycle of postings in the services. An entirely different group of administrative officers could be running a training area from year to another. So the institutional need to know where things are that have not gone off really becomes quite important. The way to handle that is to try to minimise those numbers.

I also differ with the Auditor-General's statement that the high explosive impact areas should be kept as small as possible. A lot of damage is caused by the detonation of high explosives. Big craters are created if ordnance—be it a shell or a bomb—is detonating after it falls and is buried below the ground. It is very destructive to use one particular area for the detonation of high explosives. While wanting to keep such an activity confined—not spread all over the training area—some degree of dispersal becomes essential if the environment is to be protected.

The third point made by of the Auditor-General relates to the inadequacies in the procedures for training area acquisitions. I agree with him. The matter should be fully researched before any purchases are made and it should fill a need. The Auditor-General said that the Yampi Sound training area in Western Australia has never been used for large formation exercises. The cost of the land was really quite minimal because no-one wanted it when it was bought back in 1978. The holding costs of that land have really been peanuts. The land has been held at a peppercorn rental from 1978 onwards. To say, as the Auditor-General does, that there has never been any large formation exercises there is to miss the point that we want it for the future.

The next point raised in the report is the level of repair and maintenance funding. That is a very real point. The Services have been active in repair of the training areas, but they are constrained by a falling defence Budget. Quite simply, defence does not get enough money. That is something which has to be corrected. Damage to training areas will not be corrected until the defence vote goes up.

The next point raised is the environmental policy of the Department of Defence, which has been in draft form for eight years. Later in the report the Auditor-General comments on the environmental policies of the Department of Defence. That is misleading. In my experience, going back to the mid-1950s, the Australian defence forces were conscious of environmental matters long before they became popular public issues. The defence forces have spent money on environmental matters. The testimony of that is to go through the intensive training areas at Holsworthy, Puckapunyal, Seymour, et cetera. If the land had not been looked after 30 or 40 years ago, it would just be wasteland today; it is not. The Auditor-General is calling for a more refined and developed set of policies than are in place. It is misleading to create the impression that nothing is being done in that direction.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Cooney, I table additional information received by Estimates Committee E.

—On behalf of Senator Cooney, I present the seventh report of 1992 of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. I also lay on the table Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest No. 8 of 1992 dated 3 June 1992. I move:

PARA.TAB: That the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since coming to this Parliament almost two years ago I have been a member of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. I was recently given some new duties by Dr Hewson which has made it necessary for me to retire from the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. I retired from that Committee today. Senator Tierney, from the Liberal Party in New South Wales, has taken my place on that Committee. I welcome Senator Tierney to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee.

PARA.TAB: I pay tribute to the Committee, to the work it does and to its members. The Committee is currently, and I understand that is has been for some time, chaired by Senator Barney Cooney. Notwithstanding that he is from the Government benches and the Australian Labor Party, he has been an excellent chairman and a very sincere and conscientious guardian of our freedoms. I think he is a sincere protector of the forms of Parliament, particularly of the Senate. I have enjoyed Senator Cooney's chairmanship of the Committee. I will miss our early morning meetings on Wednesdays and some of the interaction between Senator Cooney and, I think, his factional colleague Senator Crowley—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, different factions; he is in his own faction.

—He is in his own faction. I always find the meetings quite amusing. I particularly enjoy the repartee and some of the interesting philosophical arguments which take place between Senator Cooney and Senator Crowley. I also mention the Deputy Chairman, Senator Vanstone, Senator Nick Sherry and Senator Janet Powell, all of whom I have enjoyed working with in my time on that Committee.

PARA.TAB: As I leave that Committee, I pay tribute to its Secretary, Stephen Argument, who has been particularly diligent and conscientious in his work. I also pay tribute to the work that Professor Davis and his predecessor did for that Committee in bringing matters to the attention of the Parliament, particularly the Senate.

Without delaying the Senate too long, I must say that I have found the Scrutiny of Bills Committee to be rather refreshing and unique. I have practised law in Queensland all of my life. I found it quite incredible that somewhere in Parliament there is a committee which genuinely looks through Bills to make sure that they did not trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties; a committee which watches all legislation to make sure that rights, liberties and obligations are not unduly dependent upon insufficiently defined administrative powers; and a committee which checks legislation to make sure that rights, liberties and obligations are not unduly dependent upon non-reviewable decisions and that legislation does not inappropriately delegate legislative power, nor that legislation insufficiently subjected the exercise of legislative powers to Parliamentary scrutiny.
I come from Queensland where we have a unicameral system. Having seen some of the legislation which has gone through the Queensland Parliament over the last couple of decades, I was quite amazed.

TALK.START.PARA: —And quite recently, too.

—Yes, I am quite sure that the current Government is no better. In fact, I am sure that it would be worse than the previous Government. As one who grew up as a lawyer in the areas concerned, I took as common place some of the powers which were given to the executive and the authorities in Queensland by State Parliament legislation. When I came down here I found that some parliamentarians, particularly senators, made a practice of going through legislation. It was a cultural shock to me. That might explain why, in my practice of 20 years or so in law in Queensland, I always seemed to have problems with State legislation but never with Federal legislation. At the time I thought it might have been how it was. In retrospect, now that I understand how things operate in the Federal Parliament, I understand the work that this Committee and other elements of this chamber undertake to look after legislation.

PARA.TAB: We do not hear much about the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. I believe, from my limited experience of this Parliament, that it is one of the best committees. It certainly deserves a lot more credit than it ever gets. The Committee guards the foundations of our democracy. As I have said, I am retiring from the Committee today. I am pleased to have been a member of it and to have worked with the Committee members. The Committee should live long and reign long in this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. A motion was passed at a meeting of the Committee this morning that a letter be written to Senator Macdonald thanking him for his considerable efforts. He is in a long line of good senators who have come to that Committee. Senator Brownhill graced the Committee for some time.
—I enjoyed it just as much as these other people.

—Senator Brownhill did not have the legal skills of Senator Macdonald, but he had a practical knowledge, a good farmer's sense, which often brings a proper perspective to all of this. We have thanked Senator Brownhill. This is a speech in which the Committee, through me, pays tribute to Senator Macdonald. He clearly showed that he has considerable skills with the law, no doubt due to the 20 years he has practised law and the five years he had to study it. He has been practising law for 25 years. I should not have said that because Senator Macdonald is frowning in desperation. I thank Senator Macdonald, on behalf of the Committee, for the great contribution he made to that Committee. It is an important Committee. Senator Macdonald's contribution has been noted and will be noted formally by way of letter.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.
Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who will forget December 1991 when this Parliament passed legislation which substantially strengthened the financial disclosure obligations of political and third parties? However, the disclosure section of the legislation was, I believe, rather overshadowed by the passion engendered by the debate on the section of the Bill regulating political advertising. The main disclosure effects of the 1991 legislation are: that registered political parties must lodge annual returns of all income, expenditure and debts; that third parties who participate in the electoral process must disclose gifts made by them to political parties; and that the Australian Electoral Commission has been given enhanced powers to conduct random spot audits to ensure compliance.

PARA.TAB: These changes cumulatively achieve a very high standard of accountability and transparency—standards that were long overdue. Such standards have resulted, on reflection, in an unwarranted administrative burden upon political parties in so far as they rely on volunteers at local branch level to keep branch accounts and other records. Under the December 1991 legislation, political parties are obliged to record certain information on every single transaction entered into by the party and its constituent organs. The difficulties for political parties arising from this particular requirement are quite clearly canvassed in the second reading speech of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook). In the interests of time, I will not go over them.

It is the Democrats' belief that the amendments proposed in the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill 1992 are a reasonable approach to the administrative problems outlined without watering down the improved full disclosure and transparency requirements. The major provisions of this Bill that I would draw attention to which the Democrats are pleased to see are: those provisions which decrease the administrative burden on registered political parties by providing that amounts of less than $100 received from a person or organisation at a fundraising event need not be recorded in annual returns; the provision which decreases the administrative burden on registered political parties by providing that payments of amounts less than $100 need not be recorded in annual returns; and the provision which increases the time for agents to complete and furnish annual returns from eight weeks after the end of the financial year to 20 weeks after the end of the financial year.

The Democrats support this Bill but we anticipate a machinery Bill later in the year which will afford us the opportunity to address such important topics as the office of profit under the Crown, something which I am sure we would all like to see tackled before the impending Federal election. I think the passage of this Bill will set at rest the anxiety of many hardworking and local branch members of all political parties who have been mortified at the prospect of being caught up for failing to record the identification of all persons purchasing raffle tickets, even to the value of as low as $1, at any sort of local branch fundraising event. It is easy to see how omissions could quite easily occur and how the intention of the person would certainly not have been to flout the legal obligations. In seeking to cast the net widely in this legislation, we have inadvertently caught a lot of the baby fish.

The enhanced random auditing power of the Electoral Commission will underpin all of these amendments. The Democrats think that that is an extra power which will enhance compliance. There are those in the community who, for obvious reasons, still do not want us to see the connection between money given to political parties and influence which may be exerted. But fortunately as a community we continue to move towards higher standards of political accountability and such desires will not and cannot be accommodated.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Parer and Senator Kernot for their contributions to the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill 1992. Reflecting on the last time this matter was before the Parliament, we are seeing quite a different scenario today. I do not think I need to respond to much because, quite honestly, there is not much that has been raised in the debate that goes to the Bill.

PARA.TAB: There is one matter that needs to be put on the record. I will do this briefly. At some stage during the debate today Senator Parer made some reference to Senator Ray warning Lindsay Fox that if he were known to have given a substantial donation to the Liberal Party he may not have good industrial relations. I refer people who may be interested to the Hansard of 6 May 1987. It is fair to say to put the record straight that that sort of intimidation and inference cannot be drawn out of what Senator Ray said at that particular time. Any fair meaning person who may read the Hansard of the time—

TALK.START.PARA: —It depends on your own interpretation.

—Any fair person interpreting what Senator Ray said would not come up with the interpretation that Senator Parer came to in the earlier part of this debate. On 6 May 1987 Senator Ray did refer to Lindsay Fox. In the context of the need to have disclosure law to protect democracy in this country, he made reference to the good relations that Fox had with the unions. He also went on to make reference to the fact that if Fox donated $1m and suddenly a Liberal government started using his company, anyone would be entitled to know. In raising both those aspects, Senator Ray was stressing the point that disclosure laws act to protect democracy. He was not in any way intimidating Mr Fox. The inference that I make is also the inference that Senator Ray made and one that he confirms to us today.

PARA.TAB: Having put that on the record, I do not think there needs to be any greater deliberation at this particular part of the debate. I conclude my remarks here.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a couple of general questions that I would like to ask the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus). We have a distinction between parties that are registered nationally and also at the State level. This legislation means, effectively, that a person can give $1,499 to each State branch of the party and nationally before disclosure applies. Is that right?
—That's right, yes.
—Does it mean that it is still easy to shift this money from one State branch to another State branch and escape the actual source of that donation?

—In response to Senator Kernot's first question, the effect of the legislation is that, although those amounts would not be disclosed, they would still have to be identifiable and identified. That being the case—and just referring back to the point Senator Kernot made in the second reading debate that the power to spot audit is still in existence—that power obviously acts as a capacity in the Commission to ensure that there is no unhealthy non-disclosure or avoidance of the legislation. I hope that answers the second part of Senator Kernot's question as well. It may not.

—I think we are talking about a total of $12,000 if someone were to do that at every level. It is impossible for us. I think we have discussed before that it is very difficult for us to make this part of it perfect.

—I think that is right. What one can anticipate very quickly happening is a situation where there may, in fact, be coalitions or intra-party transfers to get around any situation Senator Kernot might be trying to get at—for instance, by defining each State and Territory branch as part of one party. There are ways around it whatever we try to do. It is the power to spot audit that ensures that unhealthy avoidance does not take place.
—With regard to voluntary labour, does this Bill lead to any inconsistency with previous interpretations of what constituted voluntary labour and was disclosable?

—It does not change it at all. The advice as I have received it from the Electoral Commission is that, in respect of gifts, the Commission would continue to apply its longstanding interpretation of voluntary labour supplied for the benefit of political parties. That interpretation can be found in the Election Funding and Financial Disclosures Handbook issued by the Commission. To generalise that and put it simply, that interpretation means that a service provided free of charge will amount to voluntary labour provided it is not a service that the person performing it normally charges for.

PARA.TAB: One example that has been raised in recent days is whether the group of six accountancy firms providing voluntary labour for the Liberal Party and the Fightback package would amount to disclosable contributions. Under the definition used by the Commission, that would very much be a disclosable contribution and they would have to disclose the extent to which the labour and the expertise they have provided has cost them. So there is no change in the longstanding definition of voluntary labour by this legislation. It is a definition which has been applied by the Commission since 1984.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take this opportunity to indicate to the Committee, and through the Committee to the Senate, that I will be resigning from the—
—The Senate?

—Senator Bolkus's hope springs eternal. I shall be resigning from the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters because of other substantial parliamentary commitments. I simply wish to inform the Committee of that fact. I do not think I am abandoning the ship because, of the current members, I am the longest serving member of that Committee. I think it is about time that I gave way to another honourable senator who is interested in serving on that Committee.

PARA.TAB: I certainly will be taking, as indeed all of us take, a great deal of interest in this particular subject. The Committee, by and large, has worked very well and has sought to accommodate the views of a broad range of people in the community and a broad political spectrum. Though I have disagreed on occasion with some colleagues on the Committee, the Committee has worked well and cooperatively. We have been well served, I believe, by the Commission in the work that it has done following requests that have been made to it by us. I am probably out of order, Mr Chairman, but I take the opportunity, with your indulgence, to notify you and the Committee of that fact.

TALK.START.PARA: —I consider those comments to be in order.

PARA.TAB: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Senator Bolkus) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 11 May, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition supports the Ozone Protection Amendment Bill 1992. Not only do we support this Bill, we have consistently advocated an accelerated commitment to the phasing out of CFCs, which is part of this Bill, because we are concerned about the ozone layer.

PARA.TAB: The policy adopted by the Opposition in 1990 states:

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to CFCs, we commend the positive steps taken by industry to move to eliminate the use of CFCs in Australia and we will act to ensure their complete elimination (excluding medical and pharmacological uses) by a target date of 1995. The export of CFCs and halons will be banned. We will work for further revisions of the provisions of the Montreal Protocol to the Vienna Convention on the protection of the earth's ozone layer to facilitate international cooperation in these endeavours.

This is a major environmental issue on which there is bipartisan support for the actions taken by the Government. In this case, in fact, the Opposition adopted a target which was five years in advance of the international protocol. Naturally, now that the Government is legislating to bring the Australian legislative framework into line with the accelerating international framework—that is, to bring the target date back to 1997—it clearly has our support although 1995 remains, quite frankly, our target date.

PARA.TAB: When this matter was first raised, the Opposition urged the Government to use its best endeavours to encourage Australian industry to replace ozone depleting substances, and achieve faster and greater reductions in the levels of production and use of ozone depleting substances than are provided for in the convention on the protocol, to the extent that such replacements and achievements are reasonably possible within the limits imposed by the availability of suitable alternative substances and appropriate technology and devices.

This qualification is necessary because there are technical difficulties which we must deal with in a practical and timely way in getting rid of CFCs. I think it is worth pointing out that, over a period of years, the political parties here have been prepared to acknowledge the significant dangers which exist in the area of ozone depletion and have taken, and are taking, legislative action to reduce those dangers.

There is often a lot of criticism of politicians not responding adequately and properly to matters of concern like this. I hope it gives confidence to those concerned people in the community to see this sort of cooperation. It is not simply a cooperation between the two major political parties—and I exclude the Democrats because they are about to embark on a stunt which has little substance. It is interesting to see this cooperation between government and industry, between political parties, between government and consumers, and between industry and consumers in Australia and of course between governments around the world. Virtually all the players have moved to accept that there is a significant problem which needs remedial action and each has chosen to play its part in a most constructive way.

Actions by consumers in Australia, by the way, have in effect been in advance of the legislative requirements—and I commend consumers for that. This consumer led movement has encouraged manufacturers to label products as being `non-CFC'. In fact, it was seen by manufacturers as a positive marketing mechanism proudly to say that they do not have CFCs in them. That sort of cooperation has led to the sort of movement whereby Australia is quite properly and successfully taking positive measures to resist this movement.

What are the Australian Democrats doing in this situation? Here we have agreement between industry and consumers. We have agreement between the Government and the Opposition. We have agreement internationally to resolve this matter, through protocols and so on. And this legislation has to be passed by tomorrow because that is the very last day for the legislation to pass so that Australia can ratify the 1990 changes to the Montreal protocol in the time allowed. If the Democrats did not know that, they ought to know it.

What the Democrats are doing here is setting out on a diversionary stunt. In fact, they are tainting—I suppose one could almost say polluting—this argument, this clear sense of agreement and this clear thrust towards improving the situation; they are polluting it with a side issue. I will say why this is a side issue. It might be an issue of major substance to the Democrats, but it is a matter of major disagreement which they are now seeking to introduce into an area of absolute, overwhelming consensus where here we are in a parliament achieving an important objective which will cease the damaging impact on the ozone layer of CFCs.

The Democrats are trying to drag into this situation the very general question of the problems of atmospheric pollution. They are trying to include the greenhouse effect—which, by the way, has created and is still creating massive scientific disagreement—and other matters. They are trying to impose these things on a situation where this Parliament is almost unanimous in resolving a clear and significant matter which must be resolved by tomorrow.

I do not know what the Democrats' objective is. I merely note that the terms of their proposed amendment seem to follow straight down the line the briefing that they no doubt have achieved from the Australian Conservation Foundation. Many of the words in this stunt seem to be very similar. I do not know whether they regard that as their constituency. All I say about this is that the purpose of this Democrat amendment that we are dealing with now is to bring hydrochlorofluorocarbons—that is, HCFCs—under the same regimen of control and phase them out in the same way as would apply to CFCs. In other words, here we have a situation where, to solve our ozone problems, we have the opportunity of manufacturers moving into what is understood to be an acceptable, even if temporary, solution, at least in terms of the ozone problem—

TALK.START.PARA: —Your ignorance knows no bounds, Senator.

—I am glad the Democrats say my ignorance knows no bounds. Maybe they can disagree with the scientific evidence; I am quite happy for them to do so. But here we have agreement for many people—not all of them, but it appears likely to be 40 per cent or so of current CFC users—to move to HCFCs. As I have said, this probably will be on a temporary basis while technological change develops, along with the adaptability of equipment to other forms—for example, to just HFCs which are not at this stage readily available overall.

PARA.TAB: This temporary and very useful solution to the problem of CFCs is being attacked by the Democrats as somehow disgraceful. It is extraordinary that a solution being pressed for by tomorrow for the problem we face on CFCs, a solution which will reduce the danger of CFCs, is being attacked, basically, by the Australian Democrats. They will have to put an extremely strong case to demonstrate that there is any merit whatsoever in their undermining of this move out of CFCs by blocking the use of what is generally regarded as an acceptable but temporary solution.

I do not want to speak at great length, but there is no doubt that the industry—which is in total agreement with the Government and the Opposition—sees the Democrat proposal as premature and unwarranted. It says that no assessment has been made that would justify this and that to impose a control regime on these substances would be asking for trouble in that the problems experienced with regulating quotas for CFCs would most probably be repeated. The fact is that the changes to the Act provided for in this legislation will give the Government greater freedom to operate in the future.

If the Democrats think there is a real risk in this and are concerned about it, I wonder whether they are aware of the fact that the changes to the Act provided for in this legislation will give the Government greater freedom to operate in the future; for example, by regulation. They could include HCFCs at any time in the future by regulations which would in fact come before this Parliament for disallowance, if necessary, or acceptance.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are aware of that, yes.

—They are aware of it; that is a massive concession. If they are aware of the fact that this Parliament could respond to any overwhelming evidence by regulation under this Act, why are they seeking to disrupt—and they will not succeed, I might say—the passing of this legislation which has universal, overwhelming support by the two major parties in this place? It will survive; it will be passed, despite their stunt. Why are they doing something which, if they were successful, would cause a great deal of difficulty for some legislation which ratifies a specific agreement and which must be done by tomorrow?

PARA.TAB: As for the Democrats' proposed amendment to change the name of the legislation to the `Atmosphere Protection Act', it simply cannot be done and they know it. I am glad to see that throughout industry there is an agreement—the Democrats may say it is reluctant, but there is an agreement and there is consensus—about getting rid of these CFCs which do create a problem for ozone.
The Minister for the Arts and Territories (Ms Fatin) in the other place, in response to Mr Chaney, who is our spokesman there, acknowledged:

SPEECH.PARA: The regulations will only be made in response to changes in the protocol which follow comprehensive scientific assessment and international negotiations and which take place every two years.

If the position of the Democrats has any substance, it will be discussed in November at the international protocol meeting. Why do the Democrats have some special insight that people who have been involved in this have not yet had and where the issue can be determined quite properly at the November meeting? Regulations, as I said, can be and will be made only in response to changes in the protocol which follow comprehensive scientific assessment and international negotiations. If the Democrats are fearful that comprehensive scientific assessment will not demonstrate their particular position, I can understand their trying to muck up this bit of legislation. I cannot see any other rational reason for their bunging on this stunt. In that situation, the Opposition totally supports the Government's legislation on this matter and commends it to the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just witnessed the most incredible demonstration of lack of knowledge in this area that it has ever been my misfortune to listen to. The scientific evidence in relation to ozone depletion from HCFCs is well established; it is on the record. The Australian Democrats have no intention at all of holding up the Ozone Protection Amendment Bill, as indicated by the previous speaker, Senator Michael Baume.

PARA.TAB: If we recognise that we have a very damaging technology and that there is the need to move to a new technology, it is demonstrably stupid to make an investment of billions of dollars in a technology which one already knows is only temporary. Senator Baume has agreed that the HCFC technology is only temporary. HCFCs certainly have less ozone depleting potential than CFCs, but it is well established that they have that ozone depleting potential. Almost certainly, very shortly HCFCs will come under consideration and will be included. If in the meantime Australia has spent millions, possibly billions, of dollars—certainly tens of billions of dollars worldwide—going down the HCFC road, we have done our dough. The one thing that we are trying to achieve in this is not to go up blind alleys.

CFCs, like HCFCs, are very potent greenhouse gases and are altering the characteristics of the global atmosphere very significantly. HCFCs, while not containing any chlorine, are nonetheless very potent greenhouse gases. We are very concerned that we take a broader view of this question. We should move beyond the question simply of ozone depletion and look at the question as one of continual and exacerbating damage to the global atmosphere and seek to put in place a series of industrial changes which will comprehensively address that.

It is certainly true that in this context this Bill is giving effect to the updated Montreal Protocol. However—and I make this point again—those international agreements into which Australia has entered set only minimum standards. They do not mean that Australia cannot go further in seeking to include substances which are not yet in the schedules—substances which are recognised as being ozone depleting and as being potent greenhouse gases. Australia certainly can go further and, in the process, establish some industries which would be extremely useful to this country.

If HCFCs are only 5 per cent as ozone depleting as CFCs, and if we are to go down the road of establishing an industry exporting refrigeration into China—and as I reminded the Senate when I put up my first Bill, which preceded the Government's Bill by quite some time, China has 60 times our population—the damage to the global ozone from HCFCs will far exceed that which now exists from CFCs. For the reasons of the very large capital investment necessary to use these alternatives, it is very important that we do not go down blind alleys. We have gone down too many blind alleys with industry in this country in recent years.

The Democrats are supporting the purpose of this Bill. There is no question that we are not supporting it. We are seeking, however, to broaden the application of the Bill. We believe that is absolutely appropriate, given the fact that there is continual, accelerating and exacerbating change in the global atmosphere from a whole range of gases, CFCs being only one of them.

In relation to ozone depletion, the situation is indeed more serious than the models have indicated hitherto. Michael Kurylo, a research manager at the National Aeronautical and Space Administration, was prompted recently to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Everybody should be alarmed about this.
That is, the increase in the ozone damage beyond that which was expected. He continued:
We're seeing conditions primed for ozone destruction. It's in a far worse way than we thought.

We are dealing with a problem that, together with the greenhouse effect, must be regarded as the gravest problem facing human kind today, and one that has profoundly worrying implications for future generations. It is not just ozone depletion we are talking about; we are perturbing the composition of the global atmosphere in ways without any former precedents throughout history. For this reason, we must ensure that legislation is passed which will minimise further thinning of the ozone layer and damage in other respects.

PARA.TAB: The development of the ozone layer was an essential ingredient before which life on dry land could not exist. We need to recognise that tearing that protective layer away leads to a situation in which life on land may well become increasingly more difficult.

The ozone hole over the Antarctic came as a shock to the scientific community. Senator Baume talked about the good behaviour of those who use CFCs as propellants in cans. They were dragged screaming to that situation and they have now sought to make a virtue of necessity. It took four or five years for them to even recognise that there was a problem. They resisted, as does Senator Baume, the scientific evidence in relation to global atmospheric damage and change.

We have beyond the ozone hole over the Antarctic the recent unexpected and extremely grave discovery of very significant ozone depletion over more populous regions in north America, Asia and Europe. In early February, NASA announced the highest levels of ozone depleting chemicals ever recorded over north America. The result was swift action by the Bush Administration to accelerate the phase-out of CFCs and halons. Therein is another interesting observation: the American Government, as we have seen in the way it has addressed the UNCED conference, will not do anything unless it sees it in its interest. We demand a much more holistic approach to these issues than we are seeing from either this Government or the US Government.

The ozone layer is thinning at all latitudes, including the tropics, where significant and unexpected losses have recently been discovered. Globally, it is estimated that there has been a loss of approximately 2.5 per cent in the ozone layer. The potential impact of ozone loss on world food production is enormous. According to the CSIRO Division of Plant Industry, under high ultraviolet B radiation, photosynthesis in certain plants, particularly wheat, sorghum and peas—essential crops for human nutrition for future generations—can be severely affected .

Research from overseas has found that ultraviolet radiation can also stunt the growth of pine trees and cause damage to marine phytoplankton—which, I remind the Senate, is the world's largest sink for carbon from the atmosphere, and that is the important intersection between ozone depletion and the greenhouse effect. Marine phytoplankton act as such a sink that some five billion tonnes of carbon dioxide is taken up in that source every year. To the extent that it sinks into the deep ocean, it sequesters carbon out of the atmosphere. Loss of phytoplankton can therefore gravely accelerate the problem of global warming.

The alarming concentration of ozone-depleting chemicals in the atmosphere calls for an approach to their control on the precautionary principle—a principle which, clearly, Senator Baume does not accept or probably does not even understand—the fundamental principle on which ecologically sustainable development is built. The precautionary principle reverses the onus of proof. Instead of waiting for scientific certainty, instead of waiting until the environment is irreparably damaged, if there are reasonable grounds for believing that the environment is being damaged, then action can be taken to ensure that it does not happen. It protects the environment against environmental damage on the balance of probabilities because this planet is the only habitable planet in our corner of the universe.

That brings me to the Bill which is before us. As I have said, the Democrats support the dual aims of this legislation, namely: to give effect to the amendments of the Montreal Protocol; and, to enable Australia to ratify the amended protocol. However, we would observe, as Senator Baume has observed, that this is the last day on which Australia would be allowed to do that. Rather than praising the actions of the Australian Government, I point out that it has been particularly tardy in not having moved with this legislation much earlier.

The Democrats support the extension of the quota control system provisions of the Act to encompass the 10 additional CFCs and trichloromethane—colloquially called methylchloroform. We also support the introduction of a restricted licence system for carbon tetrachloride and for the export of halons and trichloromethane. However, we have two major concerns with the Bill as it currently stands. The first relates to the class of chemicals called the HCFCs—the hydrochlorofluorocarbons. The second relates to the chemicals called the hydrofluorocarbons. The Bill before us requires that importers and manufacturers of HCFCs report on the quantities being imported or manufactured. There is an urgent need for this reporting. I have found it impossible to collect data on current levels of HCFC usage in Australia. However, I believe that the Bill should go further and adopt a truly precautionary approach to CFC replacement.

That brings me to the crux of this issue. As pressure mounts to phase out CFCs, industry has sought to develop replacements which are more benign to the ozone layer. Industry has already begun to invest millions of dollars in the development of HCFCs and HFCs. HFCs do not contain chlorine, as I explained earlier, and are therefore not ozone-depleting. On the other hand, HCFCs do contain the damaging chlorine atom. A few years ago the HCFCs were hailed as being the answer to the CFCs. Although they still depleted the ozone layer, it was thought that their impact was negligible. It has now come to light that the HCFCs are three to five times more damaging than previously thought. It is estimated that CFC-11 and CFC-12 remain in the stratosphere for between 75 and 150 years. It was previously thought that the HCFCs remained in the stratosphere for an average of eight years. However, researchers from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration reported last year in the Journal of Physical Chemistry that this has now been extended to 13 years. The Washington-based Institute for Energy and Environmental Research has found that HCFCs are 95 per cent less ozone-depleting than CFCs only if it is assumed that the alternatives release chlorine at the same slow rate. The HCFCs, of course, degrade more rapidly and free chlorine faster than previously thought. The Institute's report calls for a phase-out of HCFC-22—which has been in common use for many years—by the year 2005, 25 years earlier than the planned US phase-out date.

Some companies have already responded to the growing international concern about HCFCs. The German company Hoechst, for example, has decided not to proceed with the production of these chemicals, although it is considering going ahead with the production of the HFCs depending upon the results of toxicity tests. American Democrat Senator Albert Gore has said:

SPEECH.PARA: It's a mistake to replace one ozone-destroying chemical with another. Any added increments at this point represent true insanity.
Across the Atlantic, the UK Stratospheric Ozone Review Group reported in 1991 as follows:
Anything other than modest substitution of HCFCs and CFCs could both increase the peak chlorine loading and sustain for decades unprecedented levels of stratospheric chlorine.

Certainly, there will be major costs involved in phasing out HCFCs. However, the earlier a phase-out date is established the lower the costs will be. That is why we are seeking to move to not allow this substitution to occur at this time by including them in the schedule.

PARA.TAB: The Bill before this chamber allows the Minister, as Senator Baume has said, to use regulations rather than legislative amendments to respond to future amendments to the protocol. This would allow the Minister to include by regulation HCFCs in the list of scheduled substances. However, Australia would regain its prominence in international efforts to control ozone-depleting substances if it adopted unilaterally a phase-out date for HCFCs and would at the same time gain a significant advantage for Australian industry in so doing by making the obvious next jump in its industrial development. This prominence has been considerably dented by the tardiness of the Government in getting the amendments to the protocol into this chamber—a matter to which I referred just a moment ago.

Accordingly, I will move an amendment to include HCFCs under the licensing system established by the Principal Act and extended by this amending Bill. That means that HCFCs would no longer be defined as `transitional substances', a transition which, I believe, we should and can avoid.

I now turn to the question of HFCs. Du Pont (Australia) announced at a recent ozone conference in Canberra that, ultimately, all industry must be using HCFs. That might be good news for the ozone layer, as HFCs do not destroy ozone, but it is bad news for the greenhouse effect. That is because HFCs—and HCFCs, for that matter—have significant global warming potential. It is critical that we respond to ozone depletion in a way that does not add to our problems elsewhere in the environment. If we take the precautionary principle seriously, then we must not allow industry to move in this environmentally damaging direction.

In this connection I point out that for well over 100 years we have had a technology—a very energy-efficient technology—which would allow us to totally avoid this transition, and that is the technology for refrigeration which is dependent upon ammonia. Ammonia is a substance which is readily available and manufactured in Australia. It is cheap. Most large commercial refrigeration establishments have already used it for well over 100 years and still continue to use it. Of course, the smaller domestic refrigerators, which are dependent upon either gas or kerosene for their motive power, still use that technology. It is a technology that could be well and truly exported into China in large amounts to Australia's advantage if we were to substantially increase the manufacturing capability of that industry.

Because the HFCs are not ozone-destroying but do represent a significant threat to the atmosphere, I would seek to change the title of the Bill, as Senator Baume suggested, to make it the Atmosphere Protection Act. That would open the door to many more reforms to protect the atmosphere from the enhanced greenhouse effect of this and other substances.

The Democrats recognise the progress made by industry to phase out the CFCs. Obviously, it is not cheap for industry to wean itself off ozone depleting substances, particularly in refrigeration, but there are the substitutes which I have just mentioned. Mr Bob Worthington, who is the Chair of the Industrial Refrigeration Workshop, at a conference in Canberra just recently said:

SPEECH.PARA: To date ammonia has been used mainly in large industrial refrigeration plant such as freezer stores, abattoirs and breweries. Ammonia systems can be used in almost all cooling applications including industrial cooling, air conditioning, supermarkets, etc.

Ammonia is already part of everyday life as it is used in many household cleaners. It is a natural substance totally biodegradable, non carcinogenic, non ozone-depleting and contributes nothing to Greenhouse warming.

Other advantages are that ammonia is low cost, made in Australia, the skills to use it are readily available in Australia, no new technical developments are required and its efficiency has been proved for over a century.
I stress that the energy requirements of an ammonia refrigerator are much less because the ability to transfer heat requires the transfer of less mass through the compressor system.

PARA.TAB: The export of HCFCs and HFCs to developing countries is another pressing concern. I have already mentioned that China has 60 times our population. We must, if we are sane and sensible, make all reasonable efforts to prevent China from going down the CFC or the HFC road. We would be well advised to attempt to build an industry which could readily export ammonia based refrigerators into China. That would be of enormous benefit to the industry of this country and, of course, to future generations of Australians because of the potential damage that the large number of Chinese using refrigeration based on other systems could do the global atmosphere.

The potential for HCFC use in the developing world is enormous. Therefore, it is imperative that industrialised countries develop technology and financial cooperation programs which promote ecologically sustainable development. We should be substantially increasing our foreign aid program and specifically directing it towards technology transfer in this area. Ozone protection policies in the north will be of limited value once developing countries start to rapidly escalate their use of ozone depleting substances simply because they cannot import cleaner and more expensive technologies.

Australia can develop a cheaper and better technology and we should be doing it. We must put in place policies that prevent developing countries becoming dependent on the importation of HCFCs and HFCs. We must do this as much out of concern for social equity as out of concern for the environment. At the next review of the Montreal Protocol, the Australian delegation should propose that the 10-year delay for developing countries to phase out ozone depleting substances be brought forward by five years. This must, however, be done in conjunction with the provision of increased resources to developing countries and accelerated environmentally sound and socially just technology cooperation and transfer programs.

It is vital that we adopt an ecologically sustainable development approach to the development of alternative technologies, that we do not continue to go up these blind alleys up which the Opposition, if Senator Baume is any indication, would take us. We must look beyond the limits of present international agreements, and identify and so avoid the several very expensive blind industrial alleys that now open before us and into which we may be led unless we take this longer view. We should base such an approach not on the narrow confines of ozone depletion in isolation but, rather, on a broad concern for protection of the global atmosphere. We have an opportunity to develop and export new industrial developments which would move Australia and the Third World together towards a greater level of sustainability.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Effectively, the Ozone Protection Amendment Bill is designed to update the Australian legislation with respect to ozone protection in accordance with the amendment to the Montreal Protocol on substances that deplete the ozone layer which was adopted by the parties to the protocol in London on 27-29 June 1990. The major aim of the amendment and, therefore, of the Bill, is to add substances which have been proven to be ozone depleting to the list of controlled substances.

PARA.TAB: During debate in the House of Representatives, there was bipartisan agreement to the Bill. The honourable member for Pearce pointed to this fact during debate on this Bill in the other place on 28 April when he stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I think there is a lack of public understanding of the extent to which on major environmental issues there is bipartisan support for the action which is to be taken by government.

Regrettably, however, the Green position on it is that it may well be bipartisan willingness to not do enough with regard to the problem of ozone protection. This bipartisan agreement only serves to illustrate the fact that the major parties are not prepared to address the fundamental issues associated with such global environmental issues as ozone depletion.

PARA.TAB: The Greens' approach to ozone and to other environmental issues of this nature is to examine the fundamental causes of the problem and propose solutions that address these causes rather than treat the symptoms. Technological fixes that only address the symptoms will not solve the fundamental problems caused by the depletion of the ozone layer. A reappraisal of our lifestyle and its impact on the environment is required. These amendments merely detail technical aspects that allow us to agree with the legislation and, as has been pointed out, not fall behind in our commitment with other countries to move towards ozone protection.

The whole rationale behind air-conditioning is an example of how lifestyle reappraisal and its impact needs to be part of our thinking when we are addressing the problem of ozone depleting substances in our society. We need to question the rationale behind it. Why do we need air-conditioning? It is largely because the homes and buildings in which we live and work are not properly designed to withstand extremes of temperature. It is interesting to note that the Commonwealth Government has been researching in this area for many years and has published guidelines for buildings that are efficient in this regard, but there has been no legislation established to encourage builders and owners to follow the guidelines or to penalise those who design and build inefficient buildings.

This leads to the related question of the greenhouse effect. Buildings that are badly designed and, therefore, require air-conditioning are, by definition, energy inefficient and consequently add to greenhouse problems. Also, if HFCs are used as replacements for CFCs and other ozone depleting substances, the greenhouse problem is potentially worsened because HFCs are a greenhouse gas. These facts point to the inherent interconnectedness of these sorts of issues and to the need for a broader policy perspective than the one we are discussing today.

If we solve the ozone problem but exacerbate the greenhouse effect we have effectively achieved nothing. The short term, reductionist and bandaid approach of both major parties is ineffective in approaching such fundamental and complex issues as ozone and greenhouse. The most appropriate analogy in this regard is to equate the ozone problem to that of a person with a heart problem. Given their track record in this regard, the major parties would advocate bypass surgery and drug treatment until the patient finally dies—a protraction of life, perhaps, with reduced quality. The Greens would advocate an approach which stresses the need for a fundamental reappraisal of the patient's lifestyle and the ultimate causes of the heart problem.

I will cite three examples of involvement I have had with the community with regard to our ozone protection legislation. Firstly, I will cite Mr Aston of New South Wales who wrote to me and probably to many other people in this place imploring us to address three issues with great urgency. I agree with at least two of his issues and I can summarise the third. I quote from his letter to honourable senators as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: I am writing to you and your brethren, as, unlike everyone else in Australia, I care about what happens to my children.

PARA.TAB: I read an article in Time Magazine of 17 February 1992 about how the ozone layer has been depleted to such an extent that it may be too late to repair the damage. It went on to say that an ozone hole may be about to appear over Europe and showed a recent satellite photo of a large `cloud' of chlorine over that Continent. Of course, this is additional to the existence of the Antarctic ozone hole, which gets closer to Australia every year.

Even if that article is only partly accurate, the inhabitants of this planet are in a lot of trouble. I hope that I am not insulting your intelligence by saying that all life depends on the existence of the ozone layer. Plant life is particularly vulnerable to increased ultraviolet radiation. On the other hand, most people seem to think that the problem can be avoided by purchasing a pair of sunglasses.

I find it rather amazing, therefore, that the Government continues to allow companies to manufacture and import CFC's. If politicians in this country had any conscience at all, CFC's would have been banned in 1974 when their full potential was realised or as soon as possible thereafter. The future of the world is at stake!

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Aston urges the immediate banning of CFCs, the banning of imports from countries that have not signed the Montreal Protocol and the exertion of very strong efforts to combat the existing problem. His solution is to exert pressure on the US Government. I might say that I have less faith in the US Government's concerns in this regard than he has.

PARA.TAB: The second example I wish to cite is a group of Western Australian individuals who are involved in all aspects of the air-conditioning industry, both manufacture and retail. These people have shown remarkable responsibility in gathering together to consider the impact of their industry upon the overall environment. They have made some suggestions which they are pursuing at State level, but they are suggestions which deserve our consideration.

They point out that there is no licensing program for people who handle CFCs. Quite irrespective of the import and export regulations that are being dealt with here, the aspect of the handling of those CFCs that are already circulating within our community has been neglected. They recommend that education be provided to all people who are likely to be working in this area. They also point out that uniform licensing regimes and procedures do not exist throughout Australia. For example, there are none in Western Australia and varying standards apply in Victoria and New South Wales.

A final suggestion which springs from their initiative is to ask why we are not looking at incentives for companies which responsibly take measures to recycle and handle with great care the CFCs that currently exist within our industry. These people are taking constructive steps to face the future of their industry, keeping in mind the benefits to all of us, as well as making sensible and responsible planning decisions for themselves.

The third example is the work of the Australian Conservation Foundation and the very practical suggestions that are being made of the areas at which our legislation should be looking. There needs to be mandatory labelling of all goods which use ozone depleting substances in their manufacture. This involves electrical goods, furniture foams and whitegoods. Apparently, the USA is taking some initiatives in this regard and has legislation which, although moving very slowly, is moving in that direction and ahead of us. The second recommendation from the Australian Conservation Foundation is that the concept of essential use should be looked at, and we should ensure that ozone depleting substances are used only where ozone benign technology is not available. That goes alongside the encouragement to develop alternative technologies.

In relation to the export of scheduled substances, the international perspective on this issue should also not be ignored. If the technology replacement approach to this problem is continued, it is likely that much of the old technology that has caused ozone depletion will be exported to Third World countries to maximise profits for multinational companies which have large stocks of equipment and consumables that have become unacceptable in industrialised countries. Developed countries such as Australia should be committing funds to develop alternative technologies that are inherently friendly to the environment and assisting in exporting that technology to Third World nations. As Senator Coulter mentioned, green technology transfer is an area where Australia has a very great potential to contribute.

I am also aware that the Australian Conservation Foundation and other non-government organisations have recently written to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly) concerning the ozone issue and the Government's response to the forthcoming meetings of the Montreal Protocol. There needs to be greater community input allowed and encouraged, and resources supplied for community members and non-government organisations to participate at all levels of the ozone debate, including the Montreal Protocol process.

In order to facilitate a more fundamental reappraisal of the ozone problem and of the policy approaches suggested by the various community and business groups with an interest in this topic, I suggest that the Government gives serious and immediate consideration to some of the more fundamental solutions to this problem and encourages ways of community participation within it. Specifically, I would like to suggest that the Government investigate alternative technologies, designs or procedures that avoid altogether the need for ozone depleting substances and methods by which these alternatives could be implemented in the community. In addition, consideration should be given to the opportunities for Australian industry with respect to these alternative technologies and the best method by which government can encourage the manufacture and adoption of these technologies by industry.

The opportunity exists for Australia to become a world leader in the field of alternative technologies and processes, with the attendant benefits to the nation's trade balance and the unemployment figures, as well as the state of the environment. The choice exists for us to continue to follow the herd or take the initiative on this important issue. I trust that the Government will support my suggestions and those of the Democrats in working towards effecting a sustainable future for this planet. I certainly support this Bill and, along with the Democrats, urge for a broadening of the approach to the problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—The Ozone Protection Amendment Bill 1992 is quite a complex scientific Bill. I have a very extensive knowledge of these particular matters, but I have always had the problem of trying to put them in terms that laymen like Senator Coulter would understand. I hope he bears with me during my response.

PARA.TAB: In general, on behalf of the Government I wish to thank the Senate for the general bipartisan support that this Bill has attracted. Australia has much to be proud of, having already phased out over 50 per cent of its use of CFCs since 1986. Much of this success has been due to our ability to focus clearly on ozone depletion and avoid confusion with other important, but separate, atmospheric protection issues. Hydrofluorocarbons are not ozone depleters. The Ozone Protection Amendment Bill is thus not an appropriate place for provisions on HFCs. To attempt to merge the two issues at this stage by broadening the ambit of the Bill may place at risk our ability to make continued gains in ozone protection.

An atmosphere protection Bill would bring with it the need to consider a very wide range of additional issues. Apart from any other factors, the mechanisms to protect the ozone layer are much further advanced than other atmospheric issues. Time delays in amending this Bill would prevent one of the principle objectives of the Bill, namely to allow Australia to ratify the 1990 Montreal Protocol before the meeting of the parties in November 1992.

One of the principal issues in the amendments proposed by the Democrats, namely the control measures for hydrochlorofluorocarbons—HCFCs for short—is already being considered in the context of the renegotiation of the Montreal Protocol on substances which deplete the ozone layer. It is important that the measures taken by Australia are consistent with such international regimes. We will, of course, be putting into place whatever control measures for HCFCs are adopted under the Montreal Protocol following the November 1992 meeting of the parties which, in any event, will only be a short while after this Bill passes into domestic law. The provisions of this Bill already take into account Montreal Protocol requirements for reporting HCFC consumption. This will form a basis for the introduction in Australia of control mechanisms to meet Australia's obligations under the Montreal Protocol.

It is also important to ensure that the detail of any control regime for HCFCs in Australia not only meets our international obligations for ozone protection but is also appropriate to the circumstances of Australian industry. The Government would wish to maintain the cooperative approach which has been so productive until now. This means that any control regime has to be developed in consultation with those affected, not simply imposed through legislation without prior consultation. I wish the Bill a speedy passage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the fact that we all recognise the need to get this legislation through tonight, I wonder whether honourable senators would be content if I were to speak briefly to all the amendments, move them all at once and just have the one division. I see the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) nodding.

PARA.TAB: In moving these amendments, I simply point out that, in view of what the Minister has just said, nothing in these amendments makes the legislation inconsistent with our international agreements; they are simply to take the matter several steps further, recognising that almost certainly those steps will be taken very shortly. As already indicated, the HCFCs are likely to be brought under an umbrella in the meetings in November of the protocol nations.

The essential point is that, in moving the amendments in the way that we are, we are seeking to close off as quickly as possible the use of those alternative substances, the technologies of which they form a part and the very substantial capital investments required if we go down that road. In that way, industry gets a very clear message as early as possible as to which way we need to go and, therefore, is encouraged to move into those alternative technological pathways which do not pose significant environmental damage.

I stress—and I am pleased to have heard Senator Chamarette also make this point—that it places Australia in a very good position to help others, particularly Third World countries, so that they do not go down the very disastrous roads that they are virtually right on the edge of going down now. The sooner that a very clear signal is given to industry that HCFCs and HFCs are not a solution, the better.

On the one hand, HCFCs pose an ozone depleting potential, given the high probability that there will be a massive expansion in refrigeration use around the world in Third World countries. The HFCs pose very significant greenhouse gas problems. Either of those substances will be recognised as damaging and will eventually be legislated against. Consequently, it is very sensible to send the strongest possible message to industry that those technologies are to be discouraged. Hopefully, by dealing with this on a broadcast day, part of what I have said will help to deliver that sort of message. It would be disastrous for this country and for the world if we were to create such problems.
I seek leave to move all the amendments standing in the name of the Australian Democrats. We will be seeking to divide on them, but I will not seek to divide them up.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know there is a football match being shown on the television, but I think the issue about which I wish to speak this evening takes precedence over football. I will not detain the Senate for very long. This time last week we were debating a special motion to mark the commemoration of 25 years since the passing of the referendum recognising Aboriginal people in this country. Just seven days later, we have a landmark decision with the High Court ruling today that the traditional land rights of the Murray Island people in the Torres Strait have not been extinguished by the arrival of the British in Australia.

PARA.TAB: This is a landmark decision following a 10-year legal battle by Torres Strait Islanders claiming their rights to the islands that have never been extinguished, although the islands were annexed to Queensland in the late 1870s. The High Court has found that the common law of Australia recognises a form of native title which reflects the entitlements of indigenous inhabitants. However, the decision does not mean a recognition of land rights throughout Australia as the High Court decided that its declaration would affect only the Murray Island claim. The land rights of Murray Islanders will also be subject to Queensland law as long as the State law does not contradict Commonwealth law. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the order from the High Court.
Leave granted.
The order read as follows—

EDDIE MABO AND ORSPLAINTIFFS

PARA.TAB: In lieu of answering the questions reserved for the consideration of the Full Court,

SPEECH.PARA: (1)declare that the land in the Murray Islands is not Crown land within the meaning of that term in s.5 of the Land Act 1962 (Q.);

(2)putting to one side the Islands of Dauer and Waier and the parcel of land leased to the Trustees of the Australian Board of Missions and those parcels of land (if any) which have validly been appropriated for use for administrative purposes the use of which is inconsistent with the continued enjoyment of the rights and privileges of the Meriam people under native title, declare that the Meriam people are entitled as against the whole world to possession, occupation, use and enjoyment of the lands of the Murray Islands;
