TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. As the Federal Government representative on the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, I make reference to this landmark decision. The High Court decision to recognise traditional land rights in the Murray Islands is a major legal and social landmark in Australian history. I believe that it will pave the way for much more comprehensive recognition of Australia's indigenous people. I recognise that lawyers and, indeed, politicians will continue to scrutinise and evaluate the legal consequences of the High Court decision. The immediate effect of the decision will change Australian attitudes to indigenous people.

PARA.TAB: Until today, the law has upheld the principle of terra nullius; that is, that Australia was an empty, uninhabited land in 1788. But the High Court has now found that Australia's common law recognises a form of native title which, in the cases where it has not been extinguished, reflects the entitlement of the indigenous inhabitants in accordance with their land or customs to their traditional lands.

I believe it is important that the community keeps a perspective on the decision which recognises the rights of the indigenous people of the Murray Islands, whose occupation of the land has been continuous since British colonisation. I hope that we will not have scare campaigns, especially from members of parliament, because we have agreed to reconciliation. I hope that the media reports this case in the context in which it has been announced by the High Court and gives clear recognition to the fact that there are particular circumstances, particular reasons—historical and legal—for this case. I hope there will not be screaming headlines around Australia about land grabs. This is not a question of a land grab; it is a question of recognition of native title. The Murray Island people have had continuous occupation and association with their land. This has been upheld today in Australia; it has been upheld on previous occasions in the United States and in Canada.

Given the experience of the United States and Canada, it is likely that there will be claims from traditional communities, but I would emphasise that those claims will come from remote parts of the country. It is essential that both Federal and State governments closely examine the overseas precedents in the settlement of those claims.

I would like to take this opportunity to pay tribute to Eddie Mabo, his family and his community who have argued so persuasively for over 10 years to gain recognition of indigenous rights to native title to their traditional lands. It is a tragedy that Eddie Mabo died of cancer earlier this year and cannot celebrate his victory. His family can certainly celebrate the fact that his name will be significant from this day onwards in Australian history because this is a landmark case for Australia's indigenous people.

The final issue that I would like to make reference to is that from this day, schoolchildren can no longer be educated about Australia as being an empty land, as the archaeological and historical facts of Australia's indigenous people have finally been recognised, not just as they have been for many years by numerous people in the community, but finally within the law and from the highest court in the land.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly this evening to bring to the attention of the Senate a very interesting article in the Australian Financial Review of 2 June 1992. It is headed `Vic Offers Landmark Settlement to Farmers' and states:

PARA.TAB: The Victorian Government has offered a $1.75 million settlement to 51 potato farmers who claimed their land became contaminated with the chemical dieldrin, lawyers representing the farmers said yesterday.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a very interesting article. The pesticide in beef fiasco was current at about the time I was elected to the Senate. At that stage there was quite a debate. In Western Australia alone 35 farms were affected by the over application of heptachlor and dieldrin by the State Energy Commission of Western Australia. Some were also contaminated by the actions of Telecom. A lot of farms were contaminated by farmers themselves who applied dieldrin on the advice of the Department of Agriculture of Western Australia. The same applied in South Australia, although minimally, and Victoria, as this article points out. Some farms in New South Wales were affected as were some in Queensland.

PARA.TAB: These chemicals caused the pesticide in beef problem when our beef exports to the United States were cut off for some time. It took a long time to rectify and caused a lot of headaches for farmers who were not able to sell the stock that they had ready to turn off. Compulsory levies were brought in by different States to try to get over the problem. Nowhere along the line did the State governments, through the departments of agriculture which gave the go ahead for those chemicals to be used, pick up the responsibility. As well as the farms that I mentioned which were contaminated by Telecom and the SEC, there were scores of others where farmers used chemicals because they thought they were doing the right thing.

That problem goes back to 1987. I mentioned it briefly in my maiden speech. There was a further debate in December 1987 when the Senate finally decided to hold an inquiry into the use of agricultural chemicals in Australia. A lot of its recommendations have been put into place. There was no reference in that inquiry to compensation for these farmers who were badly hit by actions that were not of their own making. I am sure that the Government would not look at the question of compensation. We pleaded with the Democrats at the time. They continually refused us, so that reference to compensation was left out. These farmers in Victoria have battled for five years to get justice and they have some sort of justice as a result of that court decision.

I encourage the rest of the farmers of Australia who were affected to take up their cause. I point out to the State governments and their departments of agriculture which cleared these chemicals that had a built-up, adverse effect on the land: that effect is still there now. That land has been used for growing crops that are cut and taken off, rather than grazing stock. With this court action I certainly hope that all the departments of agriculture throughout Australia recognise their mistake, and encourage their governments to put these farmers right and award them the compensation that they should have had at that time.

I seek leave to have this newspaper article incorporated in Hansard. I cleared it with the Minister at the table before he departed. I can show it to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) if he so wishes.
Leave granted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Vic Offers Landmark Settlement to Farmers

PARA.TAB: The Victorian Government has offered a $1.75 million settlement to 51 potato farmers who claimed their land became contaminated with the chemical dieldrin, lawyers representing the farmers said yesterday.
The Victorian Farmers Federation said the farmers applied dieldrin between 1965 and 1987 on the advice of the State Department of Agriculture and Rural Affairs.
They claimed damages because their land was contaminated with dieldrin used by them on the advice of the department from 1985 to 1987, a federation spokesman, Mr Clay Manners, said.
Dieldrin was now generally banned for agricultural use because of its toxic effect on humans, he said.
The affected properties were mainly in the Geelong region's Bellarine Peninsula, and Gembrook in Melbourne's Dandenong Ranges.
Some were at Kinglake, north-east of Melbourne, and Erica in Gippsland.
Mr Manners said meetings would be held with the claimants who took part in a test case mounted in the Supreme Court of Victoria.
The offer came in talks yesterday between legal representatives of the federation and the Government, he said.
The State Minister for Agriculture, Mr Ian Baker, declined comment, saying the matter was still before the court.
The Dieldrin Action Group's chairman, Mr John Dawson, said the offer was an achievement for farmers.
"Many of these farmers have been deprived of a substantial part of their livelihood since 1987 and this settlement provides new hope," Mr Dawson said.
"It provides for a financial package of compensation to the farmers as well as a scheme to enable cattle to be put back on the land.
The result was achieved through the support of the federation and the Australian Farmers Fighting Fund.
"Despite the inroads in recent years on the ability of citizens to enforce their rights in the courts the settlement demonstrates that the common law is the best means of enforcing justice.
The offer would be recommended by the federation to the farmers and it was expected to be accepted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Senate to a longstanding and outrageous abuse of human rights. In any circumstances the story I am about to tell would cause anger and concern. This situation is perhaps even worse because the perpetrator of this particular abuse is a government body using an Act of this Parliament to justify its behaviour.

PARA.TAB: I will have to describe the citizen concerned as Mr Y because this saga is unfortunately not yet over. This person is an employee of Australia Post. During a long career with Australia Post he became aware of a number of activities regarding the awarding of contracts within his section. In his opinion, those contracts were not efficient and perhaps were even illegal. He reported these things and subsequently found himself under siege in his workplace. He was constantly reprimanded, passed over for promotion and made the subject of an ongoing campaign of verbal abuse.

He complained. The internal complaints procedures took over two years. In the meantime, Mr Y was forced to remain in an openly hostile environment, subject to the very people that he had complained about. He also felt the people were taking bribes and fixing tenders, in his words. They kept him advised about how well his appeal against them was going. He lost his appeal. He then suffered a complete physical and emotional collapse—what is commonly called a nervous breakdown. I am not surprised.

Since then he has been unable to go out alone or to be alone for long periods. He is easily distressed and when distressed he cannot even perform the simplest of tasks, such as remembering a phone number or making a telephone call. He finds most social interactions almost impossible and most physical activity difficult; he suffers from incontinence and is constantly on medication to ease his severe depression. He is a married man with children still at home, and this has been his life for the last eight years. Mr Y has been receiving a Comcare benefit for that time. It is the opinion of all the doctors and specialists who have examined him during those eight years that he will never be fit to work at Australia Post again. I have introduced this by way of background.

This story is not about what happened 10 or so years ago that led to the ruination of this man's life; it is about what Australia Post is presently doing to further damage this man, to make his life as miserable as possible and perhaps even lead to his death. Australia Post is using the Comcare legislation put in place by this Government. The Australian Democrats supported the legislation when it was before the Parliament because we believed strongly in the provision of fair and efficient rehabilitation and compensation for all Australian workers. We believe that the Government, as an employer, has a duty of care to lead the way in the provision of workers compensation.

At the time, however, we expressed our concern about Australia Post and Telecom being allowed to administer the Act for their own employees. We have continued to express our concern as more and more cases of harshness, discrimination, misconduct and harassment come to light. Australia Post and Telecom have used their new arrangements under Comcare to clear the books of long term claimants. They have consistently misused the monitoring provisions of the Act to justify phone tapping, surveillance by private detectives, the secret video taping of medical consultations and constant doctor shopping.

In one case reported to my office recently, a woman in Perth was sent to 50 separate medical appointments as part of her annual review. In theory, once these abuses had come to light it should have been a simple matter to stop them. But no, Comcare and the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) claim they have no authority to intervene. So the self-administrators, Australia Post and Telecom, go on their merry way failing to offer adequate rehabilitation programs, subjecting claimants to constant harassment, reinterpreting the Act to suit their financial agendas and denying people the compensation to which they are entitled and which they would get if they worked in any other part of the public sector. I stress that this is not so much a complaint about Comcare as about the self-administration by Australia Post and Telecom.

My office has been attempting to assist for some time now with some small success in the case of Mr Y, despite the aggressiveness and lack of cooperation by Australia Post in Western Australia, particularly its self-appointed vigilante, Mr Lippiat, and Australia Post's solicitors, Greenland Brooksby. I am a little at a loss for words because this has been occupying my office for some time and I am only just containing my anger about this. One would hope for the sake of the other clients of the solicitors that it too is being misled by Australia Post's delegate.

Each time someone intervenes to help, however, Mr Y is subjected to a further round of vicious harassment in the form of hostile letters and more doctors' appointments. I have already described his anxieties about venturing out and certainly going on his own. His review has been going on for some 18 months and has involved a minimum of three different doctors examining him each two months interspersed with threatening and accusatory letters. As of today, the campaign has extended to include Mr Y's attending psychiatrist. Australia Post appears to have decided that all of its long term compensation claimants and their doctors are crooks and cheats and treats them accordingly.

Mr Y's condition has deteriorated dramatically under this siege of officious ill will, as we can imagine would happen. Any reasonable person would assess immediately that such activity would cause his condition to deteriorate. He has been close to suicide on two occasions this year. His treating physician has twice called personally to my office to express his alarm and to ask for help. After the first of these calls I asked the Minister to intervene directly. The Minister's response was to appoint a senior officer from Comcare to oversee the case. Despite the diligence and competence of this officer, the harassment of Mr Y continues. It continues not because of the intervention of the officer but despite it.

Even despite the Minister's intervention, Australia Post continues to deal with Mr Y just as it always has done. Despite evidence of obvious bias and mishandling, the same case supervisor is still dealing with the case and the same chain of command remains intact. All that has changed is that Australia Post now has one more person in the chain to lie to while pursuing Mr Y to his grave. They have denied Mr Y access to his own files and have failed on at least three occasions to answer questions and provide material to the Commonwealth Ombudsman.

Mr Y's mental and physical condition continues to deteriorate as he remains under pressure. In fact, Australia Post has taken to suspending his benefit in anticipation of his not meeting its ever-increasing demands to attend extra medical appointments while it tries to prove that this man, who is not capable of holding a conversation without shaking, crying and becoming totally disoriented, is secretly holding down a job as a language tutor. So long as in the end it can stop his pension permanently, Australia Post does not seem to care at all whether it has to withhold and falsify documents, lie, distort and harass or even drive a man to take his own life.

As I indicated a few moments ago, Mr Y's benefit was wrongfully suspended. Australia Post lied to Comcare's representative and to a member of my staff regarding the reinstatement of Mr Y's benefit, claiming there would be no suspension of his benefit. This was three weeks ago. Today, Mr Y rang my office in severe distress to inform me that he had not been paid and that he would not be reinstated because he and his doctor were `not being cooperative'. It took the threat of me making this speech and further action before the Human Rights Commission before Australia Post grudgingly reinstated the benefit today that it has wrongfully withheld from Mr Y for over a fortnight.

Mr Y's case is one of about 100 cases of improper behaviour by Australia Post and Telecom as self-administrators of the Comcare Act. The Democrats have brought this pattern of consistent abuse to the attention of the Minister and the executive management of Comcare. We have done that on a number of occasions. The Government has introduced legislation covering new administrative arrangements under which Australia Post and Telecom, now known as AOTC, will have to hold a licence to administer the Act. This will, so the Minister claims, give Comcare the power to intervene and take disciplinary action.

Even in the most cynical, economically pragmatic analysis, it does not make sense to allow enterprises which have spent their budgetary allocation for workers compensation for the last four years on private detectives and extravagant numbers of expert medical opinions. It is a nonsense to say that such an enterprise should be allowed to spend its budget in that way and claim that it is spending it wisely and to the benefit of the employees.

Cases such as the one I have brought to the Senate today, and the hundred or so other cases that have been brought to me, lead me to conclude that Australia Post and Telecom have proved themselves to be totally unsuitable to hold a licence, even if we could be sure that the new arrangements would mean tighter control.

It will be cold comfort to Mr Y and others like him, the majority of whom live in Minister Cook's own State of Western Australia, to license the abuses that Telecom and Australia Post now perpetrate. As victims of such grievous assault upon their rights as workers and human beings, it will be difficult to convince them that the proposed system will work or that justice denied them will not be denied others and that they will be offered some means of redress and compensation. It is very difficult to imagine, given the history that we have had presented to us—of which my story tonight is only a small part—that we can assume Australia Post and Telecom are capable of demonstrating a better attitude with these slight changes that are proposed in forthcoming legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the other place this morning, Mr Colin Hollis, the Chairman of the Public Works Committee, made a statement on behalf of the Committee in relation to the advanced air traffic system project, commonly known as TAAATs. I seek leave at this stage to incorporate the text of Mr Hollis's speech in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: AIR TRAFFIC SERVICES CENTRES, BRISBANE AND MELBOURNE

I wish to make a short statement to the House regarding the Public Works Committee's inquiry into the proposal by the Civil Aviation Authority to construct Air Traffic Services Centres at Brisbane and Melbourne. This project was referred to the Committee by the House on 26 February 1992.

Mr Speaker as I made clear at the Committee's first public hearing on 8 April the role of the Committee is to examine and report to the Parliament on the building works involved with the Australian Advanced Air Traffic System project (TAAATS). The main component of the TAAATS project is the consolidation of the five major air traffic control centres to two centres—Brisbane and Melbourne. The cost estimate of the building works when referred to the Committee was $50m.

I am sure that honourable members are aware that there has been considerable controversy regarding the CAA's decision to name Thomson Radar as the preferred contractor for TAAATS. The CAA has also announced that the Hughes Aircraft Company is the alternative contractor.

While the Committee has attempted to stay clear of issues relating to the TAAATS equipment contract it has proved to be impossible. In fact I stressed at the beginning of the inquiry that the Committee did not wish to involve itself in issues relating to the TAAATS equipment contract. The Committee's task has been made difficult due to the turnkey nature of the contract for the TAAATS project. Under the turnkey contract the successful contractor will also be responsible for the provision of the building works. This has presented the Committee with a situation where very few details of the building works have been available to it. However this is a matter on which the Committee will comment in detail in its report which will be tabled in the budget session.

It is true that the principal role of the Public Works Committee is to satisfy itself of the need for public works. However section 17 subsection 1b of the Public Works Committee Act while empowering the Committee to make a report to both Houses of the Parliament concerning the expedience of carrying out a public work also provides that the Committee may report to the Parliament concerning any other matters related to the work in respect of which the Committee thinks it desirable that the view of the Committee should be reported to the Parliament.

Despite arguments put by the CAA and an impertinent letter from the Chairman of the CAA Mr Butcher my Committee did not exceed its mandate. It is surprising that key officials of the CAA and key witnesses before a Parliamentary Committee did not bother to familiarise themselves with the role and duty of the Public Works Committee. My Committee found the comments by Mr Butcher impertinent and insulting as he attempted to lecture the Committee on its role—the members of the Public Works Committee are well aware of their role and duty and do not need to be to lectured by bureaucrats.

The Committee was also frustrated in the exercise of its duty by the unwillingness or inability of key CAA witnesses to answer relevant questions. Reluctantly the Committee conducted two in-camera hearings but even with this protection the CAA witnesses were still unwilling or unable to answer key questions. By refusing to answer these questions even in the general terms sought by the Committee the Public Works Committee finds itself in the position of being unable to fulfil its duty to this Parliament.

Mr Speaker the Committee believes it would be failing in its duty if it did not bring to the attention of the House the concerns which have been expressed during the Committee's inquiry regarding the CAA's decision to award the equipment contract to Thomson.
These concerns include:

PARA.TAB: .whether the Thomson equipment is the best available
.whether the selection process conducted by the CAA was "doctored" to favour the Thomson bid
.why the preference of the technical and operational evaluation teams for Hughes was overturned.

SPEECH.PARA: In these circumstances the Committee has decided to take the unprecedented step of recommending that the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support set up an independent panel to carry out a thorough review of all aspects of the awarding of this contract to Thomson.
This review should be completed as a matter of urgency so that the CAA can appoint a final contractor with a minimum of delay.
The Committee stresses that this issue is too important for it not to be settled as soon as possible.
The Committee feels that because of the serious concerns it has regarding the TAAATS project that it cannot report to the Parliament until this review is completed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Basically, Mr Hollis and the Public Works Committee have recommended that the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Cook) immediately appoint a tribunal, in their words, `to inquire into the awarding of the TAAATs contract to Thomson CSF'. Amongst the matters which they have raised as issues of concern are whether the Thomson equipment is the best available; whether the selection process conducted by the CAA was `doctored' to favour the Thomson bid; and why the preference of the technical and operational evaluation teams for Hughes was overturned.

PARA.TAB: This is a matter which has been raised by me and a number of my colleagues on both sides of the chamber for some considerable time. The recommendations of the Public Works Committee only go to prove that our concerns are very real and well held. I think, Mr Deputy President, both you and Senator Reynolds, whom I acknowledge is in the chamber, also have similar concerns about this matter and were willing to give up your time on an up evening to attend a very long and detailed briefing with the CAA. There are matters that have arisen as a result of that that are not satisfactory; I think that is generally agreed on all sides.

There is, on the Order of Business paper, a motion to refer this matter to a Senate committee. Whether that will be necessary will now depend on the actions of the Minister. I hope that the Minister will, as a matter of urgency, follow the recommendations of the Public Works Committee. This matter really needs to be addressed.

But I would just flag one thing to the Senate at this time: it must be a proper wide-ranging inquiry with the power to force production of evidence. Moreover, the evidence presented to that inquiry must attract the same privilege that would be attracted by evidence presented before a Senate inquiry. Matters have been raised with me by various people. Because they are so afraid of the consequences of saying the things that they know or feel to be true, they will not present this evidence unless they receive privilege. I think if this matter is to be properly investigated, all persons appearing before it and all evidence must attract privilege—even if it requires that certain of the proceedings of this investigation or tribunal be in camera.

It is very clearly the case that something has arguably gone seriously wrong. The Public Works Committee was mortified by the conduct of some of the officers who appeared before it. I do not believe, on examination of the Hansard, that their conduct was satisfactory. Mr Hollis indicated that it was not. In fact, he described the Chairman of the CAA as `impertinent'. I do note that the Chairman of the Committee says that the recommendation that this inquiry be set up is unprecedented. That is the magnitude of the problem. It is evidence that the things that many of us in this chamber have been saying for quite a while are well founded. It is now up to the Government to show its good faith and to act properly to set up the inquiry in the terms which I have recommended.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 31 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has Dr Geoffrey Duggin, Chairman of the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) Working Party on Cyclodience Insecticide Use in Australia, presented to the NHMRC the full report on cyclodience use in Australia; if not (a) when will the full report be presented; (b) will the public have an opportunity to make submissions on the report; if so, when and for how long; and (c) is it still anticipated that the final recommendations on the report will be made to the NHMRC at its next session, as stated in an NHMRC press release of 30 October 1991.

(2) With reference to Question on Notice No. 1366 (Senate Hansard, 26 November 1991, W3426): (a) how did the Pesticides and Agricultural Chemicals Standing Committee (PACC) `estimate' the Acceptable Daily Intakes (ADI) for the cyclodienes; and (b) did the PACC 'estimate' the ADI by referring to a toxicological evaluation of the cyclodience insecticides by: (i) the PACC itself, (ii) another NHMRC Committee (please specify), and (iii) an organisation outside the NHMRC (please specify).

(3) At the time of 'estimating' the ADI of the cyclodienes, was it the function of the PACC to determine the ADI of pesticides; if not, which NHMRC committee should have determined the ADI of the cyclodienes.

(4) Has the Committee of Toxicity of the NHMRC (a) addressed the problem of determining ADI for the cyclodienes; if so, what were its conclusions; if not, why not; and (b) determined ADI for the cyclodienes; if so, what are they; if not, why not.
(5) At present do official NHMRC ADI for the cyclodiene exist; if not, why not; if so, what are they.

(6) With reference to Questions on Notice Nos 567 (Senate Hansard, 14 May 1991, W3327) and 871 (Senate Hansard, 20 August 1991, W747), if Velsicol disclosed the presence of propylene oxide in heptachlor and chlordane on 14 March 1986, why did it take until July and August 1990 for the NHMRC to express concerns about the compound.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (a) and (c) It is intended to present the full report to the NHMRC at the 113th Session in June 1992 after public comments have been received and incorporated.

(b) The draft report on Cyclodiene Insecticide Use in Australia has been released for public consultation. On 18 January 1992 advertisements were placed in the Weekend Australian calling for public comment within 90 days. The draft report has also been drawn to the attention of relevant consumer and industry organisations.

(2) and (5) The Pesticides and Agricultural Chemicals Standing Committee (PACSC) of the NHMRC last reviewed the toxicology of aldrin, dieldrin, chlordane and heptachlor in May 1989 and agreed to continue to utilise the previously established ADI values which are based on the toxicological review of data. These are the same values as currently used by the Joint FAO/WHO Meeting on Pesticide Residues (JMPR):
aldrin/dieldrin 0.0001 mg/kg/day;
chlordane/heptachlor 0.0005 mg/kg/day.
(3) Yes. The consideration of an ADI is part of the process of estimating a Maximum Residue Limit (MRL) which is the responsibility of the PACSC.
(4) No. Consideration of ADIs is not within the "Terms of Reference" of the Standing Committee on Toxicity.

(6) The review of the toxicity of propylene oxide and its implication for the scheduling of formulated products in which it was a component, was initiated through the NHMRC Drugs and Poisons Schedule Standing Committee in late 1986. After consultation with industry, a process for an orderly phase out of propylene oxide was recommended. Initially this involved allowing products containing propylene oxide at less than 4% concentration to be listed as Schedule 6 poisons with those exceeding this placed in the more restrictive Schedule 7. Industry was advised that the restrictive Schedule 7 status would be applied to all products containing propylene oxide and encouraged to seek alternatives.

In 1990 the Schedule 7 status of propylene oxide was confirmed. The Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council (AAVCC) was advised of NHMRC concerns about this chemical and its presence as a contaminant in technical grade heptachlor and chlordane.
The action taken by the NHMRC in respect of propylene oxide was in response to studies involving this chemical alone and not as part of the re-assessment of cyclodiene pesticides.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 4 May 1992 with reference to Question on Notice No. 1367 (Senate Hansard, 25 February 1992 W112):

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) or any of its representatives given, officially or unofficially, an undertaking or an indication to (a) Standards Australia; (b) representatives of the pest control industry; and (c) the manufacturers/distributors of heptachlor/chlordane, that the outcome of the NHMRC's review of cyclodiene insecticides and their use in Australia, chaired by Dr Geoffrey Duggin, will be to recommend that the cyclodiene insecticides continue to be permitted to be used in Australia for the next five years; if the answer to (a) is yes, is the review of the data on the cyclodiene insecticides and their use in Australia chaired by Dr Duggin and the public consultation over Dr Duggin's draft report entitled Cyclodiene Insecticide Use in Australia, a cynical and unethical political exercise the outcome of which is a foregone conclusion.

(2) When did (a) the NHMRC; and (b) Dr Duggin, Chair of the Working Party to Prepare Report on Cyclodiene Insecticides, first become aware that a re-evaluation of the toxicology of the cyclodiene insecticides heptachlor and chlordane beginning in October 1990 was being undertaken by the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC).

(3) When did: (a) the NHMRC; and (b) Dr Duggin, Chair of the Working Party to Prepare Report on Cyclodiene Insecticides, first become aware of the outcome of the IARC re-evaluation, which was the classification of heptachlor and chlordane as animal carcinogens and possible human carcinogens.

(4) In relation to the draft report Cyclodiene Insecticide Use in Australia by Dr Geoffrey Duggin, the Chairman of the NHMRC Working Party to Prepare Report on Cyclodiene Insecticides: (a) on what date was the report released to the public and how long did it envisage as the public consultation period; (b) what was the official closing date for public submissions on the report; (c) how many times has the NHMRC Working Party chaired by Dr Duggin met; (d) who are the members of the Working Party to Prepare Report on Cyclodiene Insecticides; (e) what contribution did each member of the Working Party make to the writing of the draft report of the Chairman of the Working Party; (f) did the Working Party consider the first draft of the working party report before its release to the public; if not, why not; (g) will the Working Party as described in (d) review the comments received from the public as part of the public consultation period over the draft report Cyclodiene Insecticide Use in Australia; if not, why not; (h) will the working party meet before the report is finalised; if not, why not; and (i) what are the qualifications of Dr Geoffrey Berry of Sydney University.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a), (b) and (c) I am advised that no advice of this nature has been given. At its February 1992 meeting, Standards Australia Subcommittee BD/74 (Termite Control), whose membership includes representatives of the pest control industry, was advised by the Chairman of the NHMRC Working Party, Clinical Associate Professor Duggin, of the draft recommendations of the working party subsequent to the release of the draft report for public comment.

(2) and (3) The IARC Working Group in question met during 16-23 October 1990. I am advised that distribution of the IARC Monograph containing that working group's evaluation of chlordane and heptachlor was commenced on 24 February 1992 and was received in the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services in March 1992.

Several of the written comments on the draft NHMRC working party report drew attention to the IARC Monograph which was not available when that draft report was released for public comment in January 1992.
(4)(a) The availability of the report was advertised in The Weekend Australian on 18 January 1992 allowing for a 90 day public consultation period.
(b) 16 April 1992 although late responses were accepted until 12 May 1992.
(c) Two meetings on 15 May 1990 and 18 September 1990.
(d) Participating members of the working party were:
Clinical Associate Professor Geoffrey Duggin (Chairman), Head, Toxicology Unit, Royal Prince Alfred Hospital, Royal Alexandria Hospital for Children
Adjunct Associate Professor Ian Calder, Specialist—Toxicology/Organic Chemistry, Senior Scientific Officer, South Australian Health Commission
Dr Tony Watson, Termite Entomologist, CSIRO
Dr Gary Baker, Specialist Respiratory Physician—Pulmonary Toxicologist/Fellow of the Royal Australian College of Physicians—National Occupational Health and Safety Commission
Mr Ian Fraser, Land Use Environmentalist, Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations
Mr Geoff Cramp—Research Associate
Dr Edward McArdle, previously Director of Public Health, Tasmania.
Dr Peter Abbott, Toxicologist, Commonwealth Department of Health, Housing and Community Services.

Professor Geoffrey Berry, Professor of Epidemiology and Biostatistics, University of Sydney provided additional assistance in the evaluation of the epidemiological studies on health effects of chlordane and heptachlor.

(e) and (f) The draft report was a consolidation of a range of contributions made by members of the working party, plus others, whose involvement is acknowledged in pages 21-25 of the report. The draft was not reviewed in a formal meeting of the working party, but I am advised that a copy was provided to members before it was released.

(g) and (h) A new panel, based on the available participants of the original working party, was formed on the recommendation of the Public Health Committee on 12-13 March 1992 (confirmed by NHMRC Executive Committee on 27 March 1992) and will complete the evaluation of the public consultation responses to the draft report. The initial meeting of the panel was held on 13 May 1992.
(i) Professor Geoffrey Berry's qualifications are as follows:
MA, PhD (Cambridge), FIS, FACOM (HON.)

ANSWER.PARA: Professor Epidemiology and Biostatistics, University of Sydney

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 4 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the CSIRO tested Termimesh, a stainless steel barrier method of excluding termites from structures; if so (a) what tests were conducted; (b) who conducted them; and (c) what were the results of each of the tests conducted.

(2) Is it the opinion of the CSIRO researchers conducting tests on Termimesh that further tests are required to establish the efficacy of its use as a method of protecting new structures from termite attack; if so, what are the additional tests the CSIRO and/or researchers conducting tests on Termimesh consider are required; if not, do researchers conducting tests on Termimesh consider Termimesh stainless steel barriers to be a fully developed method to protect new structures from termites; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) CSIRO has tested Termimesh to assess its efficiency as a termite barrier. The tests were conducted by the Division of Entomology, Canberra. The results are given in two Divisional reports by M Lenz and S Runko, Report No. 90/11 October 1990 and Report No. 91/15 August 1991. The results of tests on both reports were generally satisfactory in that termites did not breach the mesh except in one instance where one species of termite with a head width of 0.76mm passed through the mesh. The openings of the mesh were reduced to 0.67x0.45mm to prevent this.

(2) The CSIRO Division of Building, Construction and Engineering (DBCE) is of the view that further appraisal is required before Termimesh can be considered to be sufficiently developed for national application to new construction. This is being conducted by a DBCE Officer through Australian Building Systems Appraisal Council (ABSAC) and concerns physical properties, durability and installation procedures with particular reference to Australian Standard AS2057-1986 `Protection of Buildings from Subterranean Termites'. Following this work details of optimum installation have been developed with the manufacturer, reports of corrosion tests received and inspections made of trial installations. Following ABSAC advice, a training program for franchised installers is being adopted. Comments from State regional committees are being obtained in relation to State requirements under the Building Code of Australia before issuing an appraisal document. A satisfactory appraisal generally ensures approval by local government building surveyors for use in construction.
